Would I recommend this game? The answer is a glaring "Maybe". 

Pros:
+ fun gameplay, chill with friends
+ lots of different PvE content
+ PvP can be fun

Cons:
- absolutely horrendous, non-existent ACCESSIBILITY options: no adjustable FoV over 90, no turning off head bobbing or motion blur. 
There's tons of posts all over the internet of people getting motion sick from SoT. Games with First Person perspective should do better nowadays!!
- mandatory PvP opens you up to griefers
- oh, the whole "mandatory pvp"-part? yeah, not only can't you avoid pvp, the game is also almost always a mess of game breaking bugs, so better pray, that if you get attacked and anchored, you won't get the bug, where your anchor suddenly can't be interacted with any more. 
IF YOU WANT US TO GIT GUD AND SHIT, maybe you start with an even playing field? but that's just the LOGICAL suggestion, i don't think anyone at rare is particularly fond of logic. 
- Tutorial is relatively useless
- if you give a damn about your Avg. Game Completion Rate, this game is a nightmare. 217 mostly grindy achievements at the time of this review. For reference, I'm about 100 hours into the game and have an Achievement Completion of 30%.

I've played 4.2 hrs, and for 4 of them I was stuck in the character creation screen trying not to pull my own hair out. Honestly trying to create a character in this game that you like is more painful than grabbing your potato peeler from your kitchen and proceeding to skin yourself alive. In fact skinning yourself alive would probably be faster.

This games customisation is infuriating to say the least.

Now to say that I've only played the tutorial twice (yes, that's right, you can't skip it after deleting your char and then making a new one) it forces you to play it all over again.

Either way, from what I've saw of the tutorial so far, the game shows some promise, I'm hoping once I've finally settled on a character that I'm happy with, I'll then finally get to try the proper game and leave a more productive review.

However because the character creation is so bad, and I'm going to have to do the tutorial for a 3rd time in a row, I'm going to give this game a thumbs down for the time being.

Update..

Now that I've managed to play the game a little more, I will say this, despite it not having a very good customisation system, the game it's self can be a lot of fun. I personally wouldn't recommend playing this game solo, that's not to say it can't be done, in fact my partner clearly enjoys playing this game, solo or with her friends.

I personally found that this game is best only played with friends, when I played this game with my partner and her good friend Dani, I'm not going to lie I really enjoyed myself. This is something I honestly didn't think would have be the case, as normally I find playing in a groups with multiple people, it can somehow leave you feeling a little socially burnt out, well at least for myself it tends to do this.

However there was just something different about this game, somehow the team work just felt really fun, my partner would helm the ship whilst me and her good friend would man the cannons.

When the ship started to take damage I would then drop below deck and bail the water with the tidy wee bucket that the game supplies you with. There was just something oddly fun about getting water into a bucket and running up the stairs with it and pouring it over the side of the boat. I don't know maybe I'm just a little odd.

Then there is the repairing aspect of the ship, there is just something oddly satisfying about putting planks of wood over big gaping holes and watching the water slowly trickle to a stop.

So between the firing of the cannons, the bailing of the water, and the running back and forth like a headless chicken whist trying to repair the ship and hoping for it to not sink, the game feels strangely entertaining, and a lot of fun.

There is also fishing in this game, which is actually done really well, its basically a mini fishing game built into a pirate, ship welding, sea exploring, treasure hunting, adventure, pvp, ship destroying, gun firing, sword swinging, hand jerking, tit shaking (oh wait, them last two parts might be from a different type of game) My bad, but you get the idea.

Well anyway, I think the game as a whole is a lot of fun, however I have noticed sometimes there are cheaters on the server when I've been watching my partner play, luckily I haven't had to experience that for myself just yet.

Hopefully this is something the developers are working on and will fix in time.

Oh and I forgot to mention the fireworks in this game are actually really well done. (they are very realistic) for a cartoon style game.

So, with that all said, would I recommend getting this game? I would say Yes if you plan to play it  with friends, and No if you are planning to just play it on your own.

I think until they add an anti cheat and maybe change the customisation options of creating your character then I'm going to leave this still as thumbs down.

This game is by no means bad, quite the opposite really. It just needs a few improvements and it could be a masterpiece.

EDIT / update... So the more you play this game, the more you start to love it, so for that reason, I will now give this game a thumbs up.

This game is incredible. I want every person who said that it's "an ocean wide and an inch deep" to stick a tankard of Grog where the sun don't shine. Its lack of a main story slightly alarmed me at first, but the many charming tall tales make up for it tenfold. There is so much to do in this game, so much for leveling, and yet, it never becomes unfair. There is no level where you get a better cutlass, ship, or gun. You can even earn the game's purchase-based currency. Just when you think you've run out of things to do on the Sea of Thieves, there is more. Playing with friends makes for a top-tier comedic pirating experience,  with mechanics like locking people in the Brig, damaging teammates with Blunderbombs, playing music, and eating leeches. Playing solo is just as fun, leveling up the many trading companies' reputations to unlock more missions. The fact that there are negative reviews for this game astounds me. My only regret is not buying it sooner. 

-Proud captain of the Bucket O' Holes

Ingredients
Pizza Crust (makes 2)
3 and 1/4 cups (406g) all-purpose flour (spooned & levelled)
1/2 cup (60g) yellow cornmeal
1 and 1/4 teaspoons salt
1 Tablespoon (12g) granulated sugar
2 and 1/4 teaspoons (7g) Platinum Yeast from Red Star instant yeast (1 standard packet)*
1 and 1/4 cups (300ml) slightly warm water
1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, divided (1/4 cup melted, 1/4 cup softened to room temperature)
olive oil for coating
Tomato Sauce for Both Pizzas
2 Tablespoons (28g) unsalted butter
1 small onion, grated (about 1/3 cup)*
3/4 teaspoon salt
1 teaspoon dried oregano
1/2 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes (optional, but recommended)
3 garlic cloves, minced
one 28-ounce can (794g) crushed tomatoes*
1/4 teaspoon granulated sugar
Toppings for Both Pizzas
4 cups (about 16 oz) shredded mozzarella cheese*
1/2 cup (45g) grated parmesan cheese
optional: 1/2 cup sliced pepperoni
optional: 4 slices bacon, cooked and crumbled
Cook Mode Prevent your screen from going dark
Instructions
Please use my step-by-step photos below this written out recipe as a guide to making the pizza. For best results and ease of mind, read through the recipe completely before beginning. You will need two deep dish 9×2-inch round cake pans if you are making both pizzas at the same time. You can also use 9-inch springform pans.
For the crust: Combine the flour, cornmeal, salt, sugar, and yeast in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook attachment. If you do not have a stand mixer, use your hand mixer and a very very large bowl. If you do not have any mixer, you will do this all by hand. Again, use a very large bowl. Give those ingredients a quick toss with your mixer on low or with a large wooden spoon. Add the warm water and 1/4 cup of melted butter. The warm water should be around 90°F (32°C). Make sure it is not very, very hot or it will kill the yeast. Likewise, make sure the butter isn’t boiling hot. If you melt it in the microwave, let it sit for 5 minutes before adding. On low speed, beat (or stir) the dough ingredients until everything begins to be moistened. Continuing on low speed (or remove from the bowl and knead by hand if you do not own a mixer), beat the dough until it is soft and supple and gently pulls away from the sides of the bowl and falls off of the dough hook- about 4-5 minutes. If the dough is too hard (it will be textured from the cornmeal), but if it feels too tough, beat in 1 teaspoon of warm water. Alternatively, if it feels too soft, beat in 1 Tablespoon of flour.
Remove the dough from the bowl and form into a ball. Lightly grease a large mixing bowl with olive oil and place the dough inside, turning it around so that all sides of the dough are coated in the oil. Cover the bowl tightly with aluminum foil and allow to rise in a warm environment for 1-2 hours or until double in size.
Once the dough is ready, lightly flour a large work surface. Remove dough from the bowl, set the bowl and aluminum foil aside (to use later). Gently punch down the dough to remove any air bubbles and roll the dough into a large 15×12-inch rectangle. Spread 1/4 cup of softened butter on top of the dough. Roll it up lengthwise per the photos below. Cut the dough log in half. Form the two pieces of dough into balls and place back into your greased bowl. Cover with aluminum foil and allow to rise in the refrigerator (not in a warm place) for 1 hour until they are puffy as you make the sauce.
For the sauce: Place butter in a medium saucepan over medium heat and allow it to melt. Once melted, add the grated onion, salt, oregano, and red pepper flakes. Once the onion has slightly browned after about 5 minutes, add the garlic, tomatoes, and sugar. Turn the heat down to low-medium and allow it to simmer until it’s hearty, fragrant, and thick- about 30 minutes. You’ll have about 2 and 1/2 cups of sauce at this point. If you have more than that, keep simmering until the amount has reduced. Remove from heat and set aside until ready to be used. You may store the sauce in a tightly covered container in the refrigerator for up to 2 days if planning to make the pizza another day. You may freeze this sauce for up to 2 months as well.
Preheat oven to 425°F (218°C).
Assemble the pizzas: After the dough balls have risen in the refrigerator, they should be puffy. Keep one ball of dough in the refrigerator as you work with the first one. Roll it out on a lightly floured work surface, working it into a 12-inch circle. Using your rolling pin as a guide (see photos below), place over a 9×2-inch deep dish cake pan. Using your fingers, press the dough into the cake pan. Make sure it is nice and tight fitting inside the pan. Trim any excess dough off the edges with a small knife. Repeat with 2nd dough. Brush the top edges of the dough with a little olive oil, which gives the crust a beautiful sheen. Fill each pizza with 1/2 of the cheese (about 2 cups/8 oz per pizza), then the pepperoni and bacon or your desired toppings. Pour about 1 and 1/4 cups (300ml) of sauce evenly on top of each. If you do not like that much sauce, you can reduce to 3/4 cup (180ml) per pizza and have leftover sauce. Sprinkle each with 1/4 cup (22g) of grated parmesan cheese.
Place the cake pans on top of a large baking sheet, which will catch anything potentially spilling over the sides of the pans. (Nothing usually does.) Bake for 20-28 minutes or until the crust is golden brown. Feel free to loosely cover the pizzas with aluminum foil after the 15 minute mark to prevent any heavy browning and uneven baking. Remove the pizzas from the oven and allow to cool in the pans placed on a wire rack for 10 minutes. After 10 minutes, slice, serve, and enjoy. Place any leftover pizza in an airtight container and refrigerate for up to 5 days.  Reheat leftovers in a 300°F (149°C) oven for 15-20 minutes or until hot.
Notes
Make Ahead & Freezing Instructions: Dough may be prepared through step 4. In the last part of this step, the dough needs to rise in the refrigerator for 1 hour. You may leave it in the refrigerator for up to 1 full day, making sure to punch it down to remove any air bubbles before rolling out as directed in step 7. You may freeze the pizza doughs after preparing them through step 4, and instead of allowing to rise in the refrigerator, simply freeze for up to 2 months. Then, allow the doughs to thaw overnight in the refrigerator and allow to rise at room temperature for 1 hour before continuing with step 7. Make-ahead and freezing instructions for the sauce are written in step 5.
Special Tools (affiliate links): 9×2-inch Round Cake Pans or 9-inch Springform Pans | Electric Mixer (Handheld or Stand) | Glass Mixing Bowl | Wooden Spoon | Rolling Pin | Saucepan | Box Grater
Yeast: Platinum Yeast from Red Star is an instant yeast. You can use any quick rise or instant yeast in this recipe. You can also use active dry yeast in this recipe with zero changes. The rise time may be slightly longer if using active dry yeast.
Onion & Tomatoes: Please see notes below the recipe in the step-by-step photos for details about the grated onion and the can of crushed tomatoes.
Cheese: You can use sliced mozzarella or shredded mozzarella cheese.
Toppings: Feel free to swap the pepperoni and bacon with cooked and crumbled sausage, thinly sliced green peppers and/or onions, sliced mushrooms, etc. Add enough toppings to suit your tastes.

Ah, Sea of Thieves, the magnificent opus of maritime marvels and untold adventures that unfurl like the billowing sails of a grand galleon upon the boundless canvas of the ocean, weaving a tapestry of boundless wonder and limitless possibility across the azure expanse of the seas. Step foot onto the weathered planks of your ship, where the salty tang of the sea mingles with the intoxicating scent of adventure, and embark upon a voyage that transcends mere mortal imagination, beckoning daring souls to chart their own course amidst the shifting tides of fate.

In this vast and intricate world, every ripple upon the water tells a story, each gust of wind carries whispers of distant lands waiting to be explored, and the horizon stretches out before you like a blank page upon which the epic saga of your adventures will be written. From the sun-drenched shores of tropical paradises, where palm-fringed beaches beckon with promises of buried treasure and sunken wrecks hide secrets of untold riches, to the mist-shrouded isles haunted by the echoes of ancient legends, where the spirits of long-lost pirates roam and the very air crackles with arcane energy, the Sea of Thieves is a realm steeped in mystery and intrigue, where secrets lie buried beneath the sands of time, waiting to be unearthed by those bold enough to seek them out.

But beware, for the waters are not without their perils, and danger lurks in the shadows, unseen and unfathomable. Sail beneath the towering silhouette of a kraken, its tentacles thrashing in a primal dance, or lock swords with the skeletal crew of a cursed vessel, bound to the ocean's depths by a vengeful curse that knows no mercy. Yet, with each challenge overcome, with every obstacle surmounted, the bonds of camaraderie between you and your crewmates grow stronger, forged in the crucible of adversity and tempered by the fires of shared triumphs and trials.

And it is not only the thrill of battle that calls out to intrepid sailors, but the promise of discovery and adventure that lies beyond the horizon. Traverse labyrinthine caves and forgotten ruins, solve ancient riddles and decipher cryptic maps, as you uncover the lost relics of a bygone era and unlock the secrets of the fabled Pirate's Code, written in blood and bound in legend. But amidst the clamor of cannons and the clash of cutlasses, there are moments of tranquility and reflection, as you and your crewmates gather around a crackling campfire beneath a star-strewn sky, swapping tales of daring escapades and shared victories, and forging memories that will endure for eternity.

So hoist the sails, unfurl the flags, and set forth upon the open sea, for the world of Sea of Thieves awaits, a realm of boundless wonder and limitless possibility where the next great adventure lies just beyond the horizon. And as you chart your course amidst the ebb and flow of fortune, may the winds of fate carry you ever onward, to new lands and untold treasures, and may the spirit of adventure guide you on your journey, now and forevermore, for in the world of Sea of Thieves, the only limit is your imagination, and the next great adventure is always just over the horizon, beckoning you with its siren song of promise and peril, glory and greed. There are some things about the game that annoy me greatly, and that I wish I'd known before buying.  I'm REALLY glad I got it on sale!  

1st, you are LOCKED into 1ST PERSON ONLY!!!  I much prefer 3rd person games.  I want to actually be able to see my character.  1st person works fine for shooters, like DOOM or Halo, where you're playing a specific named character who is fully covered in a generic suit of body armour, BUT in a game that ostensibly allows you to have a "custom character," it really sucks not being able to see that character (especially if you end up spending a bunch of money on cosmetics).  I will NEVER spend real money on cosmetics in this game, I can promise you that.  Why have cosmetics at all if you can't even see them?  I don't care what other players think of my character's looks.  

2nd, the "character creation" screen is really irritating.  This RANDOM ROLL is silly.  It takes forever to find a character that you find cool or interesting, and you can't make any personal changes to the randomly rolled model.  Not a fan of this system.  

This game, like all fantasy games, should have both 1st and 3rd person modes, that you can switch between on the fly, and a decent character creation screen.  Skyrim is a perfect example of this.  Same with Fallout 4.  Heck, even other MMO style games, like the much older SWTOR, or even ESO, allow it.  Otherwise, the game comes across as nothing more than a pirate-themed shooter, and that's not what it was advertised as.

Now that I've had a chance to play the game with some friends, I will say that the game is a lot of fun, IF you have a group of friends to play with.  Solo, the game is not much fun.  If my friends didn't play this game, I would never play it again.  The artwork is bright, colourful, and cartoonish, and can be downright beautiful, especially the weather and wave effects!

I stand by what I've already said.  Let me also add another few annoyances.  Being ganked by campers, who the game allows to literally disguise themselves as barrels, is ridiculous.  What kind of jabroni gets his kicks by hiding on someone's ship for sometimes HOURS?  Nothing better to do, huh?  And a lot of these folks are the type who will call you "gay" or other lame "insults" when they've killed you via cowardly sneakery; only thing missing is the juvenile "tea-bagging."  

So, as you can tell, I don't enjoy PvP games.  It's partly because (admittedly) I really suck at PvP, BUT its also because I don't like a-holes and PvP games almost always attract that sort... the most juvenile and childish of gamers (and I'm not talking about literal children). 
 
They added the "safer seas" option to the game, so that folks can PvE in peace... but they've made that a hassle, too, by not allowing you to use your own purchased ships in PvE, as well as making handing in treasure much more of a hassle in PvE.  Why?  Just let people have fun with this cartoonish game, whether they prefer PvP OR PvE!

Finally, the item wheel is one of the strangest and least intuitive that I've ever been forced to use in a game.  Seriously, designers... what were you thinking?!  Have you ever played a video game before?

Sea of Thieves, developed by Rare Ltd., is a game that promises players the ultimate pirate experience, allowing them to embark on thrilling adventures on the high seas, explore vast uncharted islands, engage in epic naval battles, and uncover hidden treasures. Since its launch, Sea of Thieves has undergone significant updates and expansions, continuously evolving to offer new content and experiences to its dedicated player base. In this extensive review, we'll delve deep into the world of Sea of Thieves, exploring its gameplay mechanics, immersive world, community-driven elements, and overall experience.

Gameplay:
At the heart of Sea of Thieves lies its unique and immersive gameplay mechanics, which seamlessly blend exploration, naval combat, and cooperative multiplayer elements. Players begin their journey as aspiring pirates, starting with a humble ship and a map full of unexplored islands and treacherous waters. The core gameplay loop involves sailing the open seas, searching for buried treasure, battling fearsome creatures, and engaging in encounters with other players or AI-controlled ships.

What sets Sea of Thieves apart is its emphasis on player-driven experiences and emergent gameplay. Every voyage feels like a new adventure, with no two sessions playing out the same. The dynamic weather system, unpredictable encounters with other players, and the ever-present threat of the kraken or megalodon ensure that players are constantly kept on their toes.

The cooperative multiplayer aspect of Sea of Thieves is where the game truly shines. Crews of players must work together to navigate their ship, manage sails and cannons, and communicate effectively to overcome challenges. Whether engaging in intense ship-to-ship combat, solving riddles to uncover buried treasure, or simply enjoying the camaraderie of sailing with friends, Sea of Thieves fosters memorable moments and shared experiences like few other games.

Graphics and Sound:
Visually, Sea of Thieves boasts a stunning and vibrant art style that perfectly captures the spirit of a whimsical pirate adventure. From the shimmering turquoise waters and lush tropical islands to the detailed ship designs and dynamic lighting effects, every aspect of the game's visuals contributes to its immersive world.

The sound design further enhances the atmosphere, with the creaking of wooden ships, the roar of cannon fire, and the haunting melodies of the sea shanties creating an auditory experience that pulls players deeper into the game's world.

World and Exploration:
One of the greatest strengths of Sea of Thieves is its expansive and beautifully crafted world, comprised of a vast ocean dotted with islands of varying sizes and biomes. Each island offers its own unique challenges and rewards, from hidden caves filled with treasure to ancient ruins teeming with danger.

Exploration is a core element of the Sea of Thieves experience, with players encouraged to venture off the beaten path in search of adventure. The game's world is filled with secrets to discover, including hidden underwater caves, sunken shipwrecks, and elusive mythical creatures.

Community and Social Interaction:
Sea of Thieves places a strong emphasis on community and social interaction, with multiplayer being a central focus of the gameplay experience. Whether teaming up with friends or joining a crew of strangers, players must work together to navigate the treacherous waters and overcome the myriad challenges that await them.

The game's community-driven events and activities further foster a sense of camaraderie among players, with regular updates and content drops keeping the experience fresh and engaging over time. From large-scale server-wide events to smaller-scale player-run gatherings, Sea of Thieves offers a variety of ways for players to connect and interact with one another.

Progression and Customization:
While Sea of Thieves prioritizes player skill and cooperation over traditional progression systems, the game does offer a variety of ways for players to customize their pirate and ship. Players can unlock new cosmetics, such as clothing, weapons, and ship decorations, through in-game achievements and events, allowing them to personalize their characters and vessels to reflect their individual style.

Additionally, the game's reputation system tracks players' progress across various factions, rewarding them with unique rewards and titles as they complete missions and objectives. This system provides a sense of long-term progression and achievement, incentivizing players to continue exploring the game's world and engaging with its content.

Overall Experience:
Sea of Thieves is a truly unique and immersive gaming experience that captures the thrill and adventure of a life on the high seas. With its richly detailed world, dynamic gameplay mechanics, and emphasis on player-driven experiences, the game offers endless opportunities for exploration, discovery, and shared adventure.

Whether sailing solo in search of hidden treasure, engaging in epic naval battles with rival crews, or simply enjoying the camaraderie of sailing with friends, Sea of Thieves provides an unforgettable gaming experience that keeps players coming back for more. With its regular updates and expansions, the game continues to evolve and grow, ensuring that there's always something new to discover on the horizon.

In conclusion, Sea of Thieves is a must-play title for anyone who has ever dreamed of becoming a pirate. Its immersive world, engaging gameplay, and vibrant community make it one of the most compelling multiplayer experiences available today. So hoist the sails, raise the anchor, and set forth on an epic adventure that you won't soon forget.

Hundreds of hours, and hundreds of £ put into this game, and then they removed the ability to change FoV about their "90" (Which isn't true 90 degrees, it's just labelled 90 due to how they measure it), making it near impossible to play for more than half an hour without feeling sick. 

The worst part is that the community is so toxic that merely suggesting that accessibility options that most games contain by now should be a standard will get you banned in discussions and forums for "promoting cheating". I do not want to cheat, I simply want to play the game comfortably without making myself sick. 

This review will remain negative until the patch that blocks client-side edits is removed, or the developers finally increase the in-game FoV slider to reach at least the advertised 90 degrees for real.

EDIT - 2 years later and this still remains true, even though PVP is no longer enforced, destroying that argument. Now the only reason not to include higher FOV is laziness on part of the developer and a distinct lack of care for accessibility or inclusivity.

EDIT - Just wanted to add the devs are now actively silencing anyone mentioning fov. Google "sea of thieves FOV" and you get thousands of complaints, but the forums have 0 results. Post about it and you get banned. Absolutely insane I supported this game in the past.

Let me just say first up: this is a beautifully artistic game. It looks gorgeous, it has tons of little quirks and features that you won't pick up on initially that require time spent to figure out, and it has a ton of content to explore.

EDIT: Looks like the devs finally caved and added a "safer seas" mode, albeit they capped the rewards on it pretty hard. While the effort to appeal to a wider player base is appreciated, I feel like it is too little too late. I briefly tried it but honestly I've kind of lost interest in Seas at this point as has pretty much everyone else I game with. 

***Original criticisms***:

That being said, this game has a real problem with PvP in the sense that there are a group of people out there just trying to grind out gold/reputation/complete adventures and then there are a group of people that just want to fuck with other players and IMO, the 2 shouldn't be forced to mix and the fact that this game does not have a PVE only mode is a real shame and makes it very difficult to introduce the game to new players. It's at the point where there are enough players out there who have 500hrs+ in this game that are playing on a totally different level than new players that they may as well be playing a totally different game because you don't stand a chance against them. And if you're a new player or someone trying to bring a new player into the game, it's really hard to convince them they should play this game when you lose a ship full of hard work to some sweat lord in 5 min. Hell, it makes just playing as a solo sloop obnoxious if all you're trying to do is grind out some rep. I've also encountered some incredibly toxic players in this game, it's probably been one of the worst communities I've experienced taking 2nd only to MOBA players. 

I don't know if the game intentionally lacks matchmaking or if there just aren't enough players to balance a server but the number of times new players get rolled in with people who have been playing for way too long just feels broken.  Whatever the case is, I can't really recommend this game to anyone unless all you're looking for is another straight up PVP game until Rare ever decides to add some PVE only mode. 

And the thing is, this would be *super* easy to do, add a checkbox at the lobby, up the spawn rate of ghost ships to force more ship encounters, make the rep/gold rewards lower to encourage people to play PVP if they want max rewards, etc. I'm sure at this point, it's a matter of choice, not technical challenge. Either that, or don't throw people who have been playing this game for 2 hrs in the same server as people who have been playing this game for 2000 hrs because it just isn't fun, and if you're first experience with a game is "wow, that was a fucking waste of time", then what's the point?

This is more of a review of the new Safer Seas update and what it brings to the table than SoT as a whole. SoT is a fantastic game. Good combat, good stories, good ambiance. 
That being said: Safer Seas feels, in a word, fantastic. I wouldn't mind AI reaper ships that actively hunt you even to give a little bit of that 'watch your back' sense that the High Seas has. 
As for complaints, Rareware has a beast of a game hindered by itself. It is ruthless, with having less players being an absolute disadvantage with really no recourse and a extremely toxic player base. Not to say that isn't necessarily in the spirit of the game, but it is a game all the same.
And being a game, while it gimps your progress significantly I think safer seas is a great direction that provides an out for Rare from being stuck between a rock and a hard place. That being a live service game that needs more players and a player base that actively chases away would-be players. 
I do think the largest thing handicapping Safer Seas is the Live Service. Not it directly, but if you bust cash to look great in PvP, Safer Seas does take away from that. Aside from that, an offline mode cannot be provided as that would be a great in for hacking and currency duping. (I am sure there are also technical issues and back end problems as well).
All in all, very happy with the direction taken and I hope for more to come.

In a gaming landscape filled with hyper-realistic graphics and complex mechanics, sometimes it's refreshing to set sail on a different kind of adventure. Rare's "Sea of Thieves" offers players just that—an immersive world of pirates, treasure, and boundless exploration. As someone who has spent countless hours navigating its vast oceans, I can attest to the sheer joy and excitement that this game brings.

One of the most captivating aspects of "Sea of Thieves" is its emphasis on player-driven experiences. Unlike traditional single-player games with linear storylines, "Sea of Thieves" encourages collaboration and creativity among crews of players. Whether you're embarking on a daring treasure hunt, engaging in epic naval battles, or simply enjoying the serenity of sailing under a starlit sky, every moment in the game feels uniquely yours.

One of my fondest memories in "Sea of Thieves" was the time my crew and I stumbled upon a sunken shipwreck laden with treasure. As we eagerly plundered its depths, we suddenly found ourselves under attack by a rival crew. What ensued was a thrilling battle for survival, complete with sword fights, cannon volleys, and daring escapes. In the end, our perseverance paid off, and we emerged victorious, our pockets overflowing with loot and our hearts pounding with adrenaline.

But beyond its exhilarating gameplay, "Sea of Thieves" also offers moments of quiet reflection and camaraderie. Whether you're sharing stories with fellow pirates around a campfire, playing a shanty on the deck of your ship, or simply watching the sunset from the crow's nest, the game fosters a sense of community and friendship that is truly special.

Of course, "Sea of Thieves" is not without its challenges and frustrations. From treacherous storms to relentless skeleton hordes, the game throws plenty of obstacles in your path. But it's the overcoming of these obstacles, together with your crewmates, that makes the experience so rewarding.

In the end, "Sea of Thieves" is more than just a game—it's a voyage of discovery, a testament to the power of imagination, and a celebration of the joy of play. So if you ever find yourself yearning for adventure on the high seas, I highly recommend hoisting the anchor, raising the sails, and setting course for the shimmering waters of "Sea of Thieves." Fair winds and following seas, mateys!

I have sunk almost 1000 hours into this game from both my Xbox Game Pass hours and my Steam hours. Its definitely a fun game that is worth a try. Honestly there really isn't any other game like it. The Sea Of Thieves community is for the most part a friendly community. Yes there is toxicity but I would put roughly 1/4 of the community into that category. Getting started can be rough as a new player, specifically trying to learn the dynamics of the game; as well as learning what to do and not to do so your ship does not sink. 

The game is basically a large sandbox, you have a map with islands and outposts darted around the map that you can explore; with something called "world events" that pop up randomly on the servers that you can go complete. World events are a good and fun way to get treasure to sell; which is ultimately the main goal of free roaming in the game. Selling treasure is the main way to make gold in the game, which will give you the ability to buy cosmetics and ships. There is no pay to win in the game, its only cosmetics which I can appreciate from a competitive standpoint. World events are PVE events but can quickly be contested by other pirates roaming the sea and then it can quickly turn into a PVP/PVE event, which is probably one of my favorite parts of the game. The PVP can be really fun and exciting, and is what I usually have the most fun doing now that I have completed all of the things there is to do in the game. 

However; if PVP is not your thing, you can stay doing PVE related things such as Tall Tales ((Quests)), aswell as staying on the PVE servers. You could literally just roam the seas and trying to catch all of the fish in the game and complete achievements/commendations. 

There is a skill gap in the game which is unfortunate. For the most part while in adventure mode you will run into pirates who are either really new at the game or extremely good at the game. Its seems rare for me to run into a pirate that is a perfectly good match in a fight. 

The community is fun because its diverse; I have ran into every type of person imaginable in the sea of thieves and think that's a cool aspect of open crew / looking for group posts. Its a game that both adults and kids can enjoy. 

I will say that I sometimes wish they would add more world events, and maybe another trading company. I would give the game a solid 4.5/5.0. Maybe a 4.0/5.0 on a bad day.

Here's an update on my review.  This game is basically a first person pirate simulator MMO with an astounding amount of content.  So much content that this game requires 100+ gigabytes to play.  It is amazing how the 2018 launch day game has evolved into one of the most content filled game to ever exist, with updates that completely change the game and a really interesting story.  Right now its way easier to become pirate legend in 2024 than it has ever been before.  You can do pretty much anything you want, because you are a free pirate.  There are issues with the game though.  And that is the funny RNG mechanic most SOT players call "Getting Rare'd."  You could be going back to a port to get some loot and then whoops! Gregg Mayles slipped his fingers.  Here comes a Meg.  Oh, that's not good enough?  How about a kraken and a skelly ship?  I feel that these RNG moments should be toned down a bit.  But there is one glaring issue with one of the new updates.  And that is "Safer Seas."  This infernal update allows you to basically turn SOT into a coop game.  Sounds good right? Oh wait, you get less loot and rep, and I don't like that.  So I want to play normal SOT on the high seas.  But EVERYBODY on the high seas thinks that "Oh, since theres a safer seas mode, we can kill anybody because they were 'asking for it' by being on this mode."  High seas have become a battlefield with the illusion of a normal gamemode.  Safer seas kind of ruined default SOT and now I can't enjoy a normal game with ships on my ass who don't even run reapers flag going after my ship.  If the devs read this, please do something about making high seas a bit safer for people who want to play SOT normally.

Let's start with this. This game is AMAZINGLY fun to play with family. I play with my wife and son and this have an absolute blast UNTIL you run into literally any other of the utterly toxic players. Horrible community simply harasses you until you leave the game. There are very obvious cheating issues happening as my son and I have been DDOS'd while playing. It's ridiculous that "safer seas" penalizes you for wishing not to play with the horrible community. Sea of Thieves is one of those games you don't recommend because it has deeply flawed mechanics but still play from time to time due to a lack of comparable competitors.

[h3]Why would you play SoT?[/h3]
The immersion is striking in my opinion.  
[i]You are the pirate.[/i] You set sails, control the steering wheel, aim the cannons, repair the ship. No crosshair aiding you in aim, no pop-up UI telling you you're ship is sinking, no NPCs aboard your ship doing things. Nothing happens by itself on your ship, everything must be done by players. The immersion is just great. That's why, from time to time you boot the game up again and slowly start realizing again

[h3]why you shouldn't play SoT.[/h3] 
• Servers have all crew sizes. They try to balance it, It's just one 4 people crew per server for example but, especially considering the following, more people is just better and thus being alone or with just a friend is simply unfun.
• When you sink an enemy they respawn. On the same server. Even on a nearby island. I think it speaks for itself why this is a fundamental flaw. The ship you sank in combat that maybe took over an hour and drained many of your ressources (cannonballs, planks, food) spawns on a nearby island, not rarely within sight on the horizon and it respawns with new supplies. They are at the battlefield again before you even had time to hook up all their loot and if you left the battle victorious but without cannonballs, to bad, now you have to flee. And this has no limit. You can sink the enemy a hundred times but as long as they are willing to chase you there's nothing you can do about it except sailing away and winning again, further draining your ressources.
• Most of the quests (I'd argue all that are actually worth it) rely on you leaving your ship for an extended amount of time for extremely repetetive tasks that are deliberately made so you spend as much time on an island as possible. For example riddles with successively unveiling tasks are "1) at the north coast... 2) at the wreck on the south coast... 3) at the bonfire on the northern hill..." You just spend time running back and forth leaving your ship and the horizon unmonitored. Bigger cre? no worries, you just can leave one behind on the lookout setting sails in an emergency, the crew can just teleport back to the ship. Alone or just a crew of 2? Pray no one sees your ship.
• The cosmetics are insanely expensive. This game is about customizing your ship, you can't buy anything that would give you an advantage in combat which by itself is awesome. Also there are [i] lots of [/i] different cosmetics which is also great. In my 160h I got about 10 million coins and I'd say that's pretty average. I didn't sail for the riskiest missions every time but also didn't do low risk low rewards missions either. Yet there are many cosmetics I still can't afford which just lowers the fun you get out of the game. Instead of having a realistic chance to collect all the cosmetics there are in lets say 1000h you have to grind sooo long for just a single set that endorphine spikes are rare.
• The story is, and I am serious, the worst story of any game I have ever played. People arguing "it's about the journey and the adventures on the way" just have no idea what good gameplay is. You can make a story about the journey and the adventures throughout it while still making it rewarding. The way it is is just a massive waste of time. Don't play the "Tall Tales". Or at least research beforehand what you get into. I was massively disappointed.

absolutely fucking terrible game

6.5/10 

I'll start with the positives, and the reasons I kept trying to give the game a chance. The environments were charming. I enjoyed the fact I could care for my own ship, and the ability to jump off into the water where I wanted was great. The character movement was smooth and I liked the dynamic elements to sailing, such a weather and other obstacles. That is, however where the love stops.

I will expand on the gripes I had with this game that were enough that I ultimately quit after roughly 3 hours. Something I didn't anticipate doing as I really wanted to love this game.

First, I can appreciate unique art design in a game. As an illustrator myself, I love quirky characters in games like the Wind Waker. However, some of the SoT player character templates look like something out of a creepy pasta lore. Now, that doesn't necessarily mean the design is bad, but it became a slight when it came to character creation.

Or should I say, lack of. 

I get the whole idea of the endless pirate generators, but here's the problem with it--it's almost impossible to get a look that is anything even remotely specific. I spent probably about 400 rolls on this thing to try and get SOMETHING that was half recognizable as a decent looking character. I'm not talking good-looking, I'm talking skyrim default character. The amount of bad results were astounding, because of one fatal flaw--zero filters. Can't even start with gender preference. Simply having a gender option would decrease the time by half (or more) for the player in selecting something they are satisfied with. And I got to thinking...what if I wanted a female, who had a medium build, with one of the shoulder length hairstyles, and black hair. Yeah, sorry kid, but here's a Gollum. 

It added insult to injury that more niche options were thrown into the mix for randomization at the same rate as the other options. For example, the old woman features. I am sure there are a small handful of people who like playing elderly looking characters, but most probably don't. And having elderly looking faces make up half the randomization alone just made it feel like an impossible probability. I either had to have grandmother face, or look like Shrek with the hair color I wanted.

And I may have not even remarked at this if it was a free game. But it's not. And initially, while put off by the fact a paid game wouldn't include some basic character customization, I shrugged it off and continued.

But it got worse.

After exploring briefly, I ran into the Pirate Emporium NPC--my first real content for the game. Well, turned out to be the cash shop, so I thought, might as well browse while I'm here. And then I saw it--a change appearance item. And just like that my gripe was solved. 

The item was $2.09. A strange amount. But it became clear once I was given an option to purchase coins. Their lowest package of premium coins is $1.99, just short of the needed $2.09, which forces the player to purchase the next tier up, with is $5.99.

This is a predatory practice, and I was really disappointed, because I grew up with games by Rare, some of my favorites that I had beaten dozens of times.  

But the nail in the coffin--was when I actually tried to use the appearance change item. Nothing could have prepared me for this. The character change cash shop item--only brings you back to random pirate generator. That's right. You do not actually modify the appearance of your current character. In fact, if you spent forever TRYING to get at least a few features you wanted for your character with merry-go-round of ugly, you will in fact lose ALL features you liked and have to start right back at the bottom.  

This was the last straw for me. I just wasn't interested anymore. You see, when I invest in a game long term, I have no problem with dishing out hundreds over the course of my time playing. But when a studio uses rancid marketing practices without a modicum of respect for the players, I can't support it.

I don't usually write comments, specially negative ones, but this is not acceptable. I played a little when this game was about 30 Gb, now the store says it's 50 Gb. It's actually [b]103.3 Gb[/b], more than [b]300% its original size[/b] when I bought it, with mostly cosmetics and some game modes/ history added. Mostly cosmetics. No major changes in gameplay, no radical new mechanics introduced: graphical updates mostly. 60 Gb worth of graphical updates and barely any lore, in an open world exploration game focused on player interaction. No bigger maps, no extra mechanics, ships, or otherwise gameplay oriented modifications to improve the open world feel; just graphics and a little lore.[b]About 60 Gb worth of that[/b]. Yay.

I write this more as a warning than a genuine dislike for the game. I actually like this game. I just can no longer play it unless I want to uninstall about 5 or 6 other games that haven't done anything wrong, are quality games and I enjoy playing. So this one? I don't know when I'll play it or if I'll play it again, to be honest.

Don't buy it if you're not ready to have practically 100 Gb of space occupied by a game. Or if you think 60 Gb of graphics is a bit much for a game, and maybe gameplay should be the focus. I know I would definitely not have bought this game had I known that this is the road the developers had planned for it. To me this is a cheap way to get players to engage with a game that is no longer developing.

This game is really unique and has a lot to offer but in the past 2 years the developers have let bugs grow out of hand.
At the end of 2022 a pvp on demand mode was added to the game (after the previous one was removed because the devs didn't properly maintain it through updates). 

This was a good change that allowed the pvp community to experience combat without the hassle of finding players in the open world. Returning after 7 months of playing I decided to derust by playing this mode. 
I played 7 matches and in each I experienced at least 1 game breaking bug. 6 occurred where I encountered something called "mast bug" where the opponents mast can not be seen moving and the state of repair it is in can not be seen. This can make choosing when to attack difficult. 
2 occurred where "anchor bug" happened meaning you can not lower the anchor of the opponents ship. 
1 match even had a respawn bug that makes it so you can't leave the death screen until you fully time out of it, something that completely disrupts the flow of combat and lead to me losing my advantage and sinking before I could even get to the ferry. 
Many of the bugs have been in the game for a month now and the respawn bug has been in since 2022.

The devs are too heavily focused on monetisation never missing a monthly item shop update yet failing to meet their own seasonal schedule often extending seasons by months to add content updates that contain less than old monthly updates, or to patch bugs that have been in the game since launch.

As of writing this the game has no anticheat and hasn't had one for 5 years, despite one being announced 18 months ago. Cheaters can keep their accounts for literal months but ban evaders are banned within days sometimes hours.

Racism and homophobia is common in the game and despite being against TOS many people receive temp bans for repeat offences. You can even get banned for spawn camping and behaving "toxic" to these people.

This game is genuinely one of the best things I've ever played when no bugs occur but every update for the past 2-3 years has implemented bug upon bug with fixes still managing to break other parts of the game. If you enjoy pve fixes are more common but still take a while and for pvp players some major bugs from launch such as the funny launch still haven't been attempted to be fixed.

If you can look past the glitches to a degree then go for it, you'll easily reach long play times with how unique each interaction has the potential to be. If you can't, keep an eye on the game until major changes happen, if they do it is well worth trying.

Sea of Thieves is a great game and I would recommend this game, but there are a few bad things to it if you aren't that good at fast-paced games that take hours of grinding just to know that there is a chance for all of that hard work to be stolen by someone else and redeemed by them.
First, its combat can be really fast - Boom!! You've been hit, your mast is down, and you're sinking! What do you do? Well, Sea of Thieves is a hard game and I've found out that working together as a team helps so much and can help you against your first battle. Even if you have two friends who aren't that good at the game, they can still help a lot by bucketing stray water out of the ship, steering the ship, and controlling the main combat. These are all vital roles that are hard for just one person to do, and it gets really hard when you meet a sweat with or without his friends. I would just say that for one, if you don't think you will be good at super-fast complicated combat, then you should have a few friends to help you loot the mighty fine islands and underwater dungeons of the Sea of Thieves.
Second of all, looting and getting treasure takes forever. Getting treasure takes forever, especially when you first start, and that's because you have to do quests that require you to do things like, "Go to this island, defeat these hordes of enemies and the final skeleton boss, and now dig up the treasure and bring it back to me for a little bit of gold." and you would have to do this over, and over, and over again until you die. No, no I'm just kidding, but you have to inevitably put 21 hours of your life into the game just doing that to even do anything with the gold. Now trust me Sea of Thieves is a great game, but only when you play it with friends, because when you do these quests alone you feel miserable, depressed, and bored, and therefore can only do a few of these horrible quests before wanting to get off, BUT if you add friends you are now not alone and you feel contented, cheerful, and entertained!! Believe me when I say that Sea of Thieves is 17.82 times BETTER WITH FRIENDS THAN WITHOUT HAVING FRIENDS TO PLAY WITH.
Third of all, Sea of Thieves is a great game so don't get scared. Sea of Thieves is a game of challenge, a game of dedication, you can't just run off when scared that you're going to work so hard and lose all of your treasure, but instead, you have to play and play like it's your first time and thought that it was a PvE game and proceeded to loot everything in your way, but then sank and was looted by some sweats (Except exclude that part where YOU were sunken and replace that with the word THEM and proceed to cash in tons of loot). You should know, that Sea of Thieves is about losing some and winning more so there is no reason to get scared that you will lose some loot!! just come back better,! not only as a better fighter but a better captain, a better bounty hunter, a better booty seeker, and a better pirate. 
Overall, if you have 1-3 friends who will be willing to play with you mostly when you are ready to play the game, have a good computer that can run the game with decent graphics while still running the game fine. You have some experience in PvP (It's not required because you can learn the game, but if you do have experience in PvP then you should play the game) you should get Sea of Thieves because it changed my life, so I think that it can change yours... (For the better good of course!)

Sea of Thieves is probably my favorite modern game using the 'game as service' model, a genre that I might play a good deal of, but don't usually love in the same way that I do classic games like Mario or Zelda. Part of the reason I do love SoT is because of how exquisite the world feels. This game has a lot of charm and character, and this is partially due to how great it all looks. Map regions feel unique and distinct and islands feel handcrafted and not as copy paste as they could have been. Everything in the world feels like a lot of care, love, and talent went into it. This is a mature game (as in fully baked) developed by a mature company that (generally) knows what they are doing. 

Why do I say generally? Well... SoT is probably my favorite online game, but it comes with a giant asterisk that says "beautiful but flawed." I've watched this game grow since it's public release on Game Pass in 2018 from something with very little to do, to so much that it's almost overwhelming. As the game has grown, it has been polished and refined over time and now (currently season 11) the game seems like it's in a very great spot and has a lot to offer for new players and veterans alike. That being said, the game has some ummm... quirks. There are bugs that have been present since the beginning that have only gotten slightly improved - namely hit registration. This game has the potential to be very sweaty in the multiplayer mode (high seas) and wins and losses can be determined by flukes, accidents, and the servers just absolutely crapping themselves mid fight. There is a TON of math going on at any given time in the game, which makes things like location updates for objects, players, and bullets take a toll on the servers as it tries to work out what's happening every millisecond. This means that sometimes fights can come down to pure dumb luck, even when you and your opponent are playing at their best.

I've concluded that this game was originally intended to be a lot more casual than it became and that something in the early engine was not prepared for everything that eventually got stacked on top of it and now a decade since rare started development on SoT (2014) the proverbial house of cards is stacked too high to move one of the ones at the bottom. That's my speculation as an amateur game developer / programmer and I can't prove that for sure. Other quirks include long, arduous voyages / quests bugging out and not being able to finish them. Loot getting stuck in the ship or bugged out. Key voyage items glitching out, getting lost, not working properly. I've seen Rare fix a ton of bugs for this game, so I know they are doing good work and care about the game, but some of the ones that still plague the game are just beyond absurd. For example, lost shipments came out almost 3 years ago and it can still sometimes bug out and not give the manifest after hours of venturing with your friends. I just don't think this game was ever meant to be this big or sweaty and I don't think the engine / servers can handle what Rare are throwing at it. It concerns me that they are considering going back to 6 crews on a server instead of 5 given that it can barely handle the 5 we have at present. 

A new gripe is that "Safer Seas" aren't. While this has been seen by many as an extended tutorial for new or returning players, this game can still throw a lot at you even in PvE. I can regularly sink skeleton ships and kill megalodons solo and even then the game feels like the deck is stacked against me and the house always wins. I had an experience today where I accidentally stumbled upon a world event ship, a skeleton ship, and a megalodon all at the same time. I ended up sinking the skeleton ship and megalodon but died to the galleon. I eventually went back to the same spot and sank it and get the loot but it's odd that these kind of things can happen where it just seems unfair. I'm not an expert at the game, but I have several hundred hours in the game between this and my time on Game Pass and I can't imagine a new player going into safer seas to learn the ropes and then stumbling into something like this. For some people, it could be enough to make them bounce off the game and quit. Others might laugh at how absurd it is, but it ultimately made the last four hours of my time spent in the game essentially worthless as even after I got the loot from sinking the galleon a "Battle for the Sea of Thieves" world event triggered and I ended up loosing all the loot in the end. It's already worthless since it was in Safer Seas which only gives 30% treasure value (was experimenting with different voyages and going after events), but loosing the time was the more painful aspect of the experience. I can't imagine someone getting off of work and playing this and consistently enjoying every minute of their time and feeling like it's always worth playing or always a rewarding experience. Often it isn't, even on the High Seas. 

Speaking of. PvPvE. I've already mentioned how buggy the game can be at times and how this interferes with PvP. Polished high tic rate Counter Strike this game is not, but I won't beat that horse anymore. This game truly offers the highest of highs and the absolutely most agonizing gut wrenching lows of any game I've ever played. In real life I am usually an extremely calm and neutral person, to the point where it's likely a problem for others that interact with me expecting more... expressive forms communication. Most days I'm lake fucking placid, but SoT breaks me. I almost jump out of my seat when things go right and something finally works in our favor and goes as planned. I NEVER rage in games, but SoT sometimes makes me want to hurl my controller through my monitor, heart beating 100 miles and hour, sweaty as hell, fighting for my life. These kind of extremes are a bit much for me, as I pride myself in my ability to remain calm and rational in intense or unpleasant situations. I can only imagine what this game does to people that aren't like me and that are more prone to rage. This game has ZERO respect for your time and it doesn't mind reminding you of that fact with every major loss. The salt and the rage and the tears that this game brings out is real, and it sucks to loose even in a fair fight which brings me to my next point...

CHEATING! A problem that has constantly plagued the game, like the quirks and bugs, is the cheating. Probably my number one complaint is that it seems like nothing is being done, even as developer updates say otherwise. I have seen the most absurd shit happen in games where a player has been hit point blank over and over again and they won't die, ships stopping on a dime and rotating in mid air and hovering above the ocean and zooming across the map, cannons not damaging the ship or being comically inaccurate (even in perfect conditions and default cannon skin). It's hard to tell what's cheating and what's the game bugging out at times, and sometimes it can be hard to tell if you got out played or if someone is using cheats, exploits, etc.. to gain an unfair advantage in a fight. Some of the cheats are so subtle they could just be coincidence, sometimes fights just feel... wrong... or there is something off about them. Some of the cheats are extremely obvious. I've even heard rumor of a cheat that shows all the map circles and/or ship locations. And then sometimes players are just really fucking good at the game. And as the game is prone to being buggy / glitchy it makes it very hard to tell the two apart. I'm confident that while cheating is rampant in SoT (as they don't currently have a good anti-cheat and have commented on this problem) I'm sure half of the reports are just the game being weird or someone playing at a very high level. But my point is that the fact that it's so hard to tell the difference between good play and good cheats is not a good thing. If Rare can fix this, I think the SoT will be much better.

Honestly was a really fun game for the first 200 hours and the only reason i got that much out is because i absolutely love anything to do with the ocean and play lots of roguelikes and such so am used to repeating game loops with no real change in content, I dont really have any mates who play the game and when they did play with me it was a lot of fun but i honestly can’t recommend the game unless you have a consistent group to play with. Solo gets boring really fast, i became pretty damn good at pvp even being able to occasionally beat gally crews on my own but the missions themselves got extremely samesy after the first few dozen and the charm of the open seas and the panic of being attacked by krakens and megs wears off the instant you understand how to fight them. For a casual experience with friends its a great game but if you get even remotely good at the game or get to max level in any of the factions it just gets boring and the only progression being cosmetic means that theres really no point to playing the game once you’ve experienced everything. Theres a lot of “content” but most of it is just rehashed versions of the same thing, go here dig up thing, go here kill this thing, go to different island and repeat, deliver back to outpost or lose it on the way. Rinse repeat. Not to mention Rare has made some questionable decisions and a lot of the higher tier players have abandoned the game. 
TLDR: Lack of fresh feeling content, charm wears off fast, getting good makes the game boring and no real progression to make the game feel fresh after a few dozen hours or so

Edit: Forgot to mention that in the later stages of the game any progress will take weeks of nonstop play and perhaps even months if you dont have a lot of time to play, for instance some basic money sink cosmetics cost over 5 million gold for a single item which is fine and all but you need to enjoy the game for long enough to get there. The big one for me was the skeleton curse from the reapers pvp mode faction, i spent a solid week grinding and barely made any progress even with a 60+% win rate, and the grind just wasnt fun because most pvp players just cheese or play scared spending most of the fight running away turning it from a fun mode based around fighting to a slow boring mode based around who runs out of supplies first. Unfortunately when you get to the point where the only cosmetics (which are the only progression in this game at all) require weeks or even months of grinding for a single item and the grind itself isnt fun due to boring and repetitive design it saps any enjoyment from the game

[h1] BUY THIS GAME [/h1]

This game does everything you'd want a pirate game to do! Your crew has to actually take care of the many functions of the ship, repairing masts, hull, adjusting sails, anchor, helm, bailing water. It also has enough respect for the player to trust you to look at a map yourself, find treasure, etc. and not just slap an obnoxious objective marker on-screen. All that does mean there's a learning curve, but that only improves the satisfaction of each success. You'll celebrate everything from your first fish reeled in, to the most massive pirate ship battle won, and everything in between.

Most importantly the pirate ship battles are everything you'd hope for: Your crew scrambling to steer, repair, attack, defend, lookout, all at once in a hectic battle; even leaping aboard an enemy ship for some satisfying swashbuckling action as the cannon balls fly! What kind of land-lubber scalawag wouldn't jump at that chance. You can even perform a battle sea shanty to strike fear into the hearts of rival crews as you approach.

In this game, it's possible to: [spoiler]load yourself into a cannon, have your crew mate fire you onto an enemy ship from a distance where you distract their crew with direct combat. Meanwhile your crew mates maintain the cannon barrage, harpoon treasure off the enemy ship, and then harpoon you back onto your own ship before they enemy crew can get the upper hand![/spoiler]

Sounds perfect? Not quite. It does require an XBox account, sigh, and the online service can be fairly flaky to get connected; some friends and I have needed to restart/relaunch or even reboot to actually get into the game. But once you can actually get in the game, chef's kiss! The one improvement this game could make, is allowing you to play your musical instrument while seated on the side of the ship, just to add to the intimidation factor.

Happy sailing!

Pros:
Good game. Mesmerizing ocean fluid simulation, wonderful color palette and HDR implementation, large open-world sea to sail, good and fast matchmaking system, long list of quests and interesting riddles to solve, melee combat is good, ship to ship combat is fantastic, and the giant sea monsters and boss fights are super fun!

Cons:
Every time I take a break from this game, then come back and reinstall it, 'Games for Windows' pops up a login inside a partially hidden window and cannot be clicked, so I cant play the game. Their support says "change your windows desktop to default DPI scaling", but my desktop IS AT DEFAULT SCALING for 4k on a 32" screen and this same issue has been happening for over 2 years! The fix is usually to reduce scaling below default, click the damn Games for Windows page, then fix the desktop scaling, but I cant be bothered after this long. Uninstalled. Fix the damn scaling problem!
 
Player base. I have definitely seen WORSE communities, but in this game about 2 out of 5 crews go south. You have children who are too young signing in from consoles, super angry, toxic esports pros shouting at everyone like this is their angry RP fantasy and we are here to run their boats for them, random trolls who just stand in the boat and do nothing, people who try to steer the ship into rocks on purpose, etc. So far most crews have been good, but my very first crew was with some toxic fuq who did not care that I was brand new, and "expected me to know how to sail a ship, its like sailing a real ship." (as if everyone is an effing sailor)

Other than community and the scaling issue, this game is a blast, its fairly easy to get into a crew, & most people will play and have fun with you. Compared to some communities, where almost every group is toxic, SoT aint bad.

"Sea of Thieves" offers players an exhilarating pirate experience set in a vast, beautifully rendered ocean world. Developed by Rare, this multiplayer action-adventure game immerses players in a world filled with treasure hunting, ship battles, and exploration.

Gameplay:
The core gameplay revolves around sailing the open seas with friends or strangers, embarking on quests to find buried treasure, battling other players, and encountering various fantastical creatures. The sailing mechanics are remarkably well-executed, requiring coordination and teamwork to navigate the unpredictable waters effectively.

Graphics and Sound:
The game boasts stunning visuals, with vibrant, colorful environments and dynamic weather effects that make every voyage feel unique. The sound design is equally impressive, from the creaking of wooden ships to the crashing of waves and the stirring musical score that sets the tone for each adventure.

Content and Progression:
While some may find the game lacking in variety early on, frequent updates and expansions have continually introduced new content, including quests, events, and cosmetics, keeping the experience fresh and engaging over time. The progression system allows players to unlock new cosmetics and upgrades for their ships and characters, providing a sense of accomplishment and customization.

Community and Multiplayer:
Sea of Thieves truly shines in its multiplayer experience, encouraging players to form alliances, engage in friendly competition, or engage in epic battles on the high seas. The community is generally welcoming and cooperative, with many players eager to join forces and share in the spoils of their adventures.

Overall:
"Sea of Thieves" offers a unique and unforgettable pirate experience that is best enjoyed with friends. Its stunning visuals, immersive gameplay, and ever-expanding world make it a standout title in the multiplayer genre. While it may not appeal to everyone, those willing to embrace the pirate's life will find endless hours of excitement and camaraderie on the high seas.

Sid Meier's Pirates! was the last great pirate game.

Sea of Thieves, like everything else in the genre, ends up being a disappointment.

It's an "OK" game and the graphics look stunning. 

However - if you are looking for a immersive and exciting game with lots of multiplayer content and progression you will be disappointed. The creators focus mostly on cosmetics, emotes and amazing scenary, which might be funny for a while but leaves a lot to be desired. If you are below 15 or have young kids you want to play together with it might be perfect.

There is no progression and no real pvp-element which makes it worthwhile. The server max population is also too small to make incredible events occur. Mostly you are drifting around alone in a vast sea of loneliness - like a solitary comet between two galaxies - destined to spend an eternity alone.

They should add two servers, one for PVE's and one for PVP's (with vastly different configurations)

In a world of games competing with one another to offer the most user friendly and accessible features and gameplay Rare has decided "NO!".

Got a couple of kids you want to be a pirate with and enjoy a fun family adventure? Called horrific names and spawn camped by other players.
Want to play a LITERAL DISNEY themed story based on a popular Disney film franchise? Called horrific names and spawn camped by other players.
Want to enjoy a relaxing night after work with your spouse fishing in a virtual world that has rewards just for fishing in said virtual world? Called horrific names and spawn camped by other players.

Then, wait... 5 years later... PVE servers? A private server you can do all the above without other players calling you horrific names and spawn camping you?
Lmao, sure. Except this time it's the dev's killing all your fun. Rewards are cut to an abysmal 30%. Half the features are missing, including features DESIGNED for PVE experiences, and then you're told "This game is not for you, go play something else" because I want to enjoy this amazing world you created? I jump onto the forums to see what people are saying and it's 100 different usernames pleading for rare to knock it off and 3 usernames defending the obviously INSANE decision to require PVP in order to play the full game, and not nicely either, actually by... calling you names and trolling your posts.

Toxic community. Toxic ideology that purposely excludes people, and only for the reason that 3 out of every 100 people keep pointing back to Rare's "Original plan for the game" as reason to not make changes to be more inclusive to non-sweatlord gamers. What a joke. Give me full game and I give you wallet. Easy.

10/10 game otherwise. Give the PVP folks a big bonus for being big **** sweaty GaMErZ and let us 30yo chill folks enjoy the full game with our friends and family the way we want. Why limit it? It makes NO SENSE! I'm ready to buy my kids all the dogs and cats and birds and Banjo Kazooie ship cosmetics... but for 30% rewards and 30% features? LOL get real.

Edit: 02/24 - Several Months have gone by and the only things changing are Player count is dropping drastically (67% on steam DB, no access to Xbox numbers) and RARE has disabled comments on all it's Sea of Thieves social platforms, including steam. I don't think i'll ever buy a game from them again.

You'll have more bad experiences than good in this game, the grind for items and rewards is draining and you could lose all progress in a flash if your aren't constantly prepared for the worst.
It's fun with friends but that fun can only get you so far.

EDIT:
After some consideration and... a lot more time playing the game, it's got a steep learning curve in the form of OTHER PLAYERS.
My advice? Don't trust anyone. Not even once. But you must NEVER shoot first.
It's the kind of game that makes you think. 
"Do I want to try to get to grade five as a merchant to get max value on all this loot? OR do I go and sell everything I have at grade three because two Grade Five Reapers Bone's just joined and are coming for you?"

If you want to know what crippling paranoia feels like, play alone.
If you want to know what crippling failure feels like, play a Brig/Galleon with friends.

Final Review:
Fuck this game
It'll force you to play like an asshole or run away from every battle.
I'm sick to death of pretending there's a positive side to this game other that losing everything you had because someone got lucky.
And that's just it, LUCK. Doesn't matter how much skill you have, if someone gets good waves or their ping is better, they'll outgun you or out run you.
Don't play this game unless you like fucking blenders.

A great game,
but this game is way better with friends and sometimes really frustrating when you get sunk by players. Yes there is a non-PVP server, but the progress gets major cuts there. Plus meeting nice crews is definitly a huge highlight.
At the moment I play this to chill after stressful days, so for that I think it is great, however I also think the game might get boring fast for other people, especially when playing alone. Though, you can grind a lot in this game, if you feel like that. 
Another plus is that each player always starts with the same equipment and ships. Progress is just cosmetic and new missionss, so fights are actually always fair and very much skill based.
Finally, there are a lot of small mechanicss and details I like, the fishing minigame as an example. It is not complicated, but feels a lot like actual fishing.
All in all, i love it at the moment and highly recommend it if you have a friend to sail with or a lot of patience. :)

PS: I hope I can find Captain Max and his buddies again some day. You guys were nice <3

[b]Tl;dr:[/b] Sea of Thieves lets you go on a unique adventure each time you play it. Its random nature and well-established game systems make the game offer a delightful experience.

In Sea of Thieves, it is never certain what you will encounter in a play session. The quests set your first intent in the game and can influence the experience you will have throughout a few hours, but it is never exact. The chaotic human factor can result in you being in scenarios you couldn't even imagine. [b]Sea of Thieves is a well-executed unique game considering the possibilities it provides for each player and their play sessions.[/b]

The game's main progression is through various factions. Although each of these factions prioritizes acquiring treasure and delivering it safely, each faction focuses on a few quest types. These quests influence you to search and dig up for treasure, transfer commodities, fight skeletons or even ghost ships, and get rewarded for each of them. [b]Sea of Thieves is a game that rewards you handsomely for the effort you put into the game.[/b]

Apart from the factions, there are world events in the game. These events are always visible to other people on your server as well, so they can become pretty competitive. Random world events consist of ghost ship battles, on-foot boss fights, raids that have special conditions and waves of enemies, and even more. During my team in the game, [b]I liked the competitive aspect of the world events, and they added greatly to my experience.[/b]

When it comes to combat, the game has a great variety of tools too. There are a total of four unique weapons for combat on foot, and then you have the sea combat where things get even more complicated. During fights with other ships, you can utilize a great number of cannonball types for your cannons, and you can even board your enemies' ship to lower their anchor or defeat them onboard. I haven't put many hours into fighting other pirates on the seas, but [b]I can assure you that Sea of Thieves is a game that is easy to get into, but pretty hard to master.[/b]

The best thing about the game is that you sail on the seas with a few more other crews, which adds to the overall experience. You never know what kind of crew you would encounter during your play sessions. This chaotic nature of the game is what makes it so replayable and fun to play. [b]In Sea of Thieves, each play session is unique due to the game's online aspect.[/b]

In short, Sea of Thieves gives you the feeling that you go on an adventure, a true one. Its chaotic nature and simple but varying systems render the game a great deal of fun to play. [b]I would suggest Sea of Thieves to everyone. No matter what your age or game preferences are, I believe you can enjoy this game.[/b]

My first 10 hours were great, i really enjoyed the crew experience with my friends, the voyages, the main missions and the fact that everyone has the same skills, abilities and weapons.....or so i thought.

It turns out that 9/10 players you meet are trolls, griefers and modders that only care about ruining your day. I don't mind the fetch quests on multiple islands but it takes time, so if a bully player finds you in the middle of your quest, you've basically lost an hours play time in an instant.

If I could play with my friends on a closed game with no outside player interference this game is an 8 or 9/10. The way it is, with the worst online community i've ever played with (and I play GTA Online) it's more like a 3/10
