I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he joined a game with me. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Not a meme review so keep scrolling for the low effort stuff. This game is honestly great and I regret not jumping on the bandwagon sooner. I was scared that it would be a miserable time alone. It surprisingly isn't. There's a lot you can do alone. So if you're a loner like me, this isn't one of those games that hard punishes playing alone. There are some PvP stuff you'll struggle with, but if you're a loner you probably aren't down with PvP all that much anyway.

The game honestly looks amazing too. I was surprised at how beautiful the ocean looks. Sometimes I just sail around aimlessly having fun with the sailing mechanic and enjoying the views. Shooting some sharks and kraken every now and then.

The only thing that may be a negative is, a lot of activities are time consuming. This isn't really a game where you play for an hour and feel like you got a lot done. Even with the new diving function. It helps, no doubt. But I didn't feel like even with that, that I got a lot done and made a lot of money.

I also feel that the price tag of $40 is way to high even some really big games have a lower price tag and a lot of them are better then this game. but at the end of the day I'm not the one making the choices for you so buy it if you think you will like but I think it is not the game for me

RUDIMENTARY REVIEW:

Globally across all platforms I have over 3,500 hours logged on this game. It is incalculable exactly how much of an impact this game has had on my life. No, while the story is fun and entertaining, it is neither life changing nor the reason I praise this game so highly. The reason for what makes this game so incredible is the experiences forged while playing. With friends or even by yourself, Sea of Thieves is a completely unique and beautifully immersive experience, complemented and held up by its beautiful ambiance, score, audio design, visuals, unique stylization, and many more contributing factors. SoT succeeds flawlessly at creating the perfect, pirating experience.

Best video game simulated ocean that exists.  This game is amazingly fun.  With the addition of Safer Seas, new players like me are able to learn the basics of game mechanics without the worry of the player versus player aspect of the game interfering.  Admittedly, the benefits eventually outweighed the risk and I ended up playing on the High Seas servers after about 4 days.  Also, the fast travel to voyages feature has now enable me, a casual gamer, to log on and get in a couple of quick voyages to satisfy the need for a shorter gaming session.  I can't speak for previous seasons, but it seems like Season 11 has become the best version of the game since it's launch and I look forward to what they will be adding to the game in the future. Despite its flaws, which i'll mention in a bit, Sea of Thieves is easily one of the best "pirate game" experiences in the market right now. At its core, this game is like a PvPvE sandbox, very rich in content to do on your own or with other players. Although there isn't a specific goal to "beat" the game, there are many tall tales (what you could refer to as "campaigns") with puzzles and fun stories to explore by yourself or with friends. They recently added a "Safer Seas" mode where you essentially get put on a server with no other players who can ruin whatever you're doing (some late game content is unavailable on this mode, and you get reduced rewards.)

As for its problems, the servers simply aren't the best and you may experience a laggy experience when there are many players around. Personally, this has only been a small annoyance and it never made the game unplayable, but that's mainly because I have a decent Internet connection. I will say, however, that Sea of Thieves is not extremely welcoming to new players. The game kind of guides you through the first, basic steps of the game, but there's plenty of important stuff to learn that you are never told in any way. The main complaints, however, come from the PvP aspect of the game. I've seen many players quit Sea of Thieves because some other ship stole their loot they had spent hours on collecting, or something along those lines. This is definitely the roughest part of SoT and part of the learning process, but PvP and interaction between players are very big aspects that really make the game fun once you take time to learn. The only progress you can make is directed towards cosmetics, so you aren't even missing out on anything important other than gold to buy clothing, weapon skins and whatnot. 

Also, this is one of the most gorgeous looking games I have ever played. The soundtrack is awesome.

I'm, as of writing, at 231 hours in the Sea! My friends and I have been sailing safer seas after long days of work. It's a fantastic addition to allow this game to be more accessible to other folks that aren't into PvP. We've had plenty of Tall Tales to work through, and leveling up the 3 main companies. We're likely approaching the end of our time playing, and moving on to other games until more content is released for the Safer Seas, but we've had an absolute blast and it's been MORE than worth what we paid for it. 

If you're reading this, you're still on the fence, you think you'd like this game but are intimidated, get a friend and get this game! It's so much fun.

Ahoy, ye salty rats of the digital seas! If ye be lookin' for a game to shiver yer timbers and plunder virtual booty, look no further than Sea of Thieves! This game be so good, even Davy Jones himself be takin' a break from the locker to play.

Picture this: sailin' the high seas with a crew of misfit pirates, searchin' for treasure, and engagin' in epic naval battles. It's like a virtual vacation for yer inner buccaneer, minus the scurvy and sea shanties on loop. Ye can even make friends with a parrot, and trust me, it be a better companion than any landlubber ye'll find ashore.

But beware, for every horizon be holdin' danger and adventure. Will ye be a legendary pirate, or end up feedin' the fish at the bottom of the ocean? I played solo in the story line -long tales, monkey island. The game does not save. There is no place to save anywhere, so I assumed it auto saved. it does not. It will save your money, it will save your character but it will not save where you are.
Three times I tried in different fashions. Twice, exiting to menu, then quit game and also going directly to home screen, all to no avail. the game will make you start from the beginning every time. This may not be this way in multiplayer but it is definitely this way if you want to play solo.
This is important to me to save progress. If it means nothing to you, by all means get it, if it means something to you avoid buying it.

I played Sea Of Thieves when the game first came out on Xbox Live and now I got the Steam version so it runs far better. Sea Of Thieves has grown a lot over the years and is such a wonderful pirate experience. You choose how you play, you steal other players loot on the High Seas game mode which is playing on the seas with other players but what I love most when I've played on the High Seas, I have never stolen a thing unless someone comes and tries to sink me and my crew, then I sell that loot. You can also come across the nicest people on the High Seas which is extremely rare. I've noticed players complaining about hackers on the High Seas so I hope that Rare does an Anti-Cheat real soon. I play since the update, I play on the Safer Seas game mode where it's just you and your crew on a PRIVATE sea, or you can do it solo as well, however...there are restrictions which I find quite unfair and unbalanced for the PVE players, this game really only caters for the PVP players, so...if you want to become Pirate Legend, sadly you have to go on the High Seas and play against random players. When you first play, I recommend playing on the Safer Seas to learn the game then consider the High Seas later on. 

Now, where to start gosh, game is so big now and large with content. Every trading company as far as I believe are now all prestige level 100, Gold Hoarders, Order Of Souls, Merchant Alliance, Reapers Bones, Athenas Fortune, Hunters Call, I think it is so correct me if I'm wrong in a comment Rare devs. The game is ENDLESS now, play the game however you want, this game is popular for a reason and I highly recommend it. One of or even the best game I have ever played. You get voyages, tall tales which are like story modes you do, forts to raid, plenty of stuff to do and it does not stop there, Rare constantly keeps updating the game with more content after each Season Pass ends. I could go on and on about the content in this game from someone who has played Sea Of Thieves for years now, I want you to discover what this game has to offer when or if you consider getting this. A solid 10/10 and 5/5 stars. Please though Rare, please consider removing the restrictions in Safer Seas so everyone can have a fun and fair experience in Sea Of Thieves. Think of it this way, more money, the game becomes even more popular and this game will grow to be a solid masterpiece as it already is for the PVP players. Please consider it, over and out.

I picked this game up on release day in 2018 because the game concept seemed incredible. Back then, it got a lot of criticism (and rightly so) about it's repetitiveness and how once you get past the brevity of being a pirate for a couple of hours, there wasn't much else deeper than that.

Fast forward to 6 years later (I feel old) and the game is in a much better state. I've sunk over a 100 hours in the past two seasons alone and I'm not even a skilled player. There is so much more to do, better cosmetics and events that you can essentially fast travel to with the new dive mechanic. The Plunder Pass didn't feel like a massive grind and was well worth the credit rewards. I haven't even tried the Tall Tale solo content yet and with some of my friends being big fans of Monkey Island and Pirates of the Caribbean, it's inevitable that we'll sink a few hours into that soon, too.

The ship ownership and Guilds side, in my opinion, has thrust the game up a level and I can't wait to see how that side evolves in future. It feels great to see that your ship has a name, customisation, and a banner that appears for all players. It's half the fun when you spot new players now, to see who they are, what they're called, and what they're running.

I think £35 still feels quite steep in this climate, it hasn't come down in price at all in six years, though you'll absolutely find it for 50% off on Steam multiple times a year. In an ideal world, making Safer Seas (Private servers) give a little more than 30% reward would help get this game a much bigger and newer audience. I think 50% reward is fair, especially as the High Seas servers are hardly dying out.

Overall would recommend, thought it would be good to come back after a long time to show that the game has improved. Time will tell now whether it holds it's place as the best pirate game now that Ubisoft and others are trying to enter the market!

tl;dr 

Probably one of the most abyssal games integrated into PC I've seen, even compared to games from 2006. This game isn't actually running on steam nor does it have proper PC functionality but instead runs using the Windows Xbox app, which causes it to be a horrible PC experience as it forces you to emulate an Xbox while intentionally removing any sensible PC game settings. 

1. The Entire game is integrated into "Microsoft Game Tab" and "Windows Xbox App", the game does not, in any way have multiplayer functionality through steam or the game itself. You have to use these secondary applications WITH AN ACCOUNT for the game to be playable with other people. The applications themselves are really trashy and unpleasant to use on PC.

2. There are NO audio device settings for this game. I mean it. The game has no ability to select which device is used for input and output; instead it automatically chooses devices that are enabled on your computer. This wouldn't be so bad if the game didn't choose to select devices that are disabled on your computer. Which has made this games audio completely broken since its release if you are using a Bluetooth headset, since it ALWAYS uses a Bluetooth headset-mic simultaneously even if that microphone is disabled on your computer and an external microphone is plugged in. 
It's ability and choice to do so seem to even supersede any computer settings you have. I personally, disabled the games access to all sound devices, disabled and removed the microphone component from my devices and IT STILL CONNECTED TO MY MICROPHONE which lead to loud popping blowing out my headset. 
You cannot disable having a live microphone in-game and in fact you cannot disable voice chat at all, thus their horrible decision to remove all game options for audio devices will always make the game unplayable. 
(it also resets some of the more heavy handed ways of getting it to use the right device each time you restart your computer forcing you to repeat the process every time you want to play the game, just as an added bonus.)

3. Both of the above problems are caused by 1 core issue; this game is not made compatible for PC and it isn't actually integrated into steam or as an independent PC launch; it is an XBOX game running from the XBOX app. It's settings are some horrible amalgamation of the XBOX settings menu and Windows audio menus (is also is using windows 10 audio menus not windows 11 for extra fun, which allows it to circumvent some settings.) 
Issues  from being completely unable to play with other people to having your headphones implode not only exist, but has existed consistently and been reproducible since the games release with no intention of fixing it.

The issues themselves are only half the problem, the real annoyance is the fact it is borderline intentional by the developers and Xbox studios to have the game run this way despite it causing audio issues with any Bluetooth audio device and making the multiplayer user experience horrid. 

This has genuinely not only made me dislike this game but also made me decide to never get involved with a game published by Xbox on PC again.

Disclaimer: This is a review aimed at players who think they can find some casual fun in this game.

No, I cannot recommend this game if you, like me are a casual player. I get that it is called Sea of Thieves and is a game that heavily pushes PvP. That in itself is not an issue and is a feature of the game - The problem arises, now that most of the casual and friendly player base that used to be in the game has left for greener pastures.

I originally played this game when it came out, when it was new and fresh, and everyone was still learning. There were of course people yearning for PvP, it is nothing new, they have always been there. Now, however, they are the only ones left truly playing this game. In practice, this means that now, every time you log in and attempt to get a bit of progress in, running into another ship is an instant death sentence, unless you are incredibly good at the game already.

This game does not and will not respect your time. The only way you can enjoy this game, is if you are okay with hours of hard work disappearing in the blink of an eye, because that will happen to you, especially if you are new to the game and still learning.

I came back because I heard they had finally caved and made a safer seas mode, only to learn that this mode was completely and utterly useless for me. I don't mind that you only get 30% rewards in safer seas, it makes sense that you get much less reward when there is little to no risk - However, gating reputation levels past level 40 and making you unable to use the ships you have purchased in this game mode is what kills it completely for me.

I would have been fine just spending a few hours of my time here and there, slowly chipping away at the reputations with the reduced rewards while sailing on my own ship - But no, I am not allowed to do that, because in order to enjoy this game casually, you are forced to deal with the worst this game has to offer as well.

TL:DR: This game is not for people like me, who likes to play the game for a casual adventure with friends. This is a game for hardcore players, ready and willing to dedicate hours of their lives to become true pirate legends and reap the rewards of dunking on much less experienced players.

Edit: Hey folks. I've read through your comments and I have a few notes. Yes, I did go back and play a little more after this, pretty much only to do some tall-tales with my friends to at least get a little out of my purchase.

I get it, some of you really like this game for what it is, and that's fine. This game is not for me and it's my right not to play it. I wrote this merely to warn other people that this game might not be for them.

"I have been playing this game for over 300 hours on Steam and over 2000 hours on Microsoft. If you are looking for a PVE game, then you can try it out, but the developers are the worst I have ever seen. They don't care about the PVP players and there are various bugs in the game. The developers claim that the game is running smoothly, but it's not. I would advise you to save your money until they fix the issues. I am writing this because I just lost the game as I could not see anything on the other player's ship. I could not interact with anything and their sails were raised fully, but they were still moving at full speed. The sails were chained, but they were still up. I have thought about uninstalling this game many times, but I keep coming back to it only to find that the developers have made the game even worse. It's like Ark, but a pirate game, and the hit registration is terrible. Cheating is also a major issue in the game, worse than GTA 5. You can see cheaters every day in every other fight. If the developers make the game better, I will change my review, but for now, it's pretty bad. Even streamers who play the game for a living agree that the game is bad. It makes no sense that the developers listen to the PVE players when the PVP players are the ones who play the game more. The bugs in the game are numerous, such as not being able to interact with anything, everything on other players' ships being invisible, and sometimes even your ship's sail not going down when you chain it. You can't see water in other players' ships and sometimes there are double gun glitches. Sometimes you buy supplies and don't receive them or the game freezes. This list of bugs can go on for at least 80 more. The developers need to stop adding new stuff and fix the issues they have right now. The current player base can adapt to the changes, but the game is still bad. I wish the best for anyone who spends their money on this game right now because after grinding for 8 hours and collecting loot, a cheater can spawn a keg on your ship, kill you, and take everything. You get nothing but a fresh start at the outpost. I want to say one more time, do not buy this game right now as it's a waste of money. It's not a skill issue because I have over 400 hours in both AHG and RHG. The game is just very bad. Please fix the game, developers, or you will lose a great game because you are too lazy to fix the issues."

I'd like to start off by saying I'm biased towards anything and everything pirates. It's my thing. Sea Of Thieves is a pretty fun and lighthearted pirate game. The PvE is enjoyable. The grind for certain factions can feel like a bit of a dirge, but that's just a part of these games. It can be frustrating to go questing for hours on end only for a group of sweaty freaks to come out of nowhere and sink you to the bottom of the ocean faster than you can blink. It's quite disheartening to be completely honest. It does add to the risk reward of the game though. Everything is so much more exciting that way. I would recommend getting friends to play this with. Even just one makes a huge difference.

So I know I've said I don't recommend this game. That's kind of a lie. I love this game for what it can be at times. I have played for a little over 350 hours. Which is nothing if you want to be good at the game.  I think this game is awesome at times and is amazing to play with friends, but I can't bring myself to recommend this game.

Rare does not listen to it's community and the game can be very janky. Hackers have become more frequent by the week, and there no third party software detection. As I continue to play it I lose more and more of what used to make it fun. 

I recommend this game to people who want to be a pirate for 100-200 hours. It is a great game and very pretty. 

However it is a game that is continuing to go in the wrong direction and keeps getting increasingly frustrating to play as rare's servers are pretty bad, rare does not listen to it's community, and rare continues to ignore the hacking problem and pretend it is not as big of a deal as it is. 

To exemplify how bad the hacking is this is a triple A game, the only Triple A game I know about (besides GTA) that has speed hacks, teleportation hacks, aim bot, the ability to spawn items, flying ships, basically all the hacking under the sun. 
Rare seems to have no intention of fixing this soon. Basically fun game, nice to play with friends, but has a company backing it that seems to really not care.

I can simplify the game for you. Do you have 3 or more people you can always bring with you? If yes game is balanced for you specifically, vs. players and PVE. If not? You will get run over. Benefits to having a small boat? None. Can you go faster than the big boats? No. Do you have any type of strategic advantage you can use with sheer skill to fight an equally skilled crew of more than your 1 or 2 members? No. You will be out-guned, and sunk in a matter in minutes. Or chased until you run out of wood, because the small boats are almost twice as slow as the others. I just wonder why they even put the small boats in at all? Just throwing this in here so you don't waste an entire night accomplishing nothing because of the devs choice to make it a one sided game.

Words cannot explain how amazing of a game this is. As someone who owns the game on all consoles I have, and has combined around 3000 hours in the game, this game is a masterpiece of the sea exploration genre. It is a great introduction to the genre as well, as its mechanics are easy to grasp, as compared to some other amazing games in the genre such as Pirates. Each character has personality and very different past bosses. The unlockable characters have an obvious skill cap and much higher risk/reward. Granted, when you play the game as much as I did, it slowly loses something, but as with all of these pirate-like sea explo games, they only keep the repeatability for so long. There comes a point when you know every item, every combo, every boss pattern and every enemy. If you enjoy this, and more important, enjoy extraordinarily difficult sea exploration try Nuclear Throne, TBOI, and a few others. I feel like this game is a very good bridge for these types of games that are so great for speedrunners like myself, and casual players alike.

I come to this as a relatively newer player - I played briefly on Xbox Game Pass before obtaining a copy on Steam.

I am increasingly lost in large scale live service games like Sea of Thieves. I think the mechanics and how to properly interact with the game world or catch up on the many lost seasons of story development hamper my ability to enjoy games like this (or others like Destiny),

During our play throughs, my friends and I struggled for a while to find something outside the normal process of go pick up a quest, go to an island filled with Skeletons, bring back whatever loot we found there, drag it back to a port, sell it to a vendor, and then repeat. That got boring quickly. If we had researched more, we may have come across Tall Tales sooner. However, after completing 3 of these tall tales, we were still disenchanted. 

These tales often meant going to an area, swimming around a lot, taking in some scenery, fighting the same groups of enemies in arenas over and over, then returning to a port to try and do the same again. Each one of these last hours and the reward felt... empty.

The final straw was our last play-through. After completing a tall tale where we were rewarded with one chest that flooded our ship if it was not bailed out, we were set upon by NPC pirates and a Megladon at the same time. Our ship inevitably sank, but I managed to drag the chest to nearby island. After waiting 25 minutes for my friends to sail to collect me, we were attacked by another group of players - our loot stolen after being killed. 30 minutes after that, we had sailed back and collected our loot, before dragging it to a port.

That felt on one hand, vindicating. On the other, hollow. We spent hours to obtain that chest, for a miserable set of circumstances to be set upon us, which meant we lost an hour just to complete what should be a simpler objective.

Yes, it is a game about piracy, and there are settings to prevent PVP. But I think back to that quote by Gabe Newell that a fun isn't about realism, its about reinforcement. And in my time playing this game, I did not feel like an amazing pirate, or sharpshooter or whatever. I felt like I was faffing in a game that is un-intuitive, made by those who focused on making it being more pirate-y or having realistic sailing mechanics than making it fun to play with friends.

By far one of the most amazing n best games I've experienced and played, even to this day.

Sadly, as a solo player... it does get boring rather quick. This game is incredibly nice and fun with the friends though for sure. Something I do honestly miss.

But overall, by far best ocean mechanics in any game. Amazing customization ships and cosmetics for both ship and your character, as well as weapons. LOT of stuff to do and achieve, unlock, work towards, etc... And this game only keeps improving. I personally like the devs as well, by far the best and one's who ACTUALLY listen to their community and why this game is succeeding to this day. It is NOT pay to win like most games and for an UE4, this game surpasses even the most UE5 ones in my opinion.

Of course I am truly not a fan of the massive reward nerf for safer seas and pve based players. Though in my recent times playing, I have hardly experienced any pvp players and tend to be left alone. But that's just me... even then, not everyone is entirely toxic in my experience.

Sea of A-holes.

The developers do nothing to discourage game abuse, they don't actively encourage it, but they don't employ any game mechanics to discourage it. That and only until recently certain ship types finally blocked bullets, when they didn't before, further there was no server-side hit registration at all, it was all client side guess work, who play tested that and thought it was ok?

They're slowly realising that this is potentially killing their player-base after 2 years of game release, that and the £35 price tag.

The game's now available on the XBox Game Pass, which if you can trial it for £1 is totally worth it to see if the game's for you. However, this is also why Rare have introduced a 'plunder pass', like other games which have 'passes' such as Rocket League, Dead by Daylight and Destiny 2, it's mostly for cosmetic items only that don't affect the game in any meaningful way. Which is perfectly fine.

For £35 if you're a single player, the game isn't quite worth it. As a single player you can join other crews at random, but your experience with this will be a mixed bag. You'll encounter young children who simply want to troll, joke around and not make a decent 'crew'. They'll run around, disconnect, and simply play music.

However you'll find a few who'll help introduce you to the game and take you on quests.

The game isn't forgiving to a new player, there's no real introduction to how to play the game aside from the 'maiden voyage' which you can start, that tells you how to setup and sail your ship - spend some time here and look around the island for a bit more of an introduction, but it still does a poor job at telling you about the factions in the game (Reapers, Gold Hoarders, Order of Souls, Bilge Rats, Merchants and Hunters and of course, Athena).

This has recently improved with 'safer seas', basically you and up to 3 of your friends can sail a Sloop, Brig or Galleon without any other players. Which is total bliss, you can enjoy missions, tall tales and sail the seas - except that Rare have decided that you're not allowed to earn the entire worth of your gold, only 30% worth, and you're not allowed to level up the emissary ranks past 40, and you're not allowed to unlock the Athena missions. It's understandable that you cannot unlock Reaper of Souls since that is the "PvP" faction. Those who are against PvE will say it's a very "cut down" experience, but frankly it's closer to how the game was at release and has good core gameplay.

There's PvP in the game, and even though Reapers are the 'PvP' faction that're made to make everyone else's life worse, people use this as an excuse to be an ass. There's no honour among thieves, and there's none among Pirates - that I am fine with. However Reapers are meant to go after other 'emissary' (read: faction) flag flying ships for their points, but instead players simply slaughter and spawn camp, mercilessly. Abusing weapon switching to skip animations and sinking you for the sake of it, not even taking your loot.

PvP can be exciting, and enjoyable and stressful, in the right ways, a typical tactic is another player ship will shoot a player of their crew over to you, pretending to be friendly... while he sabotages your ship and then you're full of cannon balls. An inexperienced captain would rack up to an outpost with anchor down, only to find themselves stuck and full of holes by another Pirate coming along to take their loot.

The PvP can be as balanced and enjoyable as the PvE content in this game, but if you're going into this game with the expectation that you're often going to live out your unimpeded pirate fantasy, expect to be disappointed, regularly.

It's not all too often you end up making backstabby piratey friend chums in an alliance or that you enjoy going on missions to have a bit of a tete a tete, you'll be pushed up against with the old "git gud" and "just scuttle your ship" but none of this is satisfying when you've been abused and forced to submit your hard worked loot by simply... drowning your ship, which would've happened anyway to those who're manipulating and abusing the game.

The tall tales almost save this game, the old pirate shanties and joining other crews on the deck as you purposefully burn your own ship at the end of a long voyage. The 'pirates life' update with the Disney content is really nice, for the Disney portions, and if you've been on the ride you'll love the little tip-offs, and there's a small part for if you're a Secret of Monkey Island fan.

It can be highly satisfying when you've had a rough day of fighting skeleton ships, raiding a vault, and then running away from or fighting other players on the server instance and trying to avoid the Reaper ship, and then being sunk by them and building it up again. It's part of the experience, it's part of the tale, it's finally allying with another crew and getting 50% of their bounty, or choosing to betray them and getting 150%.

They need to balance out the abuse and encourage the good work while putting in active discouragement for the abuse, instead of letting it play out.

Youll also never be able to play with friends on other ships,not without luckily instancing on the same servers as them. Any friends you make in game will be fleeting at best, as the only way youll play together again will be on the same ship if you add each other as a friend, theres currently no hope for being able to sail any friendly alliances you made on a server again with the same people.

With how many times I've seen people frustrated with this, I can't recommend it. Not unless it's hit a price point you can justify and you can tolerate the problems, but don't believe all the advertising. You can enjoy playing solely on 'safer seas' though, and you're put on this by default when you start, but the next time you play you'll have to know to choose, the game doesn't explicitly tell you that you start in 'safer seas' though. Rare don't want you on there, they want PvP fodder.

I have a feeling this game is going to go free to play within a few years, with the season pass and other functionality coming in.

The recent season 8 with the PvP versus mode is also pretty awful. After waiting to queue up with others, you'll then be victim not to the person you're fighting against, but the sheer lag of the ship. You'll try to repair with a plank only to discover that it didn't apply, you'll try to interact with your cannons, or the sail, to find you have to hammer the button to interact with it, all the while you're trying to save time and your ship. It will get frustrating as the cannon fire lays into you and you're struggling to fight with actually navigating your own ship, and lose not to your own skill or lack of, but to the game physics and mechanics against you.

The recent season 11 with Safer Seas though is great. Finally you can play the pirate game that you always wanted, almost, it's nearly there if they would simply reward players that want PvE rather than PvP.

Since the Safer Seas Update in 2023 it got much nicer for an PvE Player like me. Get 1-3 Friends and sail on !

If you want to do High Seas be warned there are Toxic PvP players.

Ahoy my mates! lets sit down for a minute and talk about the fantastical sea of thieves!
This game is top of the line, up there with Minecraft and Red Dead Redemtion 2.
The open world is fantastic and inspiring, anything a pirate could think of is here in the sea of thieves.
The ship physics are top tier; manual steering, manual sail adjustment, manual anchor management.
Everything about the customization is perfect, the fact that everything in this game is cosmetic makes the game feel more even and fair, it's all about skill and practice.
Playing this game with friends is a true experience to behold, I recommend this game to anyone who has some patience and is ready for some fun; go looking for long lost treasures, explore the expansive openworld, take down enemy skeleton fortresses, take down fellow players' ships and take their loot for yourself! well ahoy, its time for me to find a new adventure in the Sea of Thieves. See you there!
Holy hot cakes from hell, i think they've done it. The servers are finally not dog water. Game play is fantastic and completely worth it, when everything plays smoothly.

I like this game.  I wish there were single player servers or guild specific servers so I could get more than 4 people together in a game to go do some of the big group stuff without having to deal with server hopping or random assholes. Or just do any of the stuff without random assholes. I enjoy pvp from time to time, but sometimes I just wanna go dig up treasure with friends and mow through skeletons, and it can be incredibly annoying to go from that to dealing with the human equivalent of screeching eels chasing you across the map halfway through a voyage. 

Even dark souls lets you opt out of pvp in multiple ways. 

No safer seas does not count, Its helpful for new players, but doesn't solve the base issue of sometimes I just want to play alone, or with a friend or two, and not engage with randoms.

Sea of Thieves is a thrilling pirate escapade that excels in the journey to Pirate Legend, intense ship battles, and lucrative fortress raids. The progression from a humble sloop to Pirate Legend is rewarding, and battling other ships with cannons provides heart-pounding moments of strategy and teamwork. Fortresses offer a reliable gold source, adding dynamic challenges to the gameplay. Notably, Sea of Thieves strikes a balance by providing affordable customization options, a breath of fresh air in the gaming industry. While occasional repetitiveness and technical issues exist, the game's overall charm and engaging features make it a must-play for those seeking a dashing adventure on the high seas.

the game itself is great, but it's ruined by a rampant cheater problem that the developers refuse to do anything about.

They say "Just report them!", we do that, and they come back on an alt in under 5 minutes.
the developers say "Just report them again!" we do, and they come back on another alt account in under 5 minutes.

 this is Because of multiple things.
1. The moderation team doesn't Hardware or IP ban people, so cheaters literally only need to log out of one account and into another, which takes all of 3-5 minutes.

2. buying the game on steam guarantees you a free infinite supply of alt accounts, as the moderators don't monitor steam IDs linked to xbox gamertags.

Stack that on top of servers that run like complete TRASH 90% of the time (I'm talking averaging 80 ping in your own region's servers, with lag spikes approximately every 5 minutes),
and developers that DON'T CARE to do anything about all the game-breaking glitches, and make false promises every single update.

and you get a pile of shit that drives new players away on a regular basis.

Amazing with a group, fun on your own, sailing around singing and fighting is a magnificent experience and even if things go wrong you're back in the action almost instantly.

I recently set sail into the enchanting world of Sea of Thieves, and I must say, it's an absolute gem in the vast sea of gaming experiences! Rare has truly crafted a masterpiece that stands out for its unique blend of exploration, camaraderie, and heart-pounding naval battles.

From the moment you step foot onto your trusty ship, the freedom to chart your own course is exhilarating. The open-world design encourages exploration, and the attention to detail in the stunning landscapes makes each island feel like a hidden treasure waiting to be discovered. The dynamic weather and day-night cycle add an immersive layer to the game, creating an ever-changing and captivating environment.

One of the standout features of Sea of Thieves is the cooperative gameplay. Whether sailing with a crew of friends or forming alliances with other players on the high seas, the camaraderie is at the heart of the experience. The coordination required to navigate a ship, manage sails, and engage in thrilling ship-to-ship combat creates a sense of teamwork that is both challenging and immensely rewarding.

Awesome game

Sea of Thieves has a compelling game loop - several, actually, given the range of voyage types available. The positive elements of its gameplay design are, unfortunately, overshadowed by the game's lack of respect for its players or their time.

Session progress can be lost at any time, at the whims of other players who choose to engage with the game's PvP mechanics. For those whose time is a limited resource, this simply makes for a bad experience. And while a private (and therefore, strictly PvE) mode exists, other gameplay systems are intentionally handicapped when using it, presumably in an effort to push all players towards open play so that there continue to be targets available for those who are most heavily monetized.

I genuinely wish I could recommend it, but I can't.

TLDR Mandatory PvP game with terrible PvP mechanics and no concept of risk/reward balancing. The game needs PvP to work, but the current mechanics make for terrible gameplay and overly incentivise toxic behaviour. 

There is plenty of PvE content. And they keep adding more of it. And it's fun. But if you spend any decent amount of time doing PvE, you [i]will[/i] have to protect your hoard in PvP. Which is fine, "it's a pirate game" as the barking seals often remind me. But 99% of the time you encounter someone who wants to pick a fight it's some fresh spawn with no loot who will attempt to steal your hard work with no risk to themselves. Your options are: 
1) Run. You can't really get away unless they let you get away, but if you spend half an hour on nothing but helm and sails you might wear out their patience. Or they might literally follow you around the map forever. Not fun in the slightest. 
2) Fight. The ship side of naval combat is actually pretty good, except that chainshot is utterly broken against sloops and I have no friends, but that's just me. The other side of naval combat is crews using overly-forgiving respawn mechanics to kamikaze their players onto your ship (using throwables, dropping your anchor, stealing your supplies, respawn camping, or just swimming across with a gunpowder barrel...). This "boarding" can be done from great distances by firing people out of cannons, at no risk beyond a small wait to respawn. 
And once they're on your ship, pirate-on-pirate combat [i]SUCKS[/i]. It's janky, clumsy, and the hitreg is awful. When I imagine pirates boarding ships and fighting each other, a single fat man with a blunderbuss jumping up and down/side to side to avoid bullets while shouting racial slurs is not the first thing that comes to mind. 

So let's say you avoid the raining toxic pirates and actually win this hypothetical fight. What do you get? Nothing. Nothing at all. There is no reward, other than continued existence and the salty tears of your enemies. Whenever someone attacks you you're risking everything, while they probably risk nothing at all. 

Nowhere is safe. You cannot avoid other players. Even if you seem to make friends and form an alliance to give them free loot (they get an extra 50% of your sell value, for no effort), it takes literal seconds for them to sink your ship and take everything (because 100% is better than 50%). And they will, because people in this game have no concept of honour. "It's a pirate game", after all. And in my playtime I've had what I would consider a successful alliance exactly once. 

And this doesn't even include people who are assholes just for the sake of it. You could be fishing/doing tall tales on a solo sloop with a huge neon sign saying "no loot here" and you will still get attacked 50% of the time you see another player. But "it's a pirate game"- no. Pirates steal for profit. If you do this you're just a terrible person who somehow derives pleasure from other people's pain, and you seriously need to see a psychologist. Edit - after Safer Seas the example doesn't work so well, but my point still stands. 

There is no downside to being a toxic asshole, in fact it is usually beneficial. So instead of tense alliances where crews work together for a short time towards a shared goal and then either part ways or bring out the guns, it's always better to just shoot first and ask questions never. There is never a reason for teamwork, because everything is possible solo if you throw enough respawns at it. The only reason to have a ceasefire is to get in a better position to start shooting. 

So what needs to change? 
1) Rewards for killing antagonistic pirates. If I spend time defending my loot I should get something out of it, otherwise every sail I see on the horizon is just another waste of my time. There needs to be some kind of bounty system where if someone else shoots first and I successfully defeat them, I get paid. It makes absolutely no sense that I have to continually risk my hours of work levelling emissary against people who just spawned, and they're the only ones who can get anything out of the encounter. 

2) IMO there needs to be a better Parley/ceasefire system than the current alliances. It shouldn't [i]stop[/i] people from shooting each other, but in a kind of Pirate Code way severely disincentivise it. Maybe tie it into the bounty system from point 1 where if you break Parley other pirates get rewards for killing you. That way you end up with a risk/reward situation where betrayal is still possible, but you have to decide if the cost is worth it. 

3) Never going to happen because too many people would cry about it, but pirate combat needs an overhaul. More punishing respawns to stop the endless suicide missions, especially for larger crews. Less one-shot-one-kill so that shooting first isn't the [i]only[/i] viable option when you see another player (looking at you, blunderbuss). When a ship is sunk there should be an immediate server migration, otherwise you get angry players hunting you from beyond the grave and you just have to keep killing them over and over for no reward, until they finally get lucky and kill you. 

4) There needs to be a reason for ships to work together, whether willingly or with a finger on the trigger the whole time. Alliances are vestigial because there is never a need for them, and 100% > 50%. The game needs PvE content that's actually hard enough that you may need more than one ship. (And no, "you need 5 people to summon the megalodon" doesn't count. Look up “artificial difficulty” if you have trouble understanding why)

[strike]5) There needs to be a way to play the overly-grindy Tall Tales with no PvP at all (and possibly throw some Hunters Call stuff in as well). Earning gold would be disabled. I hate that spotting another player often adds half an hour or more to the repetitive "storyline". Especially when the achievements make you play through it [i]FIVE TIMES[/i] for some reason. Alternatively, make them worth my while with actual rewards that might be worth fighting for.[/strike]  - Edited after Safer Seas update. I probably would have preferred other PvM stuff be disabled to keep PvP player counts up, but it's definitely better than nothing. 

I want [i]good[/i] PvP, not this janky torrent of expendable pirates. I want tense, briefly-lived alliances where nobody trusts each other but still has to work together, not meaningless loot increases. I want to win fights by knowing I out-fought my opponent, not because my crew was more expendable or because I got the first shot off and things went downhill from there. 

The game supposedly thrives on tension, but it also completely removes any reason to ever trust other players. All trust does is open you up for betrayal. In turn, the only meaningful interaction with other players is as obstacles. The best way to survive is to run or to murder on sight. Instead of the ocean of player interaction that [i]should[/i] be possible, the only tension is that of wondering whether I'll have to run off the map to finally make my pursuers give up, which by comparison is just plain boring.

I am a 45 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. My son recently started playing Sea Of Thieves and in less than a week, he had already played for over 100 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just busy on internet. So I decided to open the old Steam account my son don't use anymore now and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. My son hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had left us. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, EVEN IN BEING DRUNK PIRATES AND DOING QUESTS OR ROBBING OTHER SHIPS and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories. I will play this game more with my son!

There's a lot of young kids playing this game. So don't expect any mercy if you're new. There is a couple things I think they should change. When there is loot in the water, I think you should be able to just drive the boat right over the loot and it's automatically on board the ship. Sitting there for 5 minutes trying to harpoon or jump in and bring every little thing on board is time consuming and annoying. If you sink 3 ships in an area then have a player jump you, by the time you get done battling the loot is long gone from trying to avoid the player. There are cheats for this game, ESP, Aimbot, and an aim indicator for cannons that show where to shoot to guarantee a hit. Pretty lame. The game is mostly just sailing around and collecting treasure chests and skulls, then bringing them back to a port to sell them for gold. Other than that, it's pvp. If you are on at a populated time, there is a ton of people just looking to sink you without remorse. If you want to farm, play later at night. I really wish they had a ship boost though, like every 2 minutes 10-15 seconds of increased speed. It can take 10-15 minutes to sale to a location and it just gets tiring. I've met some cool people, had some good battles and adventures. Really liked the underwater cave missions. Pretty good graphics for a cartoon looking game. Make sure if you get this, that you get some friends that know how to play and will guide you. It really helps. Better to have a crew who knows what they're doing than randos who either just sit there catatonic when a battle breaks out, or who panic and don't focus on what needs to be done. Good Luck!

As of right now I cannot think of a single game online ( that isn't MMO-based ) that rewards player expression, choice and freedom like Sea Of Thieves does. There are mountains of things to learn, see and do-- Between my Game Pass hours and Steam hours, I'm about just shy of 200 hours in this game and am just now making decent headway into cosmetic grinds and commendations.

This of course can be a daunting ask of any player that chooses to be " casual ", and the debate of this game's validity towards " casual " and " hardcore " players alike has been pretty harshly discussed. As of season 11, though, I feel very confident in Rare's ability to create meaningful progression for new and veteran players alike. 

That said, it's a pirate game. You are a pirate, and others are pirates. What you and others choose to do with that fact is not only the core principal of the game, but what makes it distinct. If you don't like that air of uncertainty, then the game legit is just not for you. I would suggest Safer Seas, but even I'll admit it's a misstep on Rare's attempt at a newcomer-friendly playstyle.

And for the r/gaming crowd, yes, it has microtransactions. However, Ancient Coins ( the premium currency ) come in the free battle pass, and I've been able to purchase multiple passes and other cosmetics without ever dropping a dime on this game.

First of all, everyone who is whining about other players didn't quite understand the game.
PVP is an important aspect in a pirate game, and it's just part of the gameplay.

[u]pro's:[/u]

- successful, lively graphics
- it's a lot of fun with friends
- different game modes
- many possibilities
- many quests and missions
- approx. 25-30 hours of story (Tall Tales)
- only skins can be purchased with real money and no in-game advantages
- mostly lots of good stuff in free Battlepass (skins/real-money currency)
- long-term motivation through many achievements and awards

[u]con´s:[/u]

- 90% of the players run 3 times around the whole map with their gold collector 2 flags in order not to sink with their two chests
- the content is missing for a long time
- terrible hit registration in PVP
- the tutorial (maiden voyage) only deals with a few points, things like factions etc. are completely left out
- servers shit at every major event, Rare doesn't really care either
- please nerf the sword, needs little or no skill and it's just completely broken in terms of range and stun

The central element of being on a boat with friends is fun, but everything around it is paper thin. I appreciate the game for creating a good sailing mechanic, it takes real coordination with your crew to maintain both maneuverability and firepower when fighting other players. 

However, any NPC encounters are a slog, especially the redundant skeleton massacres on those fort islands. Everything on the safe islands is boring, mostly amounting to ferrying boxes from your boat to merchants for ten minutes. Makes one feel like an amazon delivery driver, not a pirate. The only way to have fun in the game is with a crew of friends, not worth a try if you are going at it alone. Keep the boat mechanics, and change the content around it, and a great game could be made! (By someone else)

[UPDATED] After getting my head around the game's logic, I have happily decided to change my review from negative to positive. Here is why:
PLUSES:
1) The sound design is of the Bafta-award level 
2) Graphics are quite perfect and timeless, will stay relevant for many years
3) One of the main protagonists is the Seas, and the interaction with it is most amazing - just sailing through the seas is pure pleasure
4) SOT was recently updated to be much friendlier to players, and the devs do already have roadmap for the upcoming 5 years
MINUSES:
1) It's not friendly to starting players - the menu is convoluted - after the initial tutorial it's not easy to understand what to do because 90% of functionality is locked (tip: you have to find the 2nd interactive tutorial)
2) It's a co-op game by design. You can play solo (like I do) but your performance is limited - for instance, you can steer your ship and operate the cannons at the same time on your own.
3) Your progress will get you mostly cosmetics, and for a non-fashionista like myself it's not motivating
NEUTRAL:
1) Sessions are quite lengthy, and each mission feels like a short pirate story
2) It's a seriously challenging game
3) Even in MP mode it doesn't feel like MP because you hardly meet someone (but when you will meet, you will be out-skilled)

By the time I write this review I have around 3000 hours in this game including xbox. I've done pretty much everything you can do around here and max level'd all the companies.

-Graphics are stunning for the most part, especially the sea. Characters do look goofy but thats not a bad thing.

-Pve is fun at first 100-200 hours or so but gets repetitive after a while.

-Gold system is just stupid. I've bought everything in the game and still have millions of gold and thousands of dubloons just sitting there with nothing to spend them on. They need to balance it more. either add more stuff to buy, make it more expensive or decrease the loot you gain.

-To basically summarize the pve, there are 7 emmissary companies in this game. They will give you quests and bonuses on the items you sell if you're sailing with their emmisary flag.

EMMISARIES

Gold Hoarders.
They give you treasure hunt quests where you gotta dig up stuff from random islands. That's all they used to do until they introduced the vaults in a recent update. Vaults are a lot more fun. You gotta put together the map for a key then go to a specific island where the key will unlock a cave. You will see a lot of gold and chests laying around in there but those are just a distraction. Your main goal will be to get the Chest of Tributes by collecting madallions and entering the correct sequence to open sesame as it were.
They only give you bonus for treasure chests and small collectibles like chalices and ornate cups and whatnot.

Merchants.
Most boring emmisary of all. Just delivering cargos from one place to another. They give you bonus for selling cargo items like sugar, tea etc.

Order of Souls.
Basically a skeleton killing faction. They give you bounties to kill some skeleton captains and they will give you a bonus for selling them their skull. There's also ghost fleets which are much more fun and giving bigger rewards.
They only give you bonus for selling skulls.

Reapers.
The ''pvp'' faction of adventure mode. I just call them garbage collectors of this game because they will give you bonus for literally everything. Anything you got you thought was worthless, they will buy it. They buy everything. They dont give you any quests. There are a couple items that you can only sell to them. Reapers Chest and Reapers Bounty but beware these chests are cursed and their positions are revealed on the map. So other players may see you. If you're flying reaper emissary flag they will see you. BUT, if you reach level 5 emmisary you will be able to see other emmisaries on the map to hunt them down. You get really good money for selling broken emmisary flags of those people you sank.

The reason I said ''pvp'' faction is because a lot of reaper players are known to just run soon as they see you. Yes. It's supposed mean ''hey guys, you can see us on the map, we're up for some pvp, come get us'' but they raise it to get more money from the items they sell and just keep doing pve.

Don't raise reaper if you're gonna run from the first ship you see. If you get sunk, they will be toxic to you naturally and you will deserve it because you made them waste an hour chasing you down.

Hunters.
Fishermen. You can fish in this game and sell your fish to these guys at any seapost. Best way to level up on hunters is to save your gems to sell it to them only(you can sell gems to everyone pretty much). It's a lot more xp and gold than fishin.

Athena.
The emmisary you unlock by reaching pirate legend. Pretty boring voyages and overrated rewards. I was disappointed. It was supposed to be some big endgame company where it'd be fun stuff but its meh.


WORLD EVENTS

These are where you enjoy some of the best of pve this game can offer. Rewards are pretty huge compared to regular emmisary voyages.


Ashen Winds.
Boss on an island. Decent rewards, you also get a unique cool flamethrower skull that you can sell for 10k. Not bad.

Skeleton Fleet.
Probably the most challanging pve i'd say. Especially if you're in a small ship. But the loot haul is pretty big. Fastest way to level up your emmisary flag because of the high quantity of items you'll get.

Active Forts.
Skeleton waves and then a boss. You get decent loot.

Fort of the Damned.
Biggest loot haul you can get from this game. But beware, people will try to steal it from you. This is the number 1 event every server hopper can dream of. It's the main attraction for pvp. Really the most fun thing to do/steal in adventure mode.

-------------------------

PVP.

Now for the best part of this game, PVP. It gives you a pleasure that other pvp games can't. It's just a really unique experience battling it out as pirates. I don't even do any pve anymore it's all about pvp.

I'll see if I can summarize the key parts of it, but oh boy it's beautifully complicated.

-There's the naval part where you have to out-manuever your enemy. You have to stay out of their broadside while try to get them in your broadside while they're doing the same thing. It's not just a spinning battle where both ships constantly fire at eachother like in the Caribbean movies. There's unique moves you can pull off with harpoon turning, anchor turning, adjusting sails to surprise your enemy. Having a good captain will make all the difference between winning or losing a battle.

-Cannons. Different types of cannonballs for different purposes, regular cannons to put some holes in, cursed balls with million different (and very useful) purposes, firebombs to put their ship ablaze, blunderbombs to damage players knock them back from repairing. and in my opinion the best type is the chainshots to knock their mast down. Because soon as you're unable to move, you're done. You will just be sitting ducks for the volley of cannonfire soon to follow. Having a good gunner who hits their shots in good sequence will make all the difference between winning and losing the battle.

-Repairing. Every crew needs a good bilge rat who makes sure that the ship is in top shape. You can't just ignore the holes in your ship to do anything else like boarding or shooting. Not sinking yourself is the priority. Worry about sinking your enemy later. A good bilge rat in your crew will make all the difference between winning and losing the battle.

-Boarding. Without a doubt the most fun thing to do in this game. Boarding other people and killing them. 1 boarder who can put the enemy's anchor down and keep them busy just for a little while is usually good enough to win a battle. You dont even have to really kill them usually. Because as they are busy with the boarder, the other crew member will continue putting the pressure with cannonfire and putting more holes. They won't be able to really focus on repair while they have an active boarder.

On the other hand, as fun as it is, too much boarding can be the downfall of a bad crew. Disorganized, if you send too many boarders and they either miss the target or die without doing significant damage, you will be severely undermanned in your own ship to survive the enemy's cannonfire or boarders. I've seen people just all abandoning their ship with holes in it to board ours, we just kill them and theres nobody left to repair them. Come on people. Take care of your ship. Your ship must come first.

There's so much more to it than I can fit in this review. Really a rich game with a vast world. It's well worth buying at full price. A must buy if you're really into pirate's life. One thing I must say though, you gotta play it with friends. x10 more fun. Solo sailing can be painful and usually gets boring really fast.

Gather round! Sit down.. and have a swig of rum as this ol' dog of a pirate paints ye a tale of the great blue beyond! With over 1,000 hours sailing the high seas, this captain has a few things to tell ye poor landlubbers about yer inquiry into whether ye have the grit and gumption to become a pirate lord and legend.. or just an unheard of washed up turd, upon the banks of Chicken Isle.

One thing ye must learn and ye must learn quickly my young pirate protege.. is that ye must never hold on to yer treasure too tightly. Now.. don't get me wrong, ye want to defend yer booty with every ounce of courage and battle brave bravado ye can muster.. lest yer booty be plundered by some drooling dollard licking their lips as they parade their piratey hands upon it! But be forewarned.. Many a cowardly cohort with tail tucked between legs has gone awash in the glow of galleon fire and become cannon fodder not only on the sea, but in the ocean of their mind!

Ye must understand that to win a battle is something that is hard won with time, practice and patience. Ye don't go becoming a pirate legend in a day lad! And sometimes the battle of the mind is the fiercest one with what ye must contend! The sea rewards those who spend time with her, learning her ways.. just like the ways of yer vessel.. not to mention the ways of combat and cunning, of which you'll need both! But sometimes winning is realizing when you've lost.. and to carry on.. head held high, knowing next time.. you'll get those greedy and grimey gobshite grabbers that took yer loot with a fierce and fiery vengeance and nothing to lose!

The only advantage an old pirate has in this world besides some fancy threads or livery is understanding. With time comes knowledge, and with knowledge.. understanding.. understanding when to make friend and when to make holes! Ye may wonder when trying to make friends as a young captain, why so many seem to run away in sheer terror at yer seemingly friendly advances.. Well all I can say is that you'll learn young sailor. My advice is to meet adversity head on and with a calm and keen head on yer shoulders, to meet those that would be hailed as advocates with an open heart.. but a watchful eye! After all.. this is the Sea of Thieves, not Sea of Friends!

And last of all, the adventures that await ye both in terms of what the sea and islands have to offer, as well as the encounters ye may or may not have seeing other pirate players on any given voyage.. will shape the game in unknown and unexpected ways almost every time. Ye must be ready for anything! or.. not much at all.

One final noteworthy mention.. it's much better to sail with a crew, even if that crew must be chosen over time from yer maiden voyages.. sailing with random slobbering rum drinking drivel until ye find a trustworthy first mate and quartermaster. Sailing the seas alone is a nasty business, although some lone and desperate souls may prefer it. Regardless, I wish ye all fair winds and following seas my hopeful pirate pals!

Fun to play with friends.  It is different from many games in the fact there is no skill tree or individual progression to make your character stronger.  The gameplay is really just about adventure, exploration, and camaraderie.  The PVP combat is balanced by the fact that everyone has the same weapons, health, etc.  All ships are equal between players.  There are interesting riddle type quests to solve as you hunt for buried or sunken pirate treasure.  Reminds me of a mashup between the Goonies and Zelda:Windwaker.  Sea effects and sky graphics can be really impressive on max quality.

Embarking on a daring fishing expedition in Sea of Thieves is always an unpredictable adventure, but none have tested my perseverance and skill quite like the elusive fish that became the centerpiece of my latest maritime conquest. This piscatorial challenge, which seemed almost impossible at first, turned into a thrilling journey that left me both frustrated and exhilarated.

The quest for this mysterious fish began like any other – casting my line into the vast, shimmering sea and patiently waiting for a bite. Little did I know that I was about to face a piscine adversary that would push me to the limits of my angling prowess.

Hours turned into days as I navigated the treacherous waters, chasing rumors and tales of the mythical fish that had eluded many seasoned pirates before me. The excitement and frustration mounted with every missed catch, each fleeting glimpse of a shimmering tail leaving me more determined to succeed.

The turning point came when I stumbled upon a secret fishing spot, hidden in the uncharted corners of the Sea of Thieves. The atmosphere changed, the air charged with anticipation as I cast my line into the depths. The reel whirred as the line tugged violently – I was locked in a fierce battle with the legendary fish.

The struggle was intense, as the elusive creature danced beneath the waves, testing the strength of my rod and the endurance of my patience. It was a game of skill and strategy, a dance between hunter and hunted that played out against the backdrop of the vast, open sea.

As the battle raged on, I could feel the adrenaline pumping through my veins. The sea spray, the creaking of my ship, and the distant calls of seagulls all faded into the background as my focus narrowed on the challenge at hand. Time seemed to stretch as I fought with unwavering determination.

Finally, after what felt like an eternity, the legendary fish emerged from the depths. It was a sight to behold – a magnificent, otherworldly creature that glistened in the sunlight. My heart raced as I carefully reeled it in, savoring the sweet taste of victory.

Conquering this seemingly impossible fish in Sea of Thieves was a defining moment in my pirate's journey. The thrill of the chase, the heart-stopping battles, and the ultimate triumph made it an experience worth every ounce of effort. The elusive fish may have been a formidable foe, but the satisfaction of adding its glorious trophy to my collection was unparalleled. In the world of Sea of Thieves, where the seas are teeming with challenges and hidden treasures, this elusive fish stands as a symbol of perseverance and the sweet taste of victory for those bold enough to seek it out.

This game has a rather unique concept where a new player has the exact same equipment as a veteran player - in other words, there is no progression in that regard. This game does not hold your hand, but gives you all the tools necessary to navigate the world and its dangers. I enjoy the balance of the game, and the updates so far are leading it into an even more interesting direction. I also enjoy just how "alive" this game feels on High Seas, and only your own survival instinct and perception of (ships, rowboats, and mermaids) going on around you can keep you safe.

I know it's called Sea of Thieves and you're supposed to be "pirating" everything, but the community and player base for a casual player is so toxic and you can't do anything or even learn the game without being sunk. Trying to do the tall tales that they put in there is almost impossible due to the amount of people who just don't care and continue to troll you. 

For the casual player its not a good game. But if you have a constant group of friends it might be alright. Don't expect to make any money if you can't get around the PVP aspect. Don't expect to do any of the story without constantly being harassed. 

The gameplay itself is amazing. The graphics are very good and what content I could play is awesome. (The pirates chapter 1 and the maiden voyage are PVE only). I will continue to try  but no I can't recommend this game to anyone anymore until they put in PvE servers or they implement some way to stop people from constantly sinking you (like a PvE shield).

(Edit) With recent additions they have added a PVE or solo server and you can now do the tales easier. They have made the game more enjoyable for everyone.

I am not the first person to say this in a review, nor will I be the last, but I truly wish steam would add a "maybe" option on recommendations. Sea of Thieves is an anomaly in our hobby. The developers clearly care immensely about this game, the art style is fantastic, battle pass system is well implemented. Not everything is perfect, of course. Hit registration can be wonky as hell, and about 50% of the game is sailing across open seas to actually get to the treasure. However, overall, the amount of pride and hard work that has been put into this game shine through. If you don't like dealing with people, you can even play on private servers now. As with most always online games, the experience is going to vary based on who you encounter. As I said already though, the game is good and keeps getting better every update.

All in all, give it a try. It's fun, mostly chill, and incredibly well cared for, which is a lot more than can be said about a lot of games nowadays.

Sea of Thieves is a true gem in the world of multiplayer gaming, offering an unparalleled experience that seamlessly blends exploration, cooperation, and sheer fun. Rare has truly created a masterpiece that goes beyond being just a game – it's an adventure, a playground, and a canvas for unforgettable moments.

The vast open world is a sight to behold, with its stunning visuals and dynamic weather system that adds a layer of immersion rarely seen in other titles. From the moment you set sail, you'll find yourself entranced by the beauty of the seas, the lush islands, and the thrill of discovering hidden treasures. The attention to detail is simply awe-inspiring.

What sets Sea of Thieves apart is its emphasis on player interaction. Whether you're sailing solo or with a crew of friends, the game fosters a sense of camaraderie and shared excitement. The collaborative nature of ship navigation, treasure hunting, and battling other pirates creates a dynamic and ever-changing environment. I've made lasting memories from epic naval battles to impromptu dance parties on the deck – it's the unpredictability that keeps me coming back for more.

The progression system is well-balanced, allowing players to unlock cosmetics and upgrades without compromising the level playing field. It ensures that even new players can enjoy the full scope of the game without feeling overwhelmed. The regular updates from the developers, introducing new content, events, and challenges, demonstrate Rare's commitment to keeping the Sea of Thieves experience fresh and engaging.

Moreover, the community is one of the friendliest I've encountered in an online game. Whether you're seeking allies for a mighty fleet or looking for rivals in a daring duel, you're bound to find like-minded pirates eager to share the seas with you. The developers have successfully fostered a positive and inclusive environment that encourages cooperation and friendly competition.

In conclusion, Sea of Thieves is a triumph in the world of multiplayer gaming. Its combination of breathtaking visuals, engaging gameplay, and a vibrant community make it a must-play for anyone seeking a unique and unforgettable gaming experience. So, hoist the anchor, set sail, and embark on an adventure that will leave you with stories to tell for years to come!

The game is super fun I’ve been playing since release and you can see how much time and passion the devs have, all new “dlc” in the game is free and treated like a regular update, people say it gets old but most of those reviewers haven’t played recently. They’ve added story based quests known as tall tales and recently have started a second story in the tall tales. There is also exstensive lore.  You can fish or hunt animals, kill krakens, fight skeleton ships, or kill megalodons. You can explore regions such as the shores of plenty a carribean like place, the wilds a more stormy and darker version of the shores of plenty, the ancient isles a old region of the map with exstensive lore and huge islands, the devil’s roar- a fiery tempered place full of volcanoes and earthquakes, and finally if you do the last tall tale you can have access to the lucrative shores of gold the biggest island in the game with huge chunks of lore and a lush environment filled with deadly traps, a skeleton lore known as the GOLD HOARDER a wicked skeleton held together by gold and lust for riches, and as the mighty pirate lore would say A GREAT BIG PILE OF TREASURE! There are also pets in the game but those cost money or if you play the game for a while skeletons might show up that carry this elusive currency known as ancient coins which buy you pets. If pvp is what you want head over to the arena where you and other ships compete for treasure and get into constant battles. They’ve also added a tutorial known as maiden voyage for new players which (if the search hard enough and do some challenges) can give you some gold doubloons(used to buy from the bilge rats) and some ship cosmetics. There are also fun challenges in the game givin by the bilge rats who are wild and carefree like sit in thrones made of bones, shoot skeletons carrying gunpowder, find Easter eggs, and carry chests of rage. So a fun game that has recently had huge leaps in terms of content honestly would suggest everyone pay the devs obviously have a huge passion for this. Thank you for reading this huge rant.

I bought the game and was happy about the PVE mode. Not everyone needs to kill others online to get satisfaction in life.
I was aware that there is only 30% reward, but you can only level up to level 40, then it stops. Most items are not available in the safe sea, and many options are not available. Many misssons are simply blocked. I can accept that PVP players should get some sort of reward and trophy, BUT to exclude PVE so much is not ok, the safer sea mode just feels like a mode they introduced just so they can say "we did something" "wait, you don't want to farm for hours and then get killed?". Too bad for you. 
The mode makes you feel like you're worth less as a player (not as a human), like "You don't have time for the awesome PVP mode we have or you're just not interested in it? Then just play with the leftovers in the dirt" As I said, I can live with fewer rewards BUT as the Safer Sea mode is at the moment (26.01.2024), it is not recommended.Rar probably saw that they weren't getting any new players and were targeting the PVE faction and so they quickly slapped something together without effort and as unsatisfactorily as possible.by the time you realise all this, you probably can't return the game and they have your money.
I wouldn't be surprised if the Mouds disappears again soon because it's "underused".  A rogue who thinks evil. 
Maybe 4 more years have to go by before the mode feels fully-fledged and fun. Now technical things I don't like. The aiming system, why don't the weapons have sights? It's not like it would destroy the game world and atmosphere of the game. Sights have been around as long as firearms themselves. The next point is navigation, why can't I have a map on my deck when I'm at the helm? That you have to set the course at the table is fine, but can't I just have a board with the markings on it?  It should be my choice if that spoils the atmosphere or not, even Skyrim and many other medieval games have that. The next thing that bothers me is the thing with digging up chests on islands. You sometimes search for ages to find the chest, couldn't they just introduce a sound when you get close to it? It gets louder the closer you are and quieter the further away you are. For all those who want to play here in peace and quiet, the game as it is at the moment is unfortunately still nothing.  Very Disapointing
