Sea of Thieves is a very entertaining game, but has some downsides that can make it rather unappealing to some people. I will break it down in a pros & cons list.

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
+ Great with Friends (Total of 4 crew members on the largest ship, including yourself).
+ Plenty to do (Quests, Treasure Maps for that Looty Booty, Fishing, PVE Plundering).
+ PVE is actually rather entertaining and rewarding.
+ Large map. Plenty of islands, outposts & secrets to find and explore.
+ Safer Seas so you could go into a private session to do Tall Tales or get to know the game mechanics.
+ Guilds. Allows 24 players to join & work together to gain additional rewards. Also allows ship sharing.
+ A few different ships for different crew sizes.
+ Variety of tools, weapons & ammo types to utilise.
+ Customisation options for both the ship & player. 
+ Pets (Dogs, Cats, Foxes, Parrots, Monkeys). Plus, if you can afford to spare the ancient coins, outfits for the pets.
+ Sea Shanties. Need I say more?

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
- PVP in all areas. I've been attacked at sea, spawn camped on my own boat, ambushed at an outpost where I was trying to sell my haul of loot & tricked with the "Alliance" System. There is no passive zones, or passive mode upon spawn with a "x" amount of time before you start taking damage again, which is rather annoying.
- Sea of Thieves has a rather crappy community, some people will avoid you or be nice to you, but most will try to kill you just for sport & the slim chance of loot. I've spent 30mins in a session, just fishing & chilling, winding down after a busy day & people have literally killed me for fish. Fish for crying out loud, which can barely get you 1K gold!
- Useless reporting system. Can't report racism, griefing or any type of harassment without a video of it happening. Most reports without that get ignored.
- Less enjoyable by your lonesome. It's not terrible, it's just better with friends.
- Safer Seas (Private Sessions) have a slight waiting time to them & aren't as rewarding as normal sessions. (Gold gains are reduced significantly, no emissaries & level gains are capped).
- Guilds are a thing, but being able to set sail with multiple crewed ships on the same server from one guild, from my knowledge, hasn't been implemented. 
If you have more than 3 friends that you want to play Sea of Thieves with, in the same server, be prepared to do 20Mins+ of Server Hopping.
- Requires a XBOX / Microsoft Account.

[b][u]Conclusion:[/u][/b]
Generally, I do believe this game is pretty awesome, as for 6 months I've come back continuously to sink time into it. But while communities can often make games, in the case of Sea of Thieves, it can also break them. I've played solo & with friends, I've joined random people via the official discord & met some really cool people on the high seas. However, these cool people are far & few between.
Rare makes it more rewarding for people to be douches towards each other & that for me is quite annoying because I often play to chill out, not compete with others for loot that I've already worked hard for.

So all in all, if you're reading this review, I'd say this game is worth buying, but only if you've got friends to play with & whilst it's on a 33% Discount or more.

When 'safer seas' was released, I hoped it would be enjoyable as a solo player, to explore and relax, sailing and discovering. 
Some people do enjoy the game solo, PvP being an aspect that is fun for them. 

However, I am not able to think and move fast enough to survive in PVP - and unfortunately most encounters I've had sailing and exploring are not relaxing. 
Not all modes are playable for me due to other players who think it is enjoyable to destroy your ship and kill you / steal for fun.

If an offline single player mode was available, I would enjoy the game.
I followed this game from launch and waited to see if the developers would provide an option to sail and explore in singleplayer.
As an alternative, an option to be able to host a local private server would also be welcomed.

The progress speed for completing the available 'safer seas' aspects are massively restricted - by a 70% reduction in rewards.
If in the future a true offline singleplayer option is offered, and/or a private/offline/local server becomes available, then I may revisit this game.

Great potential, looks to be fun for those people who 'grief' others, but not enjoyable for me.
Cheers.

Season 11 has wrenched everything that made Sea of Thieves a pirate simulator out of the game and made it into a generic grind-heavy MMO. Nothing is left to chance anymore : the loot is predetermined, the adventures are designed by the player from beginning to end, and your hand will be held through the entire process. 

I've been a great fan of the game for years but this has changed the game on a very fundamental level, and it's altered how it feels to play it so much that I can't see it being fixed by anything short of rolling the update back. You're no longer sailing a wild and open sea anymore, you're just opting in to the loot you want and checking items off a checklist now. 

A week ago I was excited for this update and I would never have believed I'd be saying this now, but if this is the new direction this game is going to take, it might be time for me to hang up my bicorne for good

Played for a good while and was severely let down. I enjoyed the atmosphere, the music, the humor and the aesthetics. However, the game is entirely session based so all the supplies and treasures you gather are gone as soon as you leave the game unless you manage to sell or deliver them. Only purchased cosmetics are really saved for the next session. The game is mostly just sailing from point A to point B then back to point A. Rinse and repeat. The events and quests are repetitive and more generic than following all the random maps and solving riddles on the side. Also add in the fact that you are not allowed to enjoy just sailing and looking for buried treasures because everything is PVP. 

No joke, the first time I played, I couldn't sail from one island to another without being attacked and sunk. People camp and demolish you before you can even get going. Doesn't matter if you have anything on board or that you fly peaceful flags or that you openly announce that you are not interested in fighting. They sink you and you have to try again. I spent almost my entire game time killing other players in self defense or being killed. 

The only time I enjoyed myself was when the server was empty except for one or two other players. It was the one and only time I've experienced a session where all agreed we just wanted to be left alone to sail, hunt treasures and explore the map. I didn't even know there were more NPC enemies or bosses until then since I had never gotten far with all the homicidal campers around. Sadly, the game does not like empty servers. Too few players and you are automatically kicked to a server with more players. Which means back to running, fighting and not really accomplishing anything. The only sure way to make worthwhile progress is to play with several other people and form a large crew. A fact of the game I and many others do not agree with.

I know it will never happen because the developers of this game don't want to make it possible but, this game would be so much better if there were setting options to play offline or host private servers. Until that happens, this game gets a thumbs down and is going in the garbage.

UPDATE

So, now you can avoid the horrid pvp and solo. This is great and I tried it out for several hours. Props to the devs for finally listening to the fan base. However, I'm sorry to say that I will never play this game again. Why? On my first voyage to dig up a single treasure chest a measly one island over from port, I had: a skeleton ship pop up; a megalodon rise from the depths; 2 of those clam faced brutes that spew toxins; 5 normal skeletons; 3 ghosts; 2 regular sharks; 1 of those electric eel zombie pirate things; 3 red named skeleton captains; and there were cobras scattered all over the island. 

What. The. F#@%! 

I couldn't get the freaking treasure chest back to my ship without running a nightmare gauntlet and everything kept re-spawning! And, as if that weren't enough, a huge, 3 mast skeleton ship comes sailing around the corner to say, "Waz up!" just as I raise anchor to get the hell outta dodge! 

Great, we can solo to learn the mechanics and explore the actual game but seriously. There's really no limit on what type, how many or what level enemies are that can spawn around you? Even when you're only on your first quest after the tutorials? Also, it's not a matter of skill or anything. I survived and completed the quest so it's not as if I couldn't do it. The thing is, the entire experience was [u]not fun.[/u] Sorry, I love the idea of soloing a pirate game but this is ridiculous and not worth it. Back in the garbage you go Sea of Thieves and good riddance.

As others have said, this game really doesn’t respect your time. Either you play on the High Seas and get PVP’d to death after spending hours trying to make a little money (and many times, getting killed with no treasure on you at all - just griefers) or you play the Safer Seas and your rewards are nerfed to hell. Either way, your time isn’t respected.

I’m not a bad player, I played back on Xbox when this game was for insiders only years ago. But I’m not an expert either. Sometimes you just want to log in and play for a few hours here and there with people, casually. Well, this game isn’t for that in my opinion.

An example - last night I was playing with 2 people. We got the Key of Siren Song, then went and got the treasure chest for it. Then got killed immediately when 2 ships showed up. They killed us (us 3 vs 7 or 8) and circled the chest repeatedly until we left. They didn’t even want the treasure, they just didn’t want us to have it. Very toxic.

And that’s just one instance of many over my years of playing this. The Safer Seas is cool, I guess, but it’s not the best option. There should be an option, like in GTA Online, where you’re still in the same lobby as everyone else, but you’re unable to attack/be attacked. You can still watch others battle, still encounter people, just can’t be griefed. That’s what I would have implemented.

A whole separate lobby by yourself with nothing going on and little reward seems overkill. We still want to encounter people and take part in events, we’d just like to do it more peacefully. If that can be achieved in a game as toxic as GTA Online, there’s no reason it can’t work here.

So why am I downvoting it? Mainly because absolute sub-human scumbags play this game and there's no real way to escape them. If you're not in a crew with trustworthy people, you need to constantly be on the lookout while on land. And at sea, but that's another matter entirely, point is that if you're in the middle of doing something, especially a world event or Mermaid Shrine, people can and absolutely will destroy your ship while you're busy or wait for you to do all the hard work before doing so, ensuring they don't have to work for it while your efforts amount to absolutely nothing.

Yes, I know it's called 'Sea of Thieves', but it's no excuse for screwing people over just because you can. There are countless ways to get loot, making other people suffer because you're lazy is inexcusable.

As a Veteran player, I have to say that as of season 10's release with the new "safer seas" update, I don't find this game as appealing as I once did back in February 2020. SOT has changed a lot since then both in the good, the bad, and the ugly. seasons 1-7: great, Seasons 8 and 9: meh, season 10: made me not want to play the game anymore. Like I get it that not all players need the anxiety, and stress-inducing, players/reapers hounding them for hours (especially if you are a noob.). This game used to be fun and full of all walks of life. Now it's a hollow shell of what the game used to be. I have met a lot of cool and fun people who turned into great lifelong friendships. ( like from the glitter beard Easter egg).  I wish SOT and Rare would actually take the time to ask the community for input for the next update (besides the insider's program). This game used to be an absolute BLAST of a game. Now fresh players don't get the experience we the elder players had right out of the CANNON. the safer seas were a great idea on paper but not in reality. I know I will get some hate from new players, but this recent update has made me and my entire crew stop playing SOT altogether.  It's still a great game, it's just not as exciting as it once was. I will still recommend this game to friends and other people that I meet but I would give them a precaution.  I have SUNK hours into this game, but as of this review date, I have not played this game at all since the new update came out. SOT is still one of my top-tier games. Like I said above. I met a lot of cool people who all shared one thing in common,"let's have some fun!". At least the new players get a better grasp of what the game is all about(mechanic-wise), they can then venture into the real world for some harder action than what the safer seas offer. I want to play this game but as of recently non of my cremates want to play, as my option is fairly similar to theirs, " Screw the new update it made the game full of sweats!" My buddy Esany

Thanks for taking the time to read my thoughts about this game and its status in 2024! 
Let's hope the SOT team and Rare can have a pint and chat it out.

Season 11 was over-hyped in promo material and seriously under-delivered.

Raids have zero respect for the time spent both unlocking them to begin with and then actually completing whatever challenge you chose. You will get about 5 pieces of loot regardless of the challenge or time investment, and it won't be particularly valuable loot either, just the bare minimum of whatever company you dove for. 

Voyages and random events seem mostly the same with only a few getting touch ups to not be totally worthless, though much of the 'rare' loot said to appear in these updated ones is rare enough that it's not really any more worthwhile to do them.

The Fleet of Fortune is just... a normal skelly fleet, with a chest of fortune. No other special loot to incentivize players to get it.

The update is mindbogglingly buggy and my Reputation will constantly drop and shoot back up at random, radials will often break, and several issues with captaincy commendations and milestones are still present after several updates.

If I had my way I'd suggest that players pay up some gold/doubloons to spawn world events and the loot of the event then changes based on whatever Emissary happens to finish the event, actually encouraging people to fight over them to get the most profit possible by having their team 'win' by completing the event, and not just waiting to ambush the person who does. But alas, that is not the reality we live in.

This 'overhaul' of the voyage system, events, and trading companies has been a serious letdown and I'd be shocked if player counts don't drop back down to whatever they were prior to the update, or even lower. Not without some serious changes on Rare's behalf at least, as currently this speaks of Devs with either not enough resources, community understanding, or care to make something that actually grips players beyond shiny new cosmetics.

TLDR, The game is split in two. PvEers who want to guild and farm Athena, and the toxic PvPing Reapers that infest High Seas and are proven to be more toxic than League of Legends, Dead by Daylight, or Dota 2 players. Let that sink in for a moment.

Safer Seas could have been the haven for PvE guilders, but no. The devs capped gold gain to 30%, rep to level 40 in any company, and disabled progress for capitancy, disabling having capitained ships at all, and you can't grind Athena at all even though it is literally designed for a PvE Guilded environment with how long it takes to level and farm emmisary for. It's basically just for chilling, commendation farming, and grinding gold since you can't earn any in High Seas anyway unless you want to deal with what is essentially people playing unofficial Ranked 24/7. Also, it still has an AFK timeout, because that was totally necessary in a solo experience. Now that the next season is viewable, you also can't grind for the prestige levels in here. Again, missed opportunity in favor of meatgrinding people for the PvPers. Garbage.

High Seas has everything enabled and at 100%, but you won't get any progress in anything because this is where the scumbag instasinkers/griefers/campers/returners (returning to where they died/sank to continue to hunt you until they win, it's annoying) hunt everyone (even other Reapers) down endlessly, and they've only gotten more and more toxic and kill-on-sight with every passing season. 

Thus, about like 75% of the content of the game is actually playable in Safer Seas (aka AT ALL), and all the fun bells and whistles are getting given to the most toxic part of the playerbase that doesn't care about them. Even the "Adventures" are in High Seas, and the PvEers are forced to grind EVEN MORE with the safer seas gold reduction, it's... all just so very dumb. 5/10 because only half the intended experience actually remains in Safer Seas.

Arrr, gather 'round, me hearties, for a tale of the Sea of Thieves and the misadventures brought forth by the latest update, launchin' this very day. The seas, once teemin' with life and excitement, now be feelin' the chill of a ghostly wind, as the developers have made decisions that would make even the fiercest pirate scratch their head.

In their pursuit of shiny coins from the Pirate Emporium, the devs have cast a shadow over the once-glorious seas. Fast travel now be a curse upon the waves, robbin' us of the thrill of a long sail. Aye, they've given in to the temptations of convenience, allowin' any scallywag to whisk themselves away to their quests with a mere snap of their fingers. The very essence of piracy – the sea breeze in yer hair, the creakin' of the ship, and the anticipation of the horizon – be vanishing like a ghost ship into the fog.

But that be not the end of the tale, me hearties. The Pirate Emporium be overflowin' with trinkets and baubles, enticin' newcomers with promises of grandeur while neglectin' the seasoned sailors who've weathered the storms. And mark me words, the seas be feelin' emptier than a deserted isle, for these newfangled fast travel shenanigans be temptin' pirates to abandon ship, leavin' their loot behind and seekin' refuge in a different server.

The PvP heart of Sea of Thieves, the very essence of the Pirate's life, be sufferin'. Events be poppin' up like mushrooms after a storm, and the once-thriving PvP Reaper's Alliance be feelin' the brunt of this change. The social fabric of the seas be torn, and the joy of meetin' fellow pirates in the vast expanse be replaced with a grindin' monotony.

And as if a ship without a compass, the game's performance be takin' a hit, with hit registration as reliable as a drunken sailor tryin' to walk a plank. The developers be fixated on stockin' the Emporium with trinkets to lure in fresh blood, while old hands be left with naught but the bitter taste of disappointment.

Sea of Thieves, once a beacon of promise on the gaming horizon, be now a ship adrift in turbulent waters. Rare, oh Rare, ye be leadin' us down a treacherous path, where the thrill of adventure be replaced with the drudgery of a never-endin' grind. May the winds of change blow in yer favor, or may ye find yerselves stranded on a deserted isle with no grog to comfort ye!

Sea of Thieves is dead, and the developers killed it. If you look at the player count on the community hub, no that number is not a glitch, that's the ACTUAL playercount. 

The community was alienated for so long, with no valid updates for over a year, they let the gameplay get boring. Even after a whole new season with updates, all they did was split the players into two separate versions- "safer seas", where you're the only crew on the server, and the regular mode. 

When your player count is this low, being able to turn off cross-platform will alienate your players, having a separate PVP mode where you literally leave the map will alienate your players, private servers will alienate your players. When you have more people WATCHING Sea of Thieves on a BoxyFresh stream than actually PLAYING it on Steam, there's a huge issue. 

The problem is that we all love the game, but you can't figure out how to keep your players to PLAY, and even less, keep them engaged. The game is incredibly good, but it relies on other players playing with you to do so. If you can't fill up a server with other crews due to low player count and no cross-platforming, there's essentially no reason to play.
Plenty to explore, lot of fun to be had, it's great for solo experience, but better as a group experience.

Clear Xbox Live credential from Steam
- Click the Start button from the bottom Left corner of Windows and type Credential Manager then press Enter.
- Once viewing the Credentials Manager, click the Windows Credentials button.
- Find Entries labelled Xbl_Ticket
- Left click any with 1717113201 (or 804980065 if you are playing the Insiders Build) in the name and select Remove
- Sign back in to Sea of Thieves

i started the game when it first came to steam, around 2019 i believe, they released frequent updates maybe not with much content but enough content to keep everyone happy without overworking their workers. ive heard rumors of the main dev team changing so rare can work on different games, ever since then the game quality has drastically dropped, from gimmick features being added every season, to severe hit registration issues becoming even worse, the game was fun while it lasted and having almost 4.5k hours, i can say the first 1000-2000 were fun, figuring out stuff for myself etc. i started as a player only doing quests, keeping away from players because i didnt see the point in fighting, but then i slowly started becoming more and more pvp oriented just so i could find a reason to stay on the game because i enjoyed the gameplay. but now the gameplay has been ruined in my opinion, changing fundamental mechanics which also resulted in stuff becoming buggier. i dont expect this game to last through time, but it is fun if you play it for a year or so
Oh yeah, add a feature no one asked for instead of addressing the blatant hackers, couldnt be season 11 and 10! ( i guess i can kinda say something as i have 620 hours on console)

Only downside is that you have to get a Xbox Live account, free, but don't like their policies.

Outside of that, ships steer like the real-deal, drift in high wind, and stay away from squalls!  Weapon choices are very basic but each fun.  Sword (default) and flintlock pistol, blunderbuss, or rifle (eye of reach) are the basics you choose from, can switch on boat or at weapon smith.  You can sail around fighting to get drop quests, take on quests from the different people (gold hoarders, merchants, etc...) or even go around just in PVP mode.  Ship battles are quite fun but take time, if you have never shot a real weapon, as you have to lead your target with cannons.  Depending on what ammo you are using, it may be slower flight path so you have to wait way ahead all while your ship is bobbing up & down too.

Resource gathering really isn't that big of an issue, things auto-replenish on islands or can be found easy enough.  Quests start out easy enough and get progressively harder but the rewards scale up on each as well.  Don't spend your money outright on silly things, they're just cosmetic, does not change accuracy, or anything like that.  You'll want to save up to 250k coins to buy a Sloop (cheapest) boat so you have a named + captained boat vs. having to charter one.

Take wide berths on parking/dropping anchor at islands or you'll be repairing and bucketing a lot.  Also, when it rains, you'll need to to go bucket as well.  You'll know when it is time, your ship will slow down even in full sail.

Get your pirating, sailing, and plunder on, a lot!

Been sailing the seas since the early days total played time easily 2000+ hours. Seas has ups and downs, and plenty o' cheaters. If you can get past that SoT is a lovely sandbox pirate simulator that is a gem of a multiplayer & best played with a crew, but can just as easily be played by yourself for a extra challenge.

What i liked about the game:
• Stunning seascapes: The world of Sea of Thieves is a visual feast. Sun-kissed islands, treacherous reefs, and mesmerizing sunsets will draw you in and keep you captivated.
• good combat: From sword-clanging duels to cannon barrages, combat is visceral and thrilling. Coordinating with your crew to sail, fight, and mend the ship makes for some truly epic moments.
• Evolving content: Rare hasn't been sitting idle. New Tall Tales, world events.
• storytelling: The best stories in Sea of Thieves aren't scripted, they're forged in the fires of player interaction. A tense standoff with another crew, a daring heist, or a shared voyage filled with laughter - these are the memories that truly stick.



Cons:
• Repetitive core gameplay: While the world is vast, the core activities like fetching skulls or digging up chests can get repetitive after a while.
• Solo sailing struggles: While doable, Sea of Thieves truly shines with a crew. Solo players can feel stranded and vulnerable, especially against coordinated galleons.
• Grindy progression: Reaching Pirate Legend, the ultimate goal, takes a hefty investment of time. The lack of meaningful skill or power unlocks can feel demotivating for some.
• PvP: While player interaction adds spice, toxic encounters with griefers can sour the experience, especially for new players

After 100 hours, I'd say I have a decent enough grasp of the game to give it a proper review. 

The world is expansive. There is enough content for me to play for hundreds of hours and still have things I haven't seen or explored. I enjoyed the combat system, though as someone who plays on a laptop, it can be difficult to compete with more experienced players when I encounter a host of microstutters. The story mode (Tall Tales) is also quite fun! You travel to places inaccessible in the normal game, and the crossover with Pirates of the Caribbean was fantastic! Especially for someone who splits my time fairly evenly between playing by myself and playing with friends, having something I could do that didn't put me at risk of getting stomped by a larger crew was a refreshing option. 

With that being said, as has been reiterated in many reviews, don't play this game entirely solo. It is, put simply, not nearly as fun or engaging when you aren't chatting in VC, cracking jokes and having a good time. There is a heavy focus on activities that are best done with a crew, and you'll feel far more immersed in the game when you have a few friends at your side! This is also not a game for people who can't pick themselves back up after getting griefed. You WILL lose your loot, get spawn-killed, outclassed, etc. If you find yourself getting very angry or frustrated when your hard-won loot gets stolen, you will likely find this game difficult to get into. Lastly, I want to highlight performance. This game does RUN on lower-end PCs/laptops, but the difference in performance between those and higher-end setups is MASSIVE. I've had plenty of experience playing games at low FPS, so this doesn't particularly bother me, but if you play on a relatively poor gaming setup, this game will likely be difficult to enjoy, from lag spikes to a lack of optimization when it comes to massive items counts, etc. There are also some bugs that have seemingly been ignored by the development team, such as your vessel flipping over randomly and sinking. 

Overall, I've enjoyed the game a lot, but I recognize that it isn't for everyone, and that it has its flaws. I would still recommend it, but there are a few caveats. Solid 8/10!

Honestly my favourite game, it comes with its pros and cons however. Rare (Developer) has made some poor choices in my opinion with the games infrastructure like allowing all levels to join to safer seas, I understand the concept for newer players being able to learn the game, but being able to grind Gold curse without dealing with reapers and other idiots just looking to sink someone without anything takes away from the difficulty of spending 40+ hours needed for the curse. I would be more in favour if they balanced safer seas more.

On a more positive side the game will always be my go to. From being able to change what your doing every match to grinding out levels the game offers so much, and even at 400 hours at the moment I'm still learning so much everyday. be open to learning new things/skills within the game. Pirate legend is easily accomplished with 2 months of casual play. Looking back even when I hit Pirate legend I still see a noob, with minimal knowledge of the game. 

Sometimes, the game will drive you nuts, like seeing a Shrouded ghost for the first time, all just for it instantly disappear and never see one again since. That's the beauty of the game though, constant pursuit of new tasks, and the memories you make, even if you're solo slooping.

Better with friends, but an amazing world to get lost in, even with some bugs present. The bad days where you lose lots of treasure are still worth it.

The combat is clunky, the player base is toxic as hell, and no amount of new cosmetic or crossover event is going to fix this game - because at its very DNA the game is faulty. The live service model needs to die, and every time my breath is taken away looking out on the beautiful rolling seas, the sun shimmering off the ripples, I think about what this game could be if it wasn't poisoned.

TL;DR: A genre-defining game with some players who'll make you nostalgic for the comparatively mild toxicity of DotA 2's saltiest.

Long-session pirate sandbox with (often high-stakes) PvP, steep learning curve and a high skill ceiling.
On paper, that sounds like a disaster to me, but somehow I keep coming back - and I'm still loving it. There's a lot of fun to be had in the PvE content.

The PvP [strike]Arena mode[/strike] (RIP) matchmaking via the faction hourglass is pretty average, just one ship against another with the sole goal of sinking the opposing vessel, doesn't match the scrapped Arena mode for me but the devs have explained this shift.

Emergent PvP in Adventure mode is a mixed bag - its mere presence adds a bit of thrill to many parts of the game and smashing other crews who thought they'd sink you is a great time. On the other hand, it can be rough for new players to keep getting demolished while learning the ropes, and even for seasoned players it can be a nuisance when some rube chases you while you're just trying to complete voyages and sell loot.
Most of my PvP experiences while solo just consist of sailing away from my pursuer, selling my loot and scooting off to another server (unless they ragequit and sink mid-chase because they can't catch me, that's a good chuckle).
Still, as I've seen others remark, I can't deny it's often worth the possibility of PvP for the tension it adds - it very quickly gets dull grinding with ease on alliance servers.

Speaking of grind, that's an aspect that occasionally detracts from the game - there's so much community focus on hitting the game's codified quantitative milestones that it all starts to feel like piracy by the numbers when you talk to some players, not about the enjoyment of the game itself.
I find some of my favourite moments in SoT are the least grind-focused; I personally find a lot of joy in meeting other players on the sea who aren't trying to sink me. It's not just a relief to find out that they're not aggressive, it's fun just to hang out for a minute - playing instruments, launching fireworks, swilling grog (and then playing instruments again but so much worse), sharing supplies and treasure, even forming an alliance so everyone gets bonus profits.

All up, despite the issues, Sea of Thieves is still the quintessential pirate fantasy experience.

That being said, I can't post a review in good conscience without putting emphasis on how absolutely heartless other players can sometimes be; something about Sea of Thieves attracts the most atrocious people, some of whom will hunt you no matter how little gold or fun they get out of it (the tone in the verbal abuse over voice chat is more than enough to tell you they're not even enjoying it themselves). So, word of warning - be prepared to face some of the most rotten individuals that the gaming community has to offer (and I say this as someone with a few hundred hours in DotA2).
Maybe the fact that you'll encounter horrible people in this game will add to the pirate-y feel of the world for some, but I find it's usually just tedious.

This used to be my favorite game in the world, something I logged into every single day and played with a dedicated group of friends. But Rare has slowly but surely strangled the life out of this game, short-sighted update by mismanaged update.

Inch by Inch, Rare has removed every single aspect that made this a great game. Loot bloat has never stopped, adding more and more useless rewards that heap gold upon you, allowing you to purchase cosmetics that have long since stopped meaning anything. The grind is gone, and what was once a sense of satisfaction of hours of raiding other players and scouring the seas for every last gold to buy a new cosmetic, is now shallow and left behind.

The addition of Safer Seas, or private PvE exclusive servers, has ruined the game more thoroughly than any other update possible. Sea of Thieves is a PvP game, built and born, designed to support that gameplay from day 1. It's why every single player has the exact same gear and weapons, the only thing that ever separated a fresh install from a max level Reaper was skill, and skill alone. It has always been a game about piracy, a game about stealing loot from other players, and emergent gameplay from players ambushing you at the worst possible time to steal your hard earned loot. Even the possibility of PvE servers ruins this aspect. If even one person can opt out of this, the house of cards starts to crumble as people choose the path of least resistance.

With Season 11 now on the horizon, what gameplay is left has been compromised to an extent I'm surprised there's a game left. Being able to dive to skip directly to world events destroys the manual teamwork gameplay and exploration that made SoT what it is. Seeing other ships sailing across the open seas far away reminded you that this world was real, that they had a story and a journey of their own. Why spend so much development time to make sailing fun, then allow us to skip it all together, when all it does is help us stack more meaningless loot, for even more worthless cosmetics?

With a price tag of 40 dollars still, there is no way I could ever willingly recommend anyone play the withered husk of this game anymore. From a cheater epidemic that Rare still has yet to even give more than lip service to, to ever janky and unresponsive hit registration, to a dead and forgotten story that still hasn't even seen an update with the results of a community vote made almost three years ago now. Rare has lost the plot, and lost what made them great. 

I'll always cherish the memories of this game I have with my closest friends, the fun of sailing the open seas, and the battles we fought in against so many different players, to even a time we tried to run a pirate alliance with public ships that spoke different languages. This game was my favorite game ever made, and still holds a fond place in my heart, but I cannot ever recommend anyone else play it. That Sea of Thieves I fell in love with is gone.

I have over 1600 hours in this game, but it's reached the point where I cannot recommend it.

Sea of Thieves used to emphasize natural interactions between players in a sandbox, PvPvE environment. You could forge alliances (and risk betrayal, or betray), fight over map events, rob others for loot, etc. As of S11, Safer Seas and PvP Hourglass have moved in a direction that strongly separates the community. The new S11 'feature' to teleport players to their objectives further streamlines the game such that natural player interactions continue to be minimized. This game is now catering to the ADHD crowd who doesn't want to have to spend more than 20-30 minutes playing at a time. The game no longer honors the spirit with which it was designed and sold to me.

RIP Sea of Thieves, 2018-2024

Fun, immersive, and a joy to play on one side, and irritating on the other. Rare's golden goose of new players has led to a stigma and prioritization of PVE and its content. Not a bad thing, but when PVE is clearly prioritized on one side for monetization, rather than split 50/50 with PVP, issues tend to arise from neglect. Hourglass is perfect content for the PVP niche, but, following 5 years, no real anti-cheat, or anything has been developed to combat cheaters. Cheater's have been on the rise, and Rare has done nothing. They went as far as to release a reporting system to where you can report offensive names, but not the main problem of cheating; a big F-U to players.

Either way, stigma's within the community following Rare's lack of initiative arose, and PVE players simply, to this day, ignore the problem as why would they? Cheater's aren't a problem in PVE SOT, but PVP, Cheater's are abundant and with PVP being such a low niche in the game, there's no real way to fairly represent a quater of the player base, not when most of well known, respected, and knowledgeable people have been banned either unfairly, or for the use of 120 FOV, which is considered cheating because of its third party application to the game's set FOV of 90.

Even past the glaring issues of Rare's golden goose's and Rare's lack of updates on cheater's, Sea of Thieves is built on an old, outdated engine, which refuses to be upgraded because of SOT's partnership with Xbox. This of course causes problems such as D-sync, poor performance in some areas, laggy terrain and sea's, and the most apparent, Hit-Reg; something that has plagued the game for years, and still remains a constant issue. If it's not symbolic or representative enough, their attempts to fix it for those attempts to then be in vein only represents the incompetence on the management side of Rare, but also the underlying issue of the engine of the game.

Here's to the closure of Rare's partnership with Xbox, and the betterment of the game.

Sea of Thieves is definitely one of the best games I've played, truly an ultimate pirate experience. It fairly steadily receives updates, doesn't have a whole lot of bugs for being a large MMO, and looks absolutely beautiful in its own high-def cartoon-y aesthetic which I think is a really good look for a video game.

As for cons of the game, there is a decent amount of meta-gaming/sweaty tactics you run into in some combat situations. They're usually able to be beat while playing for fun but sometimes the PvP can be frustrating. Overall I've found it to be enjoyable.

Last of all, this game is great to play with friends. One problem with multiplayer is that, say you and Friend A are logged on, sailing in a 2-player sloop, and then Friend B comes online, you would have to wrap up everything you're doing to log back in as a 3-player brigantine to add Friend B to the party. There's no real way to fix this with the game except for maybe under-staffing a larger ship if you're expecting someone to want to join you. Overall, the ideal experience in this game is just laughing with your friends on a big galleon.

PVP in this game needs some kind of rework. I usually play with friends and 9/10 of our fights are us spawn camping on a sloop until it sinks. It's not fun for us doing it, and it's not fun for the people we're doing it to. If they could arrange things in such a way that there is less emphasis on boarding ships, I'd really like that. [strike] Incredibly disappointing. This game is like a crisp apple with a dead worm in the middle of it. Absolutely fucking beautiful environments, the sky is gorgeous at night, the water looks fantastic, and waves actually rock the boat in an incredibly immersive way. The cooperation is put together wonderfully, and the in game voice chat (when it works) is pretty funny. Manning your ship with your friends is very fun and the cooperation and communication of exploring with your crew is wonderful. But... [/strike]

[strike] PVP is not an option, it is a requirement, and it sucks ass. It is simplistic and boring and lots of times will just result in you getting spawncamped or you spawncamping your enemy. it is a pointless addition and adds absolutely nothing of value to the game. It'd be okay if you could toggle it on or off, so players who want PVP join PVP enabled servers, and players who just want to have a relatively calm adventure with their friends can play alone on a PVE only server. But no, for some reason this is not an option. [/strike]

[strike] 𝐈𝐧 𝐬𝐡𝐨𝐫𝐭: The game has everything going for it, but is completely ruined by random players interrupting you and your friends having fun just to kill your 20 times for no reason. Do not buy this game if you want a fun pirate adventure. Only buy this game if you want to participate in ridiculously mediocre PVP with a nice looking backdrop and a bunch of 14 year-olds yelling at you. [/strike]

Sea of Thieves has a wonderful looking open world, fun to use sailing mechanics as well as a very interesting setting with historical pirates and a bit of fantasy like skeletons and ghosts. Overall I thought this was a very promising game, that it might even be on a level with GTA. But this game really isn't what it appears to be.
    What I love about other open world games is that they offer you lots of freedom. You can make your own character, your own playstyle, your own story. The problem about SoT is that it is [b]heavily[/b] PvP focused. There are two game modes. [i]Arena[/i], obviously where players constantly fight each other and [i]Adventure[/i], where players basicly just have to first find others to kill but the community views these two modes equally. Every player behaves the same way; they'll attack on sight. There is no freedom in playstyle because everyone who does not constantly fight others will just be killed by other players or be forced to constantly run away. [u][b]Anyone interested in PvE or anything else other than constant PvP has no place in Sea of Thieves[/b][/u] is a message most of the community and the developers alike convey in forums and discussions. If the community's majority does not like PvE, fine. But it's not like nobody there would like some ability to avoid PvP and I greatly disapprove of this utter shunning of ideas and requests with wonderful phrases such as [i]"Don't tell the developers how you want the game to be"[/i] or [i]"There is nothing wrong with spawnkilling. People who say there is are just venting"[/i] and the occasional [i]"git gud, noob"[/i]. It just doesn't offer any variety and exactly destroys the open world freedom of being able to do anything you want, because you can [b]try[/b] anything you want just to [b]always[/b] end up in a fight. Also goes without saying that even those who do like it will become bored rather quickly as attacks by player also only have so much room for staying thrilling.
    There are PvE styled Trading Companies with which players can make money. People say it was the thrill of always being vulnerable when moving cargo and so on that grasps them, but honestly it's just pure stress and frustration, it makes me wonder how masochistic people have to be to enjoy always being forced to do it this way. If you could optionally expose yourself to gain extra rewards and achievements or something, so it wasn't mandatory I'd kinda understand but as it as it's far from fun.

Another major issue SoT has is progression. There is virtually none. Pertinent to its arena like style in activities, also progression in Sea of Thieves is more similar to League of Legends than GTA. [u]For the most part[/u] the only things you can attain are non-gameplay-relevant cosmetics. All use your gold has to buy a new shirt, apply a skin to your gun or change visuals of your ship. Somewhat unfortunate as there is not even an outfit system meaning as soon as your character has a single set clothing which you think looks good (which is a basic part of creating a character and should not be a long term thing) you are either passionate for fashion and will keep creating outfits anyway or you will likely never change your colthing and subsequently lose one of not exactly many things on which to spend your self-annihiatlngly hard earned gold.
    The aforementioned Trading Companies sell Voyages to players, allowing them to look for treasure or kill skeletons among other activities (or at least attempt it until another player blows up your ship). There is a certain sense of progression here, however in a nutshell, you earn reputation to increase your rank, which allows you to buy promotions, which allows you to buy more cosmetics and it increases the length and cost of Voyages. Another annoyance is as you don't get to choose price and length of the Voyage. At first ALL your Voyages are short & cheap (even free at first) and once you're promoted ALL Voyages are expensive & expansive. There is also the Pirate Legend status, which to the best of my knowledge only unlocks one thing: an exclusive Trading Company, called Athena's Fortune. To reach that you need a certain reputation in a certain number of Trading Companies and I heard you need to buy all their promotion cosmetics. I don't know AF's exact offers or what makes it so special but I assume a feature that less than 3% of the players CAN (which doesn't automatically mean they do) access can't make such a great difference and it's probably hardly even interesting.

Having said a lot about what is not good about this game and why I would not recommend the game to the average gamer in its current state, I also think this game did and still sort of does have some potential. I love the way sailing and navigating work. It's not one of these Battlefield-ish one guy drives aN MBT, rotates and fires its main gun, loads it and somehow manages to look the behind all at the same time. In SoT sailing is very realistic and immersive. And still it's somehow balanced, one guy can easily drive a small ship without major trouble, but when driving a bigger ship everyone still has their role to fulfill. Also the game uses very little UI, actually just some HUD, which adds to the realism and immersion meaning you actually have to look at the ship's map to figure out where you are and if that isle you're sailing to was east or actually weast.
I've yet to actually play any of with a crew, as I mostly play solo, but the game does have some exciting looking world events, like fighting an armada of ghost ships, and something of a story mode with interesting and perilous dungeons to brave. Also the ship combat seems somewhat unique (seriously if you know a different game that offers this type combat please tell me) and could be fun if you willingly engage in a fight.

Even if it currently looks like the devs are going to keep ignoring the game's issues, the community will keep hating and the game will stay repulsive to many, I personally hope that in the future the game will change and attract more like minded players so that we can [b]all[/b] enjoy our stay on the seas, not just the PvP worshippers. But some men just want to watch the world burn... [sad pirate noises]

As of January 2024, I have to change my review of this game.  Ever since the introduction of safer seas in December of 2023, the player base seems to feel less horrible.  There are still the odd ones here and there, but they seem to have become less common than they were a year ago.  The QoL changes to the game have been fantastic, the game feels fun and solid with engaging game play and tense PvP.  Sometimes the PvP still feels a bit unbalanced, but, safer seas has given folks a place to better practice the basics so the fights are getting more balanced, but there's some ways to go.  I'm looking forward to what the devs are gonna introduce in the future as it seems they are trying to make the game more accessible for new players and engaging for veterans at the same time.

Literally the pirate game I always dreamed of when I used to play games like Pirate Storm and SeaFight back in the day.


Visually, it's nice, it has its own style and it forms a wacky coherent world that just works. Also the waves are gorgeous.

Gameplay feels a little heavy? But not like "this character is too slow" heavy, more like "yeah there's weight to these actions, it feel right this way". I really love that we play in 1st person view and that we get to pilot our ships ourselves, instead of just "instructing" it to go to places like in the games aforementioned. It feels rewarding but also dramatically increases the immersion. I love the combat (PVE and PVP) and the naval battles can be absolutely thrilling. I do wish there was big sea creatures to hunt, other than the megalodon that has barely any interesting rewards.
The best part of the gameplay in my opinion is the moment-based spontaneous structure of the game. One minute you're cruising at sea, going somewhere, nobody in sight and you're alone with the wind, and the next minute you have something attacking you and you gotta make decisions about it, whether it's an enemy crew, a bunch of skeletons, a kraken, or a fort.
Also navigating in itself is satisfying. Figuring out which island is your destination, finding it's direction, and manning your ship while keeping course feels amazing.

The addition of Safer Seas, while clumsily marketed as an extended tutorial, is a great environment to work on Commendations and Tall Tales without having people interfering even though you're the smallest fish in the pond while doing these activities. 

Music is trying very very hard to be Pirates of the Carribean, which I don't mind, I'm a fan of the trilogy myself.

It runs better than I thought it would so I'm happy about that.

I'm a bit icky about the microtransaction/massive in-game shop/plunder pass that capitalizes on FOMO, but then again, in this game the only thing that separates noobs from experts at first glance is the cosmetics since there are no actual progression systems in the game. So really this is kind of expected and Sea of Thieves isn't one of the worst offenders in this category anyway.



Overall a stand out experience in the current gaming landscape, if you like immersive games that make you work more than the usual, you will like this one, but beware there is a large skill ceiling and you will suck at first.
This game is what you make it. There can be some rude people out there but you shouldn't let that discourage you from having a great time playing with friends!

So i've played Sea of Thieves since the closed beta in early 2018, and I've watched this game go from a fun yet shallow game, to one of my favorite comfort games ever.

Since launch, I've always had a differing opinion on the PVP community that surrounds this game, I enjoy how spontaneous it can be where someone can team up with you for one hell of a night, or you get the unfortunate luck of running into players that do play the game the way it was intended, but sure act like it's a reason to throw off slurs and insults because they killed you.

With Safer Seas launching, I still see a lot of people saying this effectively splits the community in half, and only caters to people that dont want to deal with PVP because they're "soft". I would have loved a mode like Safer Seas all the way back in 2018, even if it was more limited than it is today. I'm fine with the cut in profits and some content only being available in high seas if it means i can spend an hour not having to worry about a 4 team galleon wrecking a sloop that has nothing on it.

The game is perfect now. I cant ask for anything else.

Forever back and forth on if I recommend this game or not. 
BUT NOT RECOMMENDED FOR SOLO PLAYERS

This is the ultimate "sandbox" pirate game. With the right group of friends, and the right group of strangers (both friendly or unfriendly) - This can be insanely fun. The experience you have and the tale you will be able to tell about your adventures (and misadventures) is magical. It is, after all, the literal entire point of the game. Hour 1 plays the same as Hour 1000. The loot is only for cosmetics, "leveling up" is only for cosmetics, and the entire game map is unlocked as soon as you start (not including Tall Tale locations, which are essentially main quest story missions). You play to gain nothing except meaningless cosmetics, so you ultimately play to just play and have fun with friends. It's all about the journey with each voyage, not the destination. It's all about your crew interactions, and other ship interactions, the teamwork or betrayal. I love it.

But sometimes the "sandbox" on the playground has bullies in it that don't want to play with the sand, they just want to kick your sandcastle down and throw dry poop in your face, while screaming into their mic's. They aren't here for the voyages, or even for your stored treasures on board. With the desired intention of simple grief, these toxic players can make this game truly unplayable and frustrating.

I do think it might be related to post-game boredom for some players. After hundreds of hours, you finally hit "Pirate Legend" and what is there to do? Not much. So you can either choose to be a friendly mentor to new players or terrorize them.

Do I want a PvE mode, though? Not really. I totally understand the argument to allow PvE for kid players and their parents. But otherwise - The combat is... fine. The voyages are... fine. Tall Tales are... fine. Sailing is a highlight and fun. I'm just not sure the core of this game is strong enough to make a PvE experience compelling. It's the wildcard element with strangers that make this game special (and sometimes a nightmare).

So this hurts to write Pretty much at this Point,
SoT was and is a Great Game without any Contestants in its field of beeing a Sandbox Pirate game.

In its basics it is enjoyable and a fun time to steal , work out Plööans to get treasure and all in all Fight or Ambush others or even go full Fight in the Hourglass mode.

I found friends in this game , Enemies , People that can share a laugh , Roleplayers , Furrys , TF2 Enjoyers , Crackheads , Single Mothers with 3 Children and Dads that went for Milk 20y ago. or for short , a beutiful game with endless Potential

THE SAD STATE OF THE GAME 2024:

-The Seas are pretty empty so far, seasoned Players are dropping the game since the Content for older Players is Dwindling by now.
- There is a nasty amount of Hacking Pirates and Cheaters , and the Process of actualy banning them needs you to have a recording setup on your PC with either Shadowplay OBS or recording Software of your Choice and then open a Ticket , not from the Game but from the Official SoT website
-Major Bugs start happening with even the most Minor of Updates im taljkin about  excessively long blackscreens for Respawnig / Shooting thyself out of cannons not working & Hitregistration functionality etc. and more....
-A Company that doesnt Care about their Playerbase anymore.

Sea of Thieves is one of the best Open World Adventure Multiplayer games you could possibly buy right now! Rare captures their strong story telling and world building amazingly in this game, as of the time of this review there's so many options players have in regards to going on adventures and exploring the map from Tall Tales to Fighting Megladons what's not to love about Sea of Thieves?

Personally I've had so many incredible moments and fun experiences with friends on the seas! one highlight for me is meeting The Longest Johns while they were streaming for the Yogscast jingle jam stream in 2021.

2023: I've met and fought BehavingBeardly, LadyHaradaNiwa, EBacon and had the pleasure of sailing with ToxieSinclaire too. I've even some developers such as Andrew Preston the lead designer & Stephen Frost! I saved them with my friend while they were getting attacked by a Reaper in Hourglass we sank their enemy and they gave us plenty of their time we took screenshots together and were given a crate of "Rare Fireworks" which contain two hundred fireworks, Ten of which were fireworks of the Rare LTD logo. I think what makes this game special are the experiences you have and sometimes the mystery and unknown element of the game.

22/11/2023: Since writing this review I have clocked in an additional 2066 hours into this game and I will say despite the reputation it has I love playing Sea of Thieves 2023 has been a difficult year for the game but all in all they've added a variety of promising and content. Most recently they added the Skull of Siren Song quest which aims to have players race across the map to dig up a chest and key and battle to be the victor and hand in the SOSS (Skull of Siren Song).

They also added Monkey Island Tall Tales which add some fun adventures to an already exciting game! In these Tall Tales, you'll be visiting Monkey Island & Melee Island, locations filled with plenty of puzzles to solve. Stay away from the negative views on twitter this game is great! despite some of the lows it faced it's future is really promising.

So this is a difficult one for me. I've been playing since October 2021 and have seen this game grow and change over the years. There are a lot of good points and a lot of bad so I will break them down here.

Good as New Player
- Vast Exploration. As of 2024 The world is rich and diverse with plenty to do catering to all play styles. If you avoid all PVP  combat then it'll get boring after 60hrs. 
- Endless Sailing. 
- Pirate and Ship Customisation. Dress your pirate how you want and decorate your ship to reflect your pirate style
- Meeting New People. There is in game chat via text or with your microphone. All kinds of folk from different walks of life 
   who've had there own pirating stories to tell or just to bond with.
- Tall Tales. Story driven quests that will take you all over the sea of thieves. 

Bad
- Gameplay. It's a clunky mess. The Devs made changes to player animation to prevent players from quick switching 
  weapons to make the skill floor more balanced which I'm all for. However the implementation of it has created a lack of fluidity in movement.
- Hourglass (on demand PVP) has created this strange toxicity. Rarely do I see positive interactions during or after fights. There are also swathes of cheaters now. Keg spawns on your ship, Teleporting enemies, Invisibility, Cannon Aim assist, ESP, Item generation. It's no fun.
- Server Instability. Along with the clunky mechanics are server side stuttering, teleportation, un-registered key presses.
- Season Cosmetics. They made Season cosmetics purchasable in shop stores for doubloons. Things that were said to be 'Time Limited' are not. 

So in conclusion. It was a great game. But not anymore. 
Devs;
The key decision makers at Rare need to focus on fixing this game before adding more content and creating further instability. Otherwise player retention will fall and the life and soul of this game will diminish.

TLDR : PvP ganking game. Great for those that enjoy a game with pure PvP with zero level system or special equipment.  One of the few PvP games that is not Pay to Win.

- So if you LOVE PvP then this is the game for YOU as it has ZERO pay to win features.
- Don't be fooled by the Safer Seas Coop game mode as it has everything locked behind a PvP game wall.

MAIN REVIEW:
Yes there is a story but you will not get to experience it much as your ship will be sunk by the time you get back from doing any of those Tall Tales.
The company Rare has broken the Tall Tales story quests into smaller chunks to give you a chance but unless you have a rare group of other players that just want to trade and sail you will not enjoy it.  As long time players know where the tales quest points are and camp them often.

New 'A Pirates Life' content is PvE on a seperate shard for you and your coop crew to enjoy... great... just 10 hours long. Can't grumble too much.. it was free DLC to those that have the game.

Even newer - 'Safer Seas.'
Now you can play the main game in Coop with your crew of friends... ah.. no you can't play the main game. Lots of content is locked behind a 'Come and play this in PvP High Seas PLEASE' game wall.

You get very little gold from doing quests.
You can't advance your reputation with anyone.
You can't unlock special chests as the quest to get the keys is behind PvP wall.
You can't buy a ship to decorate.
It is just a token taster to tempt some people, in hopes they then step over to play the PvP ganking side of the game.

With so many Coop pirate games coming over the horizon in 2025 I would have thought they would at least try and get a PvE fan base going before they loose most players and end up with the PvP lot grumbling at no easy kills. (as the PvP lot don't tend to attack each other that much) Hopefully they will see that they can make money from the PvE Coop crowd and unlock more features in the Safer Seas. Because as it stands there is very little reason for a player to spend money on in-game cosmetics if they can not equipment it on a ship.

Main game is great for those that want the Pirate Life and to be constantly looking over your shoulder as you do map quests and gather loot. There are players that are not interested in any of that and just want to sink any player they come across but don't wish to take on the PvE enemy.

At the end of your game session you will have nothing. As there is NO level system. NO special ships or weapons. You will have gold to buy a cosmetic for your ship and your character.
When you next log in your will start from zero again and have to re-equip your ship and apply that paint job you bought. All before another player comes along and probably sinks you in port. 

Giving it a thumbs down as I am reviewing from my point of view.
That point of view is - 

This game gives you no reason to come back. 

You gain nothing from it other than the knowledge that you possibly made someone else miserable by ruining their last hour or more of gameplay as they tried to follow the maps and gain gold.

I can't stand griefers and gankers, as life is short and people who get a kick out of making others unhappy have something wrong in their head.

Conclusion :

Great PvPvE (Player Vs Player Vs Everything) As that is what you will face.. EVERYTHING.

Great that it has not evolved into a Pay to Win model.

Safer Seas has potential but it is early days.

Avoid if you don't like being ganked by people that just want to make your gaming experience that evening a wasted one.

Sea of Thieves is a fantastic game for those looking to plunder the booty of a vast sea with the freedom to choose where you go and what you do. The devs consistently push out updates in the form of "seasons" which provide additional content as well as a different progression system (battle pass). 

There are many different ways to earn money in Sea of Thieves, whether that being sailing to different islands defeating infamous skeleton captains in hand-to-hand combat and claiming their bounty to fighting off fleets of phantom ships and claiming the ghostly treasures aboard. There are different factions like the Gold Hoarders or Order of Souls that you can rank up in to become a Pirate Legend and gain access to a secret faction called Athena's Fortune, which offers more difficult quests for greater rewards. The progression mainly boils down to unlocking new cosmetics, as every type of weapon (cutlass, flintlock, sniper, blunderbuss) is available the second you start your journey. This doesn't take away from the game at all as there is a large variety of different unlockable cosmetics and it ensures fair fights between players.

The game isn't without its flaws. Sailing alone can get quite boring or frustrating, as if anyone with a multi-player crew decides to target you, you'll be sunk before you can say "shiver me timbers". There is an alternative game mode called Safer Seas which means you're the only ship in the server, fixing the issue of player griefing, but it has limited features and ways to make money as well as only gaining 30% of the base gamemode. Some people who are just looking for some fun without the stress of other players may prefer this, so if you think that's you, I fully recommend it. 

All in all, I 100% recommend this game despite its flaws. Grab a friend or two if you can, it makes the whole experience much more enjoyable. Happy plundering!
You get raided every 5 minutes but I don't care it's amazing

The typical negatives I see of this game are rather confusing; It seems people somehow fail to understand what they're getting in for when they hop onto an open ocean of pirates. 

- The PvP, while admittedly having a fairly steep learning curve, is an even playing field as every item is cosmetic and players will improve with time; Cannon shots will be more accurate, game sense to know when to repair, fire back or board will heighten and sailing will improve as you figure out when and where to raise/turn sails and the ship itself to maintain good angles. 
It is fairly easy to just avoid players if you want to avoid PvP all together if you check the horizon and map and keep in mind Galleons are fastest with wind and Sloops are fastest against. GL to the brigs though.

- The 'Lack of content' is something I've seen mentioned in several reviews and many more Youtube videos and this is one I think confuses me the most; For players that have been on this since day 1 I can understand how they may have this view as content has come and gone over the years and this last year was less content focused and more focused on back end stability and QoL updates as acknowledged by the developers but for any new players this point is a complete lie; I've got 150 hours as I write this and barely feel I've scratched the surface of what this game is offering so keep in mind the 3000 hr playtime of those complaining about this.

- "Safer seas sucks". Yeah I won't disagree on this, despite being a feature people seem to have been asking for since day 1 it has only just been put in the game and with considerable restrictions such as 30% cap on gold and xp making it fairly useless. I do however feel this is the right decision; If there were no restrictions to playing on safer seas and no incentives to play higher seas everyone would be on their own server removing all player interactions which add so much to the game and now instead of 5 crews in 1 server you have 5 crews on 5 servers and server stability is already something that could be regarded as a real problem for the game so making that worse in order to make the servers feel emptier would be plain stupid.
If you're expecting to just sail around peacefully fishing and digging up treasure with zero consequences on the aptly named "Sea of THIEVES" then you have made a big miscalculation and the game should not be blamed.

Now this game is far from perfect and there are issues that should be noted for people considering buying this game

- Server stability as mentioned can be problematic, this causes a variety of minor issues that can cause quite alot of frustration such as hit reg issues, teleporting, items not swapping/item wheel not working and the pain of crashing your ship because you were turning when servers merged. All these will put a dampener on your play session for sure but none are frequent enough to ruin the whole game.

-Playtime required; This is a big barrier for many people, trying to play this game in 1-2 hour increments will be a brutal grind; It is best to have a good few hours open at least so you can level up an emissary flag and get some use from it, generally the longer the play session the better (obvious really but the difference session length makes in this game is vast). If you don't have several consecutive hours to put in the game nor any friends who could keep the crew going while you're between sessions then expect any grind to be multiplied for you.

- Customisation. There's plenty of unique and well designed clothing, weapons and ship customisation with much more in the real money cash shop, The Emporium. With the free unlockable items being among the most prestigious and sought after bits content and the emporium being this games cash cow it's clear that players love this so it makes me wonder why there's still some obvious things that cannot be changed like the ships harpoons, lanterns, side ladders, map table, wheel compass and barrels. This is personally my biggest gripe with the game which should go quite far in telling you how impactful the negative issues mentioned actually are to the overall experience.

Sea of Thieves has a little of everything for everyone with work arounds for the bits you don't like and ways to enhance the bits you do but is definitely best played with friends and even though it might take a few sessions before you find your footing it's well worth it so grab a few buddies and I'm sure you'll have a good time, I would highly recommend it!

Title: A Sinking Ship of Disappointment

Rating: ★★☆☆☆

Sea of Thieves promised a captivating pirate adventure, but after spending countless hours navigating its turbulent waters, I can't help but feel like I've been sold a leaky vessel rather than a seaworthy ship.

First and foremost, the lackluster progression system left me feeling adrift in a sea of monotony. The repetitive fetch quests and unimaginative objectives failed to offer any real sense of accomplishment or meaningful rewards. Instead of a dynamic and evolving experience, I found myself stuck in a tedious cycle of rinse and repeat, with little motivation to continue.

The game's much-touted multiplayer aspect turned out to be more of a mirage than a treasure chest of excitement. Teaming up with friends should have been a highlight, but the shallow gameplay mechanics and uninspired combat encounters left us all yearning for a more engaging and challenging experience. The absence of any real consequences for failure made even the most intense encounters feel inconsequential.

Technical issues further marred the experience, with frequent server problems, bugs, and glitches that made me question the game's readiness for release. The constant need for updates and patches only underscored the developers' inability to deliver a polished product, leaving players to navigate a sea of frustration.

The lack of a compelling narrative or meaningful lore made the game world feel like an empty expanse rather than a rich, immersive environment. A dearth of storytelling left me with no emotional connection to the characters or the world, making the entire journey feel like a soulless endeavor.

In the end, Sea of Thieves is a shipwreck of missed opportunities and unfulfilled promises. The initial allure of a pirate's life quickly fades, leaving players stranded on a deserted island of disappointment. Save your doubloons and set sail for more promising horizons; Sea of Thieves is a sinking ship not worth boarding.

Bad community, great with friends, but I'd rather spend an afternoon hitting myself with hammers than dealing with sweaty gamers. Devs don't care or don't notice how bad the playerbase is, and would rather stick their heads in the sand than just let players have private/PvE servers to play on without worrying that someone with 60789275986 hours is going to roll up, call them a slur, and completely undo hours of progress.

Yeah, yeah. "It's Sea of Thieves, not Sea of Friends! This is how REAL pirates are!" Actual historical pirates took baths, and were usually the very subject of the slurs you use (minorities, women, disabled, LGBT+, etc.), my guys.

Edit: Now the game is actually fun AND playable with solo sessions! Lowered rewards and SLIGHTLY less stuff to do is a little annoying, but honestly, I play the game to play with friends and pretend to be a hee hee funney pirate and dig up buried treasure, or Tall Tales. Cry harder, sweatlords. I am soooo sorry that the way other people choose how to experience the product they bought hurts you personally and now y'all actually have to try at PVP against other sweatlords instead of screwing over folks who just want to hang with their friends or do Tall Tales. This game is a really good way to spend time with friends who live further away. Whether completing voyage quests, pillaging other players' ships, or just exploring the ocean together, its a great game for both solo and multiplayer shenanigans.

I love this game and the adventure it gives to it's players. Some common complaints I've seen for this game is that it gets old, while this can end up happening, it is unlikely. There is so much different things you can do in this game, to the point were if you get bored of one thing, you can just switch to something else. One way to prevent grinding is just to do a voyage(quest) or two, then hop off. Don't forget the beautiful visuals this game provides. It is incredibly fun solo, and multiplayer id even more enjoyable. Anything form a single voyage of nothing special, to sinking another ship and finding tons of loot, is the experience you are getting within this game. The final reason of why this game is incredible is the navigation is fun like nothing I've ever seen; raising the anchor, lowering the sails, and getting your ship to were it needs to go is some of the best traveling mechanics in a game ever. If you are more of a fan of single player platformers, or slow farming games, this is not for you, but if you enjoy being a pirate and setting off on a adventure with your friends, it is perfect for you.

This game is prodigiously empty. Over 100GB installs have become painfully familiar in recent years, but few games demand so much space while offering so little playable content. I'd wager the vast majority of that install size is 4K textures for the many paid cosmetic items that constitute most of this game's excitement. There is a half-decent concept buried under that weight, but the brief moments of progression you might feel at each stop on the few narrative questlines are severely undercut by the game then asking you to sail to a spot, interact with an object, and then rinse and repeat. You might get to kill one of about six different enemy types with the 4 functionality different weapons this game offers somewhere in there too.

Wind Waker figured out how to make sailing fun 20 years ago. Black Flag figured it out again a decade ago. It's a bummer I can't play those games with a friend, but when you have no destination, progress, or compelling quest, even playing with friends is a hollow experience.
