The biggest complaint about this game in it's infancy was that it lacked content. Every game critic and popular voice that tried the game failed to see it for what it was, which was a sandbox PvP game with the side goals of acquiring cosmetics, making coins, and enjoying the experience of discovery and sailing. The game has been beautiful since it was initially released on Xbox, I have played it since it first released on Gamepass in 2018. Many complained that the gameplay was tedious and repetitive and did not like the ship mechanics of angling sails, repairing holes, and having to constantly maintain compass bearing to reach destinations timely. These have always been necessary elements to force awareness into players about combat mechanics of cannon angles, wind speed and direction, ship maintenance, etc. There was never a time where I or most people I played with on Xbox saw this game as a PvE experience. Almost everyone flocked to skull forts to fight over them, one skull fort would typically take 2-4 hours to complete in the early days due to constant combat with everyone in the server. Over time, the devs produced content that ambitiously expanded the PvE experience, and the PvP foundations of the game went unchanged. Arena was released to mitigate the disparity between the divisive player base, because many players became upset when they lost hours of virtual gold circles to someone sinking them mid-grind. This was always the intended format for the game to be played in, and devs should have sought to balance the scale to make PvP and PvE worthwhile. What ended up occurring instead is that Arena gave PvP-oriented players a place to drastically increase their skills and test strategies and bugs in premade lobbies. No PvP player was ever going to compete in Arena and be satisfied with the game mode when they can return to the actual game (story mode) and destroy people much easier than before due to having hours of explicit PvP practice. PvE oriented players who had no interest in combat never learned how to properly defend themselves from better players, nor did they learn how to kite ships, run away or make creative plays to avoid confrontations they didnt want. Having played for years, I have experienced every dynamic of the game, having sought direct PvP, running from better players, making crafty escapes, tucking, stealthily sinking enemies, doing every quest and world event, etc. No matter what was happening to me, it was fun and entertaining and was part of the dynamic of the game. Anything could ruin an entire days grind of PvE, and I could just the same ruin someone elses day and not have any grudges or want to go rant on reddit about toxicity when I lost. Its part of the game and always has been.

The devs began to cater toward PvE players, openly allowing alliance servers to flourish, banning entire groups of PvP veterans from the game due to leaked discord messages that didn't have anything to do with the game, and they started to attempt to crack down on toxicity by reducing the ability of players to disrupt PvE quests. Exploiters and bug abusers have rampantly and openly ruined the game for many, and there are free downloads for unpatched cheats that work right now just one google search away. Hacked clients are cheap and easy subscription services and the game has no functional anti-cheat which has stopped this from happening. Almost everyone in the past 2 years has been playing with ESP, with the most popular free ESP having millions of downloads in its lifetime. The cross-platforming was quickly an issue due to the advantages PC players have over Xbox players. Double gunning was toxic and had no counterplay. Hitreg is still in the game 6 years after release and the promises to fix it. It's actually gotten worse because hitreg now happens with the sword as well. You can evade bans and avoid chat filter just by adding an extra letter to any slur of your choice, perma bans are issued for disrupting alliance server discords if you raid their server through discord. It is not fair to allow players free progression through organized discord groups that rig lobbies and bully independent players out of the lobby. These alliance servers will enter a lobby from a discord and team up on 1 or 2 ships with 4 or 5 of their own, and again, Rare will permanently ban your account if you start a rebellion from inside the discord. I have raided alliance servers with friends just to have them banned, even though I found the server myself in-game, we joined the discord to play along for a while and that apparently was a ToS violation. Arena was a dead game mode that only assisted in creating a larger skill disparity between PvP and PvE players, it was removed well past its expiration date. The introduction of private servers, PvE quests that cannot be disrupted, micro transactions which were promised never to occur at launch, and massive banwaves to PvP players completely tanked all of the fun this game had to offer.

Chain shots ruined an entire meta of ramming and boarding enemies. It is impossible to get near a ship when a player can just chain shot masts when you head directly toward them. The diversity for how you engaged in combat used to be fun, but now its devolved to long circling and hitting chain shots. The first chain shot hit typically determines the fight. You could always maneuver away from situations you didnt like, and you could still slow down enemies with cannons to the hull, because water in your hull slows you. The sword buffs and cc chaining you can do today are just as bad as double gunning, there is hardly counterplay if you try to engage in a swordfight and get hitreg to be stunlocked to death due to poor latency. Boarding ships is impossible because the sound cues or widespread ESPing give you away instantly. Ironically, had the developers never added chain shots, most PvE players would likely have nothing to complain about given they could run from any interaction they didnt like. Island camping someones dig spot has always been an intuitive strategy to steal treasure from PvE questers, and the people questing could just abandon it and do another quest, or bait with different ideas regarding treasure turn-in. Speaking of questing, unless you are grinding explicitly for commendations, quests are so inefficient compared to world events. World events have a power creep factor that makes quests obsolete for money generation. Which leads to my next point...

Server hopping has destroyed the integrity of servers and makes the game extremely unenjoyable. No matter if you are the one server hopping or the one running R5 world events that has to deal with constant hoppers trying to sink you, its annoying to have 0 interaction gameplay for an hour only to finally find a gem server worth staying on. Ask any experienced PvP player and they will tell you they have spent hours hopping daily just to find an abandoned FOTD, or an R5 that runs away and turns everything in the moment they see you raise emissary. The PvPers hopping to find something worth stealing or sinking just want interaction thats worth their time, because 90% of players running anything but world event reapers or fort stacking are doing some obscure commendations quest in the devils roar with merchant emi raised. These players will run on sight, likely on sloop and against wind, making it pointless. The devs attempted to solve this by creating hourglass, which is honestly the best update the game has had in years. If they had introduced hourglass in 2019 instead of arena, the community would likely have went a different direction with their disposition toward PvP players. The problem of server hopping still remains due to lack of steady world event content. Events should attract players and not feel like a burden, because every PvE player doing world events feels like they have a target on their back and are just waiting to be sank. 

TLDR dont buy bad devs

I previously left a negative review long after I stopped playing and gave up hope that they'd improve the game for a community firmly divided between preferring its PvE or PvP content, because my sea of thieves experience had devolved into running the same few missions ad infinitum to gain rep while occasionally happening across other ships so nooby they put up no fight and had no loot to plunder.

I have returned nearly 2 years later and in the last week I've stolen another guy's entire ship to offload his loot onto mine, I've had a 4-manned Galleon roll up and blast me to pieces with an hour's work of treasure in my hold, and I've boarded one enemy player ship, killed its captain, hopped on its cannons [i] and blasted a second enemy player ship as the first sunk beneath my feet. [/i]

I credit all this to the addition of the Safer Seas queue for children/casuals/dedicated PvE players. Everyone I've come across can actually put up a fight now, instead of all of us being separated out because our server slots are being taken up by a flotilla of sloops with white sails and no ability to defend themselves.

So pick it up if you're interested, because Rare has absolutely delivered the premise: big open world exploration with treasure around every corner and some of the best organic, if somewhat mechanically simple, world PvP I've ever played.

Update: Now that Safer Seas has been out for a while I think it's fair to say that many people within the community are disappointed. For a lot of us Safer Seas was a lifeline for this game. Many of us were holding onto the hope that we could finally enjoy the game but I haven't wanted to play SoT since Safer Seas released. With no real reward for grinding, not being able to use your own ships, not being able to co-op with other friendly pirates and being extremely limited on what you can and cant do ruins any fun aspects that the game had left. 

I only started playing at the beginning of season 10, I obsessed over this game until Safer Seas released only because I was counting on the fact Safer Seas would be better and more enjoyable gameplay for someone like myself. I can't even bring myself to log into the game anymore as it as tremendously boring. While I enjoyed my time on the high seas, pvp its not something that I want do all the time and I think players should be able to enjoy Sea of Thieves in both peaceful and pvp settings. Almost all other games have some form of PVE or Non-Friendly fire servers. 

I hope that as Safer Seas ages, changes are made to include the "peaceful" community.



Original Review: My younger sister has been playing SoT on and off for years now. She finally convinced me to purchase the game a few weeks ago. Since I've played for over 100 hours, reached Pirate Legend and have really enjoyed my voyages on the seas. The game is filled with content and things to do, beautiful places and in depth stories but actually enjoying the story and PVE aspects of SoT is almost impossible.

Not knowing the tricks and tips that the well versed community have access too as a new player can make the game seem impossible to play, I was shocked that the servers were not skill or level based match making. Because of this it is somewhat annoying that you cant have private servers or even just PVE servers.

While I understand where some of the concerns come from within the 'pro pvp' community of SoT, I do not see how adding a PVE side to the game would hurt SoT. If anything, I think it would make the PVP aspect better by filtering out the players who are sailing to enjoy the lore and don't want to involve themselves in the PVP aspect (which is totally valid and okay).

As a new player I really don't think I'd recommend getting this game to others. It is hard to get into without help, especially if many of the players sharing your servers do not respect the "Pirate Code", the toxicity that some of these seasoned players show is disheartening and unwelcoming to newcomers. While I have met a handful of fun and nice players over the last few weeks the bad experiences overshadow the good ones.

I hope that with Safer Seas being implemented we will see more changes for PVE players and in general a more enjoyable experience for everyone.

- Speaking of teamwork, you're gonna need to get good at that to succeed.
- Graphics are nice, mainly the colors.
- Most of all, try not to get too invested. Things can go south quick, and nothing is fun if you let the inevitable trash talkers get to you.

Like so many others I was given false hope when Rare announced the non pvp mode. What could have been the key feature to bring players (back) into this game, is instead almost an insult. 
 The limitations to safer seas are just frankly obnoxious and show what almost feels like contempt for pve/co-op players: Reduced rewards one can almost stomach (it's still the wrong way to do it. Carrot vs stick. Instead of punishing pve players, reward pvp players with pvp specific rewards like taunts, finishers etc, things that do not matter in pve anyway), but the caps, lack of features, not being able to use guilds, captained ships etc are not ok.

how it was all worded also makes it feel like these devs consider safer seas a "training" mode before moving on into the "real" game. The problem is that high seas isn't the fun risk/reward balance MS/Rare's PR tries to make it out to be. Where crews compete for loot, queue up for pvp battles, or take a well calculated risk grabbing that reaper's chest (You really should warn new players on what picking one of those does btw.) 

What you instead get is a near endless stream of pure trolls/griefers. Most of them do not give a toss about the loot, or if you have anything at all. All this type wants to do is kill, sink, troll, and grief others. Doesn't matter if it's a new player, an empty/freshly spawned ship, or someone hunting for pigs. More often than not any loot that was onboard is left behind to sink, and any living cargo is thrown into the sea to die. 
In the months I've played during my free included game pass time I ran into exactly 4 other players that didn't go out of their way to try and sink our ship for no reason. It was in fact so rare an occurrence we kept track.

The fact there is no mechanism to deal with this shows it is semi as intended. There is no realistic way to report another player/crew for just lousy behaviour apart from when they straight break xbox terms of service for abuse. There is no auto matchmaking that puts these types together. There is no real risk to being a troll/killer. There are no ai pirate hunters that come after you, and there are no *safe* zones either (Something even proto mmos from the 90's had.) There isn't even a single "freeport" newbie/low risk outpost with ai defenses and town guards. 

The balance is also borked: The smallest ship should allow up to 3 or 4 players, the medium up to 6, and the largest size 8 or even 10. Not having a 2nd battery of guns on the large ships is just as silly. The gun ports are visible, but not used. Even if you just moved two on each side down a level would already be something. If you want risk reward then make it so you have to manually open and close the gun ports, and sailing with ports open means you slowly take in water from waves just like when it rains. You cannot hire ai crew/defenses, nor does your ship come with any. So between the lack of real broadside advantage, and it being absurdly easy to just board another ship and blow it up, you're actually at a disadvantage in some ways for sailing the larger ships. 
There also isn't any real easy convoying, and there certainly isn't any option to have your own instance unless you're one of the special cases.

There is no sense of progression either: Sure, when you go into the actual pvp battles have players use fixed loadouts, but in the "open" part allow more freedom. Let players tinker with their ships, offer some variety in weapons, and get a non busted rifle scope etc. There are camps and forts, but you cannot do anything with these either. Guilds are also at present beyond basic: There are no special guild ship types, no guild bases, special weapons. They are just glorified pvp teams. 

So the short version is: As it is right now, don't bother buying this game unless you enjoy trolling or dealing with trolls. The question isn't "if", but "when" someone comes along to ruin your fun, every single time. Even then do yourself a favour and just disable all chat from the start, unless your idea of a good time is some profane 12 year old shrieking into your ears. 
 If you want to pvp with your mates, also avoid. There just isn't any easy way to set up a private instance to go at it together with multiple crews.
 If you like pve/co-op just avoid for now. Safer seas isn't what you'd hope for, and frankly there also isn't enough actual pve content to make it worth the price. If you want to check it out or do the tall tales just get a game pass trial. You'll be done before that trial runs out.

If you enjoy PvP, this isn't your game. Their servers are so bad that very nearly every fight will be an infuriating lagfest where you are fighting the game more than the players. Rubberbanding, interactables not interacting, hits not registering, long loading screens where there shouldn't be... its bad. That doesn't tend to be as much of an issue when you aren't around other players, but...
If you enjoy PvE, this isn't your game. People in the PvP servers will randomly murder you for the fun of griefing you, and delete your progress. They just introduced a PvE only mode to the game, but arbitrarily limited it and capped the levels because they consider it more like an extended tutorial rather than a full-fledged game mode, and you are supposed to move over to their regular PvP servers once you have an idea of what you are doing. See above as to why you wouldn't want to do that.

Edit: I've spent another 3 days of my life in his game, trying to eek out some fun between the shit servers and toxic PvP and I'm just actually uninstalling it now. Maybe some day, but not today.

Check back in on this game around mid 2024 and see if they have uncapped the PvE game mode or made progress on making their servers actually functional. Until one or both of those things happen, I don't really recommend paying money for this game. It is a cool game, and it can be a lot of fun. However, it is not in a good place and has a way of erasing any fun you might manage to have and making you rage alt-F4.

What's fascinating about Sea of Thieves is that you never know what's going to happen during the game session. In particular, the unpredictability of other players' behaviour adds a lot of variation. Sometimes they will chase you, sometimes they will steer clear of you, and sometimes they will be friendly. The most impressive element of the game are the waves which are not only very beautiful but also affect to visibility. 

[b]Likes[/b]
[list]
[*]the beautiful waves
[*]beautiful and highly optimized graphics
[*]day cycle, fog, storms
[*]music and sound effects
[*]ship appearance customisation options
[*]unpredictability of what is going to happen during the session
[*]horizontal progression
[*]on-going game development
[/list]

[b]Wishes[/b]
[list]
[*]new waters with new islands and new tall tales (Pirate Legend exclusive, maybe?)
[*]reduced clutter (event indicators in the sky and on the ship)
[*]bug fixes to tell tales and voyages (especially the wrecks)
[*]support for pee breaks! (in other words, a non-risky way to have interruptions during the long sessions)
[*]open crew matchmaking (age, experience, goals, etc.)
[*]more fish variety
[*]mooring without an anchor should cause slow drifting
[*]native Linux support
[/list]

EDIT: I had about 10 hours logged when I first gave this review back in 2021. Captain Jack Sparrow had just hit the seas, we were introduced to Forts of Fortune and Sunken Treasuries/Shrines, and PVE just got a big update, along with many other things. As of now I currently have almost 300 hours into this game, and I can comfortably say that this is one of my favorite games to play of all time.

To put it simply, this game is very much based on the multiplayer aspect. That's why PVP servers exist; you're not guaranteed to have a nice experience every time you log on, which is upsetting, but there is no honor among thieves. The game has something for all levels of play to enjoy, and now with the addition of Safer Seas, those who wish to simply play the barebones of the game for what it's worth have the option to do so without getting spawnkilled or followed by opposing player ships, albeit that luxury comes with a price. 70% reduced gold overall is the main takeaway, as well as not being able to sail emissary ships, captained ships, and a number of other things.

If you are looking for a true pirate experience, for all that it is worth, INCLUDING all of the hard labor and the fear that comes with losing it, please give this game a try. Safer Seas is nice, but new players will often fall into the trap that the gamemodes are similar and that you will easily be able to transfer skills that you learn in Safer Seas over into High Seas. Learning the hard way how the game works, how people behave, and how to protect yourself is the best way that one can learn.

I recommend this game for all levels of play. There are times when I see some ship names or see behavior from other ships that I do not condone, namely some of the more hate-crime-esque stuff, but overall I can't say that I've uninstalled this game over anything.

Navigating the open world seas, exploring diverse islands, forts, and underwater ruins is a delight, with countless treasures and challenges to discover. But, in recent updates, there is an option you can use to sail in "safer seas" with a few features and game mechanics not available in this game mode.

As you can see by my hours, I tried my best to stay involved with this game for a very long time. Probably the one game I've ever poured the most time into ever, maybe the second highest. Joined servers, pursued creative projects, became attached to my character, tried my hand at every aspect of the game there was. Looking back after all this time, I'm really not sure why I did it. Gameplay is repetitive, grindy, and mostly unengaging. PvP is frustrating whether you win or lose. Community is constantly in conflict with itself. Devs are money-hungry and consistently fail to give the fans what they want, even if some of them are trying their hardest. No matter what you do, you don't win.

Is there anything left for me in this game? No. Is my view pessimistic? Yes. Did I play the game wrong? Probably.

Don't touch this game for your own sake. It's for the best.

I do enjoy concept of the game but pity much every player is a aggressive player so there are not many who are friendly and who wont try sink your ship, Match making is rally bad as solo i always seem to be found after about 10-15 mins of playing by a galleon or a brigantine with 3-4 players and always end up chasing me no stop to sinking me, makes some of the other commissions almost impossible to do unless you have a group of friends to also play with, can be a pain for those who don't have much time to play the game and learn stuff like myself, I had this problem and ended up  stopping playing the game for over a year, each time i played i spent maybe 2h - 4h trying to learning and trying to doing a voyage or just learning how to sail, the huge pain for me was each server i join always seems to have gallons and brigantines, with few sloops but all i met were all teams so as solo i had no chance, i had 28h + game play time and pretty much no progress or money, all voyages i had tried but 1 i had to abandon due to aggressive players as most will just chase you till they can sink you even if some have to chase you for over 1 hour.
Would be nice if we could maybe choose to be in a session with just other sloops or if we want bigger ships as well to have a balance choice for those who play solo, or maybe even a choice for lobby with just players who want to solo sloop.
I have played a fair bit more now and have finally had some better sessions with less aggressive players, now over 200h game play and have had a few non aggressive players and some fun and cool encounters to go with them.
Not many will even seem to bother with the alliance system in the game, after over 50h i didn't get to use it once, even with over 200h in game i manged to use the alliance system with a few crews but not many as still most crews play aggressive been a pirate game, i have managed to use the alliance system only 4 times, shame really as even the events were alliances benefit most like x2 gold and rep, almost all i have come across are aggressive and will just sink you.
Even worse when you find players who offer a alliance and you accept or for them to accept your alliance, just for them to back stab you as you pull up to the port to sell and they decide to attack and sink you while still in the alliance.

And for those who say but the hole point is been a pirate you loot each other, yes i agree and get that when on the sea, but you know ports should be a safer place you can sell especially when you sail too and dock up seeing no other ships are there, i was frustrated and annoyed to find out in a tip video that players can actually sink there own ships and stay in that area like wow, sinking your own ship and camping a port just to steal loot and troll players is just plain dirty and ruins the game and experience for a lot, i have had this happen a few times and when i say a few time i mean a fair few .... after about 24h game play in over about 2 weeks i had this happen 5 times, it was one of the other reasons i ended up quitting the game for over 2 year, at that point if i could have ask for a refund i would have gladly as most of my experience was ether frustration or annoyance with other players.
I hope something can be done about this, the Dev's should just make it so if you scuttle your ship near a port or at a port as soon as its re-spawned it should force re-spawn you to your ship if you are still near or still at a port.

Safer sea is now here and to be honest i was and am still disappointed with the outcome and hope some changes would still be made. Thankfully some changes have been made and maybe some more in the future as well. Even with safer sea's out i still sail more on the high seas but much happier now there is a way to learn stuff with out fear of other players. 
Some changes have been make like now even if your a pirate legend you can now buy voyages reduced to rank 40, This was a must and I am very happy they have fixed it.
The only thing safer seas seems to be good for is learning basics of the games and its mechanics, playing tall tails and most commendations uninterrupted by other players, i would still NOT recommend doing any voyages as a way of trying to earn gold in safer sea due to reductions and restrictions, you can not use the sovereigns as well so if you are solo, selling your loot can take a long time as you have to carry it from your ship around the island to each tent and is not really worth the time or effort because of reductions. I would Only recommend to do a voyage on safer seas if you do not know it and maybe want to learn it safely, or maybe just want commendations uninterrupted by other player.
The reduction IS STILL 70% leaving you just 30% gold and rep, it is way to steep especially as all gold is used for is some items that are still at 100% price cost NOT reduced for the 30%  reduction, like supplies and cosmetics, most seem to be so expensive, it would take days or weeks in safer seas to just get one of the cheaper sets especially a ship sets as the lower costing parts still cost around 70k each and up, making most ships sets cost almost 1mil gold, I think the 30% would be fine maybe if we could use the Sovereigns still but as we can not use them i disagree with the reduction.
Also they did not reduce the cost of supply's for ships or crates so a empty box alone still costs you 5000 gold, Most of the higher price loot is also removed and you also have to run around more just to sell your loot.
Removing the emissary boost seems fine to me and the other content like guilds content and the commodities supplies, but stopping the use of the sovereigns altogether just seems unfair, i know its our ship that allows us access to the sovereigns but i thought that the sovereigns were added to improve game play and the experience like a quality of life update, meaning you can spend a bit less time at a outpost doing a tedious task like selling loot and spend more time enjoying the game. Hopefully the Developers will allow us use of sovereigns at a later date, mainly just to be able to sell your loot to them is all that matters and its safer seas so why can we not use them, maybe allow us to use our ships so we can sell to them and disable the milestones and stuff still.

A lot of the player base wanted safer sea for a casual and stress free experience, or to learn the basics of the game as a lot you have to learn on your own like some of fighting mechanics, sailing plus more, some to play with family or friends.
I agree with a lot of the restriction on safer sea like all PVP related content been removed and guild related content, i also agree on the levels been reduced and capped.
I was also happy see how they left a lot of the open world event content in safer seas.

This was the result of a voyage i did when safer seas was reduced to 30%, sailing from one port to another and clearing some stuff on the way.
I sailed just over 2 hours on safer seas and kind of regret doing so, i did 1 fort, 1 sunken temple, 1 sunken treasury, killed 1 megladon, 1 skeleton sloop and 2 skeleton gallons, i agree it was a nice experience and enjoyed it until i reached the end of the voyage, reaching the port was fine but then finding out and noticing, with NOT been able to use the sovereigns it soon became hell i was super tiered from work and the voyage, and wasn't to happy as it took me around 30 mins to take all the loot off my ship and sell it, after all that work due to the reduction all i got was around 23000 gold, but I also lost 5000 gold by buying a empty supple box at the start for gathering supplies.
Without fully testing i can not say if hunters call will even be worth doing on safer seas due to the reductions, maybe for the commendations but for the rep probably not as you gain such low amount anyway in high seas, to reduce it to 30% would probably give you next to nothing still.

Hopefully you aren't late to the party because this game is almost impossible for new users to enjoy. The instructions on what you're supposed to be doing are ridiculously unclear, leaving you to fend for yourself for the first couple hours. Gather round! Sit down.. and have a swig of rum as this ol' dog of a pirate paints ye a tale of the great blue beyond! With over 1,000 hours sailing the high seas, this captain has a few things to tell ye poor landlubbers about yer inquiry into whether ye have the grit and gumption to become a pirate lord and legend.. or just an unheard of washed up turd, upon the banks of Chicken Isle. 

One thing ye must learn and ye must learn quickly my young pirate protege.. is that ye must never hold on to yer treasure too tightly. Now.. don't get me wrong,  ye want to defend yer booty with every ounce of courage and battle brave bravado ye can muster.. lest yer booty be plundered by some drooling dollard licking their lips as they parade their piratey hands upon it! But be forewarned.. Many a cowardly cohort with tail tucked between legs has gone awash in the glow of galleon fire and become cannon fodder not only on the sea, but in the ocean of their mind!

Ye must understand that to win a battle is something that is hard won with time, practice and patience. Ye don't go becoming a pirate legend in a day lad! And sometimes the battle of the mind is the fiercest one with what ye must contend! The sea rewards those who spend time with her, learning her ways.. just like the ways of yer vessel.. not to mention the ways of combat and cunning, of which you'll need both! But sometimes winning is realizing when you've lost.. and to carry on.. head held high, knowing next time.. you'll get those greedy and grimey gobshite grabbers that took yer loot with a fierce and fiery vengeance and nothing to lose! 

The only advantage an old pirate has in this world besides some fancy threads or livery is understanding. With time comes knowledge, and with knowledge.. understanding.. understanding when to make friend and when to make holes! Ye may wonder when trying to make friends as a young captain, why so many seem to run away in sheer terror at yer seemingly friendly advances.. Well all I can say is that you'll learn young sailor. My advice is to meet adversity head on and with a calm and keen head on yer shoulders, to meet those that would be hailed as  advocates with an open heart.. but a watchful eye! After all.. this is the Sea of Thieves, not Sea of Friends! 

And last of all, the adventures that await ye both in terms of what the sea and islands have to offer, as well as the encounters ye may or may not have seeing other pirate players on any given voyage.. will shape the game in unknown and unexpected ways almost every time. Ye must be ready for anything! or.. not much at all.

One final noteworthy mention.. it's much better to sail with a crew, even if that crew must be chosen over time from yer maiden voyages.. sailing with random slobbering rum drinking drivel until ye find a trustworthy first mate and quartermaster. Sailing the seas alone is a nasty business, although some lone and desperate souls may prefer it. Regardless, I wish ye all fair winds and following seas my hopeful pirate pals!

It's a pretty boring game even when playing with friends. Fighting system is basic with no upgradable moves/skills. There are only like 6 weapons without any upgrades. The only things you can buy for them are skins. So basically all that money you collect you can only spend on weapons/ship skins. Map of game is huge, which is not a problem, but when the only things you can buy for in-game currency are skins, there is not much motivation for pursuing quests on the other end of map. If you value your money and time dont buy this game.

Un buen simulador de piratas, diría que no es el mejor, pero si el mejor de los existentes. El estilo artístico queda muy bien con el juego pero el máximo protagonista es el mar. Las texturas (o como se diga) del agua son increíbles aun estando en bajo o medio, y para el año que salió lo fueron aún mas. Se vuelve algo repetitivo conforme pases las 20 o 30 horas, pero no necesariamente aburrido o depende de tus gustos. Eso si, vas a estar navegando la mayor parte del tiempo, pero esta es la parte chill del juego diría yo, claro que cuando te ataca algo en el agua o sale un evento del mapa te interrumpen la calma. RARE lo esta mejorando, aunque ahora un poco más lento que hace unos años, pero es importante mencionar que no dropean el juego y siguen metiendo contenido por temporadas.

Don't get fooled by 18 hours. I have at least 500-600 on Xbox where I played the game since day one until I got anxiety from thieves. Might sound funny, but you know when you work hard for hours at a time to get loot and the game gives you no recognition for it unless you deliver it to the proper destination of course you will shit your pants when you see the player ship on horizon. I can maneuver my sloop pretty good and escape faster ships against the wind, but running away can easily turn into a multi-hour anxiety-inducing horror gameplay. Keep that in mind. However, the sea without thieves that was introduced last month, 5 years after game release, might just give me an opportunity to catch all the fish I was never been able to while I was constantly watching over my shoulder.

To be completely honest, Sea of Thieves is PROBABLY my favorite video game of all times. I wholeheartedly recommend it!

If you are a new player and if you are into story content there is at least a 100-200 hours of stuff for you. Enter calm seas or whatever they call it now and start Sea of thieves lore first. It's a nine-chapter cool little saga that will introduce you to this world's characters.

Then go through Pirates of the Caribbean story and finally the Monkey Island story-line. For Caribbean I recommend playing co-op, but for Monkey Island I recommend puzzling solo.

Once you are done with all of it I recommend dipping your toes into actual Sea of Thieves. Test if you can handle other players and go from there. If not, it was a 40€ well worth it. If you end up liking it kudos for you and see you on the high seas!

All goes according to plan until I get molly whopped with "confirm you're email with a code" type of trickery. 🏴‍☠️ Pirate Life with Friends: Unmatched!
"Sea of Thieves" truly shines when sailing with friends. Its cooperative gameplay is not just fun but deeply immersive. Whether you're forming a crew with friends or joining forces with strangers, every voyage is a unique adventure. The camaraderie and shared experiences elevate this game to new heights, making it a top pick for multiplayer enthusiasts.

🎨 Stylized Graphics That Never Age:
The game's vibrant, cartoonish graphics are a visual feast. Each character is distinctively designed, and the play of light and shadows across the seas and islands is simply breathtaking. This stylized approach ensures that the game remains visually appealing, no matter how much time passes.

🌊 Ever-Evolving Content:
Since its launch, "Sea of Thieves" has continuously evolved. What began with some criticisms about content variety has transformed into a rich, content-packed world. Regular updates bring in new PvP features, storylines, and live events, keeping the game fresh and exciting. The 2023 edition, commemorating five years of piracy and adventure, is a testament to the game's dynamic and engaging development.

⚔️ Adventures Galore in an Open World:
Live your pirate dreams in a vast open world filled with thrilling battles, treacherous voyages, and encounters with both allies and adversaries. The game offers a perfect blend of risk and reward, ensuring that no two journeys are the same.

🔍 In Summary:
"Sea of Thieves" is more than just a game; it's an ever-expanding universe of piracy and high-sea adventures. Its ability to bring friends together for shared stories and swashbuckling fun, combined with its visually stunning and ageless graphics, makes it a top choice for gamers looking for an immersive, evolving multiplayer experience. Whether you're a seasoned buccaneer or a landlubber looking to set sail for the first time, "Sea of Thieves" promises an adventure like no other. All aboard for a journey filled with piracy, camaraderie, and endless sea tales!

⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐
Highly recommended for: Adventure lovers, Multiplayer fans, Aesthetic graphics enthusiasts, and Anyone dreaming of a pirate's life!

"Sea of Thieves: True Pirate Adventure"

"Sea of Thieves" is a captivating and unique multiplayer adventure that redefines the pirate experience in video games. Developed by Rare, this game is a masterful blend of exploration, combat, and teamwork, set in a breathtakingly beautiful and ever-changing world. It's not just a game; it's an invitation to embark on an unforgettable voyage filled with wonder, danger, and treasure.

The first thing that strikes you in "Sea of Thieves" is its stunning visual aesthetic. The game boasts a whimsical, stylized art style that's both charming and immersive. The ocean, a central character in its own right, is rendered with astonishing beauty – from calm, crystal-clear waters to raging, storm-tossed waves, it provides a dynamic backdrop to every adventure. The islands you explore are diverse and teeming with secrets, from lush jungles to desolate, treasure-laden shores.

Gameplay in "Sea of Thieves" is as varied as the seas themselves. Players can choose to follow treasure maps to hidden riches, hunt down fearsome skeleton captains, or engage in epic naval battles against other players. The ship-to-ship combat is thrilling, requiring coordination and skill as you manage your vessel's sails, cannons, and repairs. The thrill of outmaneuvering and outgunning an opposing crew is unmatched.

One of the game's greatest strengths is its emphasis on cooperative play. Sailing a ship requires teamwork, communication, and a shared sense of purpose. Whether you're navigating through a storm, fighting off sea monsters, or dividing the spoils of a hard-won treasure, the game fosters a sense of camaraderie that's rare in online gaming. It's a game that's best enjoyed with friends, where each session brings new stories and laughter.

The world of "Sea of Thieves" is also constantly evolving. Regular updates and seasonal content keep the game fresh and exciting, adding new features, quests, and challenges. The developer's commitment to the community and to the continuous improvement of the game is evident.

Moreover, "Sea of Thieves" isn't just about combat and treasure hunting. It's a playground for the imagination. Players can indulge in more peaceful pursuits like fishing, playing musical instruments, or simply enjoying a sunset on the open sea. The game's open-ended nature encourages players to create their own adventures and stories.

In conclusion, "Sea of Thieves" is a triumph of game design, art, and storytelling. It offers a unique blend of adventure, teamwork, and freedom that's both refreshing and deeply engaging. Whether you're a seasoned sailor or setting foot on a ship's deck for the first time, "Sea of Thieves" promises an adventure like no other, full of moments that will stay with you long after you've set anchor.

I don't normally review games because I don't see much point in it. Most times people will find gameplay and other types of media depicting the game of their choice and see if they want it. Now that being said this game is extremely misleading as of late. 

Safe Seas was introduced to allow players to play the PvE aspect of the game, but removes Athena's Fortune, emissaries, captained ships, and guild ships. None of which are PVP content. It removes most the items that also allow to gain the more premium currency. Add onto all of that, your money gain gets kneecapped and drops down to 30%. So  a red mermaid gem, which sells for 2k on HS without emissary, 8k with emissary gets drops down to 600. So basically SS is there to waste your time and effort you put into farming if that is what you enjoy about the game.

High Seas on the other hand can be enjoyable, but not often. The community that has been built around this game is extremely toxic, to the point I have ended up deleting the game and I know for a fact I am not the only one. The PvP addicts are legitimate bullies when it comes down to it, with no repercussions to any of their actions. So they can load the game up, spawn in and chase someone down who's been playing for a few hours. Then if they lose that fight they spawn 2 islands over and head right back until either the other crew sinks or quits. Then besides all of that, there's an "open crew" setting to fill up your ship, but what they don't tell you is most times you have to worry about the trolls of the game who join ships just to sink them and waste all the resources one the ship. But here's the best part, if you call the toxic people out or happen to point out the fact that the game is PvEvP and not PvPvE they get upset and start name calling, insulting intelligence, assuming viewpoints, and attacking the person that disagrees with them. It's sad to see especially considering this game had a perfect example of what NOT to do from Destiny and proceeded to follow directly in it's footsteps anyways.

It's a great sandbox game with a fantastic core gameplay-loop of sailing around collecting treasure, and returning to town to rake in the gold. The cartoon-y art style of the game makes it feel cute and light-hearted without sacrificing the actual beauty of the tropical environment.

All of the mechanics FEEL great. Swimming feels refreshing, lowering the sails and hoisting the anchor makes it feel like I'm actually sailing this ship. The combat is bare-bones, but well executed. There's no mini-map, so navigating the seas and using your compass to traverse the island really do pay off when you hear that satisfying wooden *thunk* of a treasure chest beneath your shovel. Sea of Thieves gives you exactly the tools you need to operate in its world, and then steps back to allow you to play with them as you see fit.

One of my first online games growing up in the 2000's was Pirates of the Caribbean Online, and Sea of Thieves feels like everything I loved about that game, with all the bad stuff removed, and the systems overall improved upon for modern gaming. It's fantastic.

Listen y'all.  It's 2023.  If you haven't played this game yet, let me give this a shot here.

If you like the romance of the idea of "pirates", this is for you.

For my 80's babies/90's kids (i.e., you played Banjo Kazooie), Rare's classic "goofy" style shines through as a love letter to the tropes of piracy.  Will you get robbed and rethink your hours spent?  If you play long enough almost certainly.  But on the other hand...can you drink grog until you pass out, and also play instruments while sailing on what is still a breathtaking environment?  Also yes.

If you don't like pirates, don't envision/dream about sailing; you won't like it, simple as that.

If those things intrigue you, it's a great sandbox to get lost in.  Set sail, have fun.

SAFER SEAS IS THE BEES KNEES
I have always wanted to experience this beautiful game, but I have no patience for being harassed and put into PVP that I am not actively consenting to while trying to enjoy an otherwise incredible game. Safer Seas is exactly what I wanted. There's still danger, there's still threats, and it is so much fun to be jumped by skeleton pirates or a massive shark while boating around and scooping up loot off of meticulously crafted islands.
The story of the Sea of Thieves, the history of Flameheart and Merrick, and all of the lore and faction stuff is actually pretty interesting, and I love uncovering it bit by bit. Which reminds me - Quest design. This game has the *best* quest design I have ever experienced. You will often be given the name of an island, sometimes not even that, and have to figure out riddles and keep a keen eye out for markers to guide you to the loot and the story. I have not looked up *anything*, even when I felt stuck, and with enough chin-scratching and experimentation, the game has provided so many Eureka! moments. No minimap, no HUD markers to guide you, just your map, your compass, the waves, and the wind.
I will never go back to the frustrations of PVP - I have found the seafaring life for me. Grab a matey or three, and see what you have been missing. Long Live Safer Seas!
ship goes brrr
10/10 amezimg

I'll start this by saying there is a lot to like with this game. The core mechanics of sailing around looking for treasure, doing quests, playing a pirate story, etc. are all pretty well done. Still, after giving it solid try for about 50 hours, I can't recommend this game.

There are a few core play modes: Hourglass PvP, High Seas, Tall Tales, and the New Safer Seas.  Hourglass is the one I played least, and seemed filled with botters, exploits and toxicity. High Seas has the most potential, but is frequently ruined by the fact that its always PvP and lets vastly more experienced players ruin the fun for newer players; if you play the game for more than an hour or 2, you're likely to have someone kill you and take all your loot. If you play a short time, that might still happen, and even if it doesn't you'll get very little accomplished, since so many things in the game take a long play session to do. The Tall Tales are fine, but the ones I tried play very different from the regular game modes. I had a lot of hope for the new "Safer Seas" mode meant for solo or new players, but it is just not fun  for 2 reasons: First, significant portions of the game, such as emissary flags, are not available in this mode; the  treasure you find is worth the same value, but you will only get 30% of what you find. Picking up a bag of gold at a hard won ghost fort and getting 11 gold pieces is so discouraging,  that it made me question why I was even doing it. Second, while it doesn't seem to have been advertised much, this mode seems to come with AI opponents deliberately coded to wait till you have a decent amount of loot on your boat who will then spawn literally right next to you, are practically unsinkable using cannons, and who will chase you around the map even more than the sweatiest of actual humans, then camp over the loot you dropped when you sink. In other words, its seems that some AI was added to simulate (in SAFER SEAS) the worst toxicity of actual humans in the High Seas mode. 

So, again, the game has some nice ideas and systems, but the developers seem to actively want to make and bolster a game intended for toxic players. After the way the "Safer Seas" mode was handled and implemented, I am completely done with this game.

Half the negative reviews are just skill issue. The game has no p2w or unlockable PVP advantages, if you get sunk in this game, that's probably because you didn't play as good as your enemies did (with very few exceptions such as if it's a 2v1 sloop fight), and if you loose your loot, it doesn't really matter, because all you can do with loot is buying cosmetics and leveling your factions (which only unlocks new voyages and cosmetics) so it doesn't even matter that much if you loose your loot. Also, not everyone you see on the seas is going to sink you on sight, majority of other crews are actually willing to cooperate with you if you just use your mic to talk to them about forming an alliance etc, if you don't communicate then what do you expect? You can play the game solo (I did my first 300 hours) and it works okay, but it's more fun if you do it with minimum one other person (There is open crew or discords for finding friends to play with).

That being said there are a few issues with the game, for example that it's very grindy to unlock certain cosmetics and that you can end up spending a lot of time traveling between points of interests

Overall a very good game, don't let the negative reviews about how toxic the community scare you too much, sure some people can be toxic, but it's not a rule of thumb. However if you come here in hopes of this being a big role play game with the iconic "Are you the Spanish?" interactions happening left and right then yeah, that's not too common in this game.

i absolutely love this game. though it has a steep learning curve, sea of thieves is a extremely fun game too play and would highly recommend it. therefore i have made a list of pros and cons:

pros:
 -fun with friends and easy to make some
-extremely pretty graphics 
-lots of places to explore 
- exciting world events
-challenging bosses that are satisfiying to beat
-lots of roleplay ability if your into that stuff
-game's got lots of ship and character customization
-exciting pvp & pve (in my opinion)
-pretty waves

cons:

-some people can be toxic and offensive
-i guess if you have Thalassophobia this game might be a bit scary
-pvp/pve battles dont last that long (they usually end with 1 ship getting sunk really fast or the other ship fleeing)
- ancient coins are quite hard to get so you will probably end up buying some
-the pirate emporium is expensive
-game's got occasional bugs but they arent that bad
-sometimes crewmembers are a bit of a pill such as standing infront of you when steering the ship or wasting all the food or sabatoge your ship by setting it on fire. but dont worry youre crew can vote to lock them in the brig.

so far i would rate the game a 9.5/10

BE WARNED: some people on the game can be extremely rude and/or offensive as iv said before so if they are being rude dont take anything that they say to heart and ignore them.

I'm a pirate!

- The PvE servers are grind fests due to all the restrictions while PvP servers are no different since you don't keep your items after logging-out.

- Tall Tale quests are just compilations of fetch quests with Jack Sparrow being the only memorable part. Was expecting a full-fledged pirate game where I can rob and plunder NPC towns, but did not expect the equivalent of a Disney ride as a game.

- Graphics are good, I won't lie. The water physics are top-notch too in my opinion. But the content in this game does NOT justify 105 GB of storage space when games like No Man's Sky is only 15 GB total as of making this review.

- After a while, things become repetitive and the gameplay loop is not enough to keep my group playing.

If you haven't already been sucked in, [i]run now.[/i] 

Sea of Thieves is the posterchild for beautiful ideas soured by dodgy execution. I first played on gamepass some years ago, and left because a vocal minority of the community was (and is to this day) the kind of edgy rude child you might expect to meet in a Call of Duty game.

I recently came back to see if things have improved. They haven't.

That ever-vocal minority has been foaming at the mouth over the introduction of a very limited PvP-free mode. On top of that, I continue to encounter bugs and QoL issues that should've been fixed YEARS ago. The nail in the coffin is that my keybindings simply will not save between sessions.

It's a huge shame, because Sea of Thieves has always had immense potential, and has always been kneecapped by Rare's mismanagement. The ship driving mechanics are genuinely engaging as hell, the cosmetics are appealing (and I would sure hope they are, given they're most of what you're rewarded with in this game-- despite not being able to save your ship's cosmetic loadout unless you "earn" that privilege with in-game money.)

Rare has no idea what they're doing. I can only hope that someday someone makes a game that fills the niche Sea of Thieves falls short of year after year.

Detailed Review:

Controls: Not to bad. At first it might be confusing but you get used to it

Story: Great story. Does not get in the middle of the rest of the gameplay but is great and casual

Gameplay: A great game if you like to be a pirate. It does not limit you to doing a few things. you can be a peaceful pirate, a violent one, or somewhere in between. From the Gold Horders, Merchant Alliance, to the Reapers, there is a ton of content to be discovered and flexibility for all types of players!

Difficulty: Not too difficult. Depends on what you do in the game. There is no designated "difficulty settings" or anything like that cause its multiplayer

Cross-Platform: Great. Not much else to say here

PvP: Amazing and very emersive.

Community: Very toxic, a rare occasion to find a friendly pirate on the seas, but when you do its an incredibly fun experience, even if you are fighting for riches.

Updates: Recently have been slacking, updates like Skull of Siren Song and Guilds have been great, though the game can feel stale once you have done everything

Conclusion: If you are interested in pirates, epic adventures, amazing and emersive gameplay, and amazing story, then this is the game for you!

This game was like $40 and I have to pay to change my character from a fat guy to a decent character? Nah, I'm out. As fun as the game may be, the online aspect isn't always a good thing, even though safer seas exists, it's limited. max level from it is 40 and half the features are gone, but hey, no other annoying people that just want your loot. Just want to have fun on a quest? Well, too bad! unless the other players are half the sea away, you can't leave your ship alone! I would half recommend and half not recommend. Depends on what parts we're talking about. The game has an item shop as big as if were a free game, and no, you can't earn the shop currency, you have to buy it. Didn't like the character you picked at the beginning because you changed your mind? Well, you had better get going to your wallet! Why? I don't know. I thought people hated the item shop, but here we are. Also, if you don't have this game yet, make sure you have around 120 gigabytes of storage. Yup, that's literal. How? What am I downloading that's this much? With that kind of storage, you could have yourself 6 individual Genshin applications, or around 60 Minecrafts! 
It's insane, but as long as you have...
a bunch of friends
a lot of storage
a will to spend some
patience
and a decent PC, you should be alright! I don't meet much of that criteria, but I do have 2/3 people to play this with at least. Hope there aren't as many microtransactions, and cheers!

I have played the majority of my time in high seas with a group of close friends who would enjoy pvp every now and then. Recently when rare announced a pve mode I was excited because there are times id love to play this game but not have to deal with toxicity and rampant spawn camping from sweat players. I was shocked and annoyed to learn that the pve mode was gutted so much. If you buy this game wanting to play just pve I would strongly suggest finding a different game that involves pirates maybe try Assassins Creed Black Flag. Right now the pve game mode punishes you for even wanting a more chill experience by ONLY giving you 30% of the gold you would get if you were on high seas. Not only that but your reputation with factions is limited to lvl 40 not even letting you become a pirate legend on your own  if you wanted to. Oh and that really cool feature that lets you take your own ship into the game and customize it as its captain? Yeah that isnt available in safer seas either with no real good explanation other than Rare wanted to stick it to you that you would even want to play a pve mode. I don't hate PVP necessarily but I absolutely hate that I feel punished just because I want to play the game without other players chasing me down in their galleons and camping my island or outpost just to sink me repeatedly.

I hate the PVP aspect and want a good uncompromising PvE mode, nothing more.

Sea of Thieves is a great game! It doesn't matter if you play on your own, or with friends. On High Seas, or on Safer Seas. To fight, or to make friends. If you've been around since the beginning, or your new to the sea of thieves. Its an amazing game for all kinds of people! And even if some pirates are not as nice as others, you can still pick yourself back up and go on an adventure! If your looking for a story on the seas, then you can try the amazing Tall Tales and fight Davy Jones with Jack Sparrow! Looking for an intense fight against other players? Go vote for the hourglass PVP battles and fight for Gold and Glory! (And some rather spiffy UNDEAD looks.) Are you a looking for a cool pirate game to dig up treasure with your friends and family on? Go to Safer Seas and grab a Gold Horder quest and follow a map or riddle to treasures untold without the fear of another player coming out of there hiding spot with a gunpowder keg and taking it all! Even the in-game currency you can buy with real money has a few ways of getting some without spending a dime! So it doesn't matter if your fighting a skeleton, sailing for new lands, or fighting other players to get your hands on rare loot! Even just logging on to look at some cool clothes you bought and forgot to try on last play session, you can always have a good time. I highly recommend this game game and can never get enough of it. I hope you can have as good of a time as I have had and continue having on the sea. May many an ancient skeleton come your way.

[h1] 🏴‍☠️Sea of Thieves🏴‍☠️  [/h1]

[h2] 🎮 Gameplay: 10/10 [/h2]
Sailing, battling, and treasure hunting with friends create a dynamic and enjoyable pirate experience.

[h2] 📜 Quests: 10/10 [/h2]
Diverse challenges, from solving riddles to battling skeletons, keep gameplay engaging and fun.

[h2] 🔄 Replayability: 10/10 [/h2]
Ever-changing world, dynamic encounters, and unpredictable player interactions ensure each session feels unique.

[h2] 🎨 Graphics: 10/10 [/h2]
Stunning art style and graphics contribute to the game's charm and visually appealing world.

[h2] 💅 Skins: 10/10 [/h2]
Wide customization options for pirates and ships add a personal touch and showcase unique styles.

[h2] 👌 Simplicity: 10/10 [/h2]
Balanced accessibility and depth make it easy for new players to jump in while offering complexity for seasoned pirates.

[h2] 🕹️ Multiplayer: 10/10 [/h2]
Cooperative multiplayer enhances the overall experience, fostering camaraderie and shared adventures.

[h2] 🏆 Achievements: 10/10 [/h2]
Satisfying sense of accomplishment through various achievements encourages mastery of the pirate's life.

[h2] 🚫 Cheaters: 0/10 [/h2]
The absence of an effective anti-cheat system and reporting mechanism poses challenges and impacts fair gameplay.

poop

Sea of Thieves, A game that released back in 2018 where it was very pvp/pve based. It WAS a fun game back in early release days because there was nothing like it at that time and well there still isn't anything remotely close to it to this day.

I will say the thought process of the game is really cool, playing with friends is a lot of fun and meeting new ones along your "SoT" journey is and will forever be memorable.

BUT The game is utter dog water, The mechanics DO NOT WORK, Hit registration is the worst it has EVER been. The development team constantly shoots themselves on the foot by not listening to its core community or their "seasoned" players and only listen to players who barely have any hours in the game. They keep "fixing" (if you can even call it that) stuff that don't need fixing and in the process of that cause more issues in the game. (for example the quick swap weapon patch caused the combat in the game to be more clunky) This game is NOT worth 40 dollars I'd wait for it to be on sale and even when it is on sale I still think it's too much to pay for. 

This game is great when you have friends to play with sure but a polished turd is still a turd. The game is just on its last legs don't play this, Go invest your time in another game that is worth playing, Just my two cents.

- Lots to do, your adventure can get completely torn off the rails.
- Tall tales (story quests) are pretty interesting.
- Beautiful graphics.
- Lots of different forms of combat and voyages to appeal to whatever playstyle you like.
- Random sea monster spawns and world events to spice up the environment.
- Can mute other crews and use text or mic.
- Safer Seas allows for a private server experience with an income reduction on what gold you earn.
- Hourglass PvP allows you to queue up for PvP without searching for it.

Cons
-

- Super fun with friends.
- Limited to three ship types with ONLY cosmetic customization options.
- Community is about as piratey as you expect pirates to be. Racial slurs are to be expected.
- PvP can get long and drawn out in naval battles, especially if both crews are loaded with supplies. Many folks run away, and depending on your ship it can be impossible to catch up. (Hourglass is always an option, though)
- Guilds are really hard to level up if it's just you and a couple friends.
- Lag spikes, crashes, and glitches are fairly common, regardless of what you play on. This has been getting a little better with each patch.


TL;DR - Better with friends, lots to do, never know what you're getting into when you log in.

Even tho it gets stale playing it alone or with friends, from the first 200-300 hours you will have an awesome experience exploring the world and the game itself. Now the sad part is that the developers are focusing on bringing new players but not on keeping old ones. So after completeing everything the endgame is you sailing around and doing PvP or messing with other players.

I thoroughly enjoyed sitting in a pirate ship for 3 hours of my life and getting off of it to get treasure.  Would recommend this game to people who love to play games where you are a pirate.  

One way you would enjoy this game is if you had friends to play this thrilling, exciting, and adventurous video game.  By yourself the experience is very fun but sometimes it gets boring by yourself after playing for a while.  But with a friend or 2 or 3, the fun doesn't end! 

Another way you could enjoy this game is get like 3 friends and go in a huge ship and just blow up every single ship you see.  Which, in my opinion, can be very exciting.  You can also get good rewards because you can get very good treasures from blowing up these peoples ships.

A third way to enjoy this very fun and entertaining video game is by just playing it how you like to play it.  doing your own thing is the best thing you can do sometimes.  You can play the ways I just stated or you can enjoy playing it in whatever way you find fun.  Honestly, no one cares how you play this game.

In conclusion,  I have just said ways you could play this game and I have barely played this game or watched it, I haven't even played this game in a year because I deleted it after getting bored.

Amazing abince, feels great to play. However its all show, there is absolutely nothing meaningfull to do in this game. Loot has no value so there is no real fun in taking it from other players (games like rust give you a adrenaline rush if you get loot form others, here it is not the case). Would have been way more amazing if it was a survial game with base building or something to do other than boring pve missions. The weaponery and the combat system feels pretty bad, like mincraft but it has some depth to it at least. Especial melee combati is just awefull.

Here is what you do. You join a ship... the random instantly leaves once he sees you so you are solo or you wait/ join another ship till you find someone to play with. Then you do missions where you esentialy kill skeletons 5 shots a time, then you rush to the ammo crate to refill and you repeat this process 30 times. After defeating the boss you carry lootboxes for 10 minutes. You then drive to an outpost to sell them for gold, this allows you to buy skins. Thats about it.

The ship vs ship battels area mazing, very well made and a good mix of realism and simplification. Stearing a boat feels really good too. But there is zero progression, no guns to unlock, no ships to improve no characters to level in meaningfull ways.

Dont get mew worng the first 200 hours or so are funn, and playing it ocasionaly is funn too.
All in All: Great potential, but it is lacking substance. Probably a good game for a chilled round with the homies though.

Sea of Thieves stands out as one of the most enjoyable games I've ever played, and please allow me to explain why. For starters, this game's combination of Player versus Player (PvP) and Player versus Environment (PvE) elements outperforms any other I've played. While the journeys themselves are enjoyable, the real magic is found in the interactions with other players. The unpredictable nature of each session and the dynamic player-driven encounters create an immersive and thrilling environment. This aspect of Sea of Thieves truly distinguishes it, making it an exceptional and memorable gaming experience.

They've added Safer Seas, a PVE mode which addresses most complaints from the community.  It gives a good way to get used to the game for beginners, a method for doing story missions / Tall Tales, and also a way to play the game and enjoy the seas without the toxic PVP.  Also they have Monkey Island content.

This game is phenomenal and I love playing it, but it has a glaring issue with it that you can find out pretty fast by reading the Steam discussion posts.

The community of this game is obnoxiously toxic. You will find far more people who are going to trash talk you, chase you for more than 5 hours across the map, and find out where you spawned just to do it again for no good reason, than you will find relaxed players who just want to play some fun adventures and quests.

There are no options to only do PvE settings devoid of player combat. There are no options to avoid griefers. If you play this game, you will have to expect an experience like DayZ or Rust. You will have good experiences and meet friendly people, but they will be outnumbered by the extremely hostile players. Expect a similar social experience to something like Overwatch with the toxicity here.

Quite frankly, a game with such a toxic community is not something I can enjoy. I may love the game and how the ship sailing works, but it's far too toxic for me. It's supposed to be a cartoon pirate game, not a "try to convince little Timmy to off himself" game.


===EDIT===
They added a PvE mode. It's stupidly restrictive but it has already allowed me to enjoy the game again.

I play this game on and off periodically, when Safer Seas come out I gave that a shot. Come today 12/23/2023 I decided to see if High Seas is worth playing still. The last 3 times i have played this game, each session being over 3 hours long upwards of 6, has resulted me in getting nothing at the end of each session because when you try to do anything that isn't pvp, you get followed till the end of time even though you have nothing yet, AND if you do get onto an island where your quest takes you, you will be camped for when you bring the treasure back then they kill you, take your stuff and thats it. 

Yes, PvP is part of the game, and there is a time and a place for it. However, it is harder for you to play a tall tale than it is to PvP. I do not mind as there are commendations for PvP which will have its time and place, however, Safer Seas should not have a reduction or a restriction to what you can or can not do. You already have limited it to earning a max rep of 40, but now you don't allow for collections of items to be earned when PvP doesn't have anything to do with it. My point is the game now, because the player base has dropped so much is only PvP players, those who just want to relax and not stress about whether or not all their efforts are for nothing, has no place in this game. 

Remove the limitations on Safer Seas, and those who want to achievement hunt or like to have all commendations WILL come back to PvP. High Seas has become a land for just PvP as its quite literally impossible to do any of the tales without being chased for an hour. If you want to complain about players staying in Safer Seas and removing the fun out of the game because you can't kill people who don't want to die then just go play Team Death Match in COD, some people actually wanna have fun and play with their friends.

I'm going to be super critical. Hate me if you want. I think RARE lost a bet and had to make a game with no meaningful progression.  I get having a level playing field for PvP, but PvE? Skeleton crew ships have already got holes in them, but are harder to sink than a player operated galleon. 

With the exception of Strongholds and Ports, the map feels empty. Many places that would be neat to plunder outside of events are just vacant when there is no mission or event, and half the time are very vacant even during missions. Missions aren't exactly simple or remotely easy to follow unless you have a veteran player on your crew. Simple tasks like finding sunken ships manifest can become an endless toil if you don't stop at every island along the way to search in painful detail for clues. The only solid way to make a decent haul is to plunder strongholds. Its so easy, a solo player can handle it. Just park your ship on the low corner, wait for the phantoms to charge down in front of you and spam cannonballs till each wave is dead. Doing this clears the stronghold in about 5 minutes, then it takes another 10-20 to search the whole base and load up all the loot. 30-45 minutes worth of work and a solo player can net 35k gold. But my point is, its not fun. It's not interesting. 

Merchant delivery missions. ITS A DELIVERY, not an ACQUISITION and DELIVERY, so why the hell am I being given empty crates to go gather supplies? Never in the history of shipping companies, especially the pirate era, did the merchant say to the privateer "You're being paid to Deliver the macguffins, but I dont have them, you have to go to random desert islands and find them." Like how hard is that really to screw that up RARE? Are you imbeciles? Because playing this makes me think your entire dev team is imbeciles. I actually believe nobody in the dev raised their hand and said "But having no meaningful  progression is, like, insanely dumb." 

Whats worse is the player base. I'm NOT talking about Reapers. I'm talking about every other player who sees a ship approaching with the alliance flag raised and says "I don't need their help, I'll just kill them anyways". How stupid are you. MMO's like this thrive on player cooperation. Can we throw a bone to the soloists? In 40 hours of play (10 on PC, 30+ on gamepass) I had so many random crewmates join, then when they wanted to do something other than the voyage I was already in the middle of, just bounced? You're still gonna gain from my voyage, so why cut out? And holy crap the No-Mic'ers. Its a game about communication and you got no Mic? Turtle Beach Xbox/PC compatible is like 25 gold at any big box store. You're whats wrong with the player base.

Sea of Thieves might always have been a great game but I could not enjoy it until the recent release of Safer Seas. I am exclusively a solo player, I've had steam for years, I have 0 friends and that's the way I like it. Without safer seas, it's just not possible for me to have fun because 4v1 sucks. In no way, shape or form do I blame this on the developer, it's intended to be a multiplayer game (It's not you, it's me). This review is about Safer Seas ONLY.

The game is still not easy because I'm learning it solo, but it's super fun without getting 4v1. I still die a lot learning the ropes, but it's fun 100% of the time. The game really does have incredible atmosphere and I'm ecstatic I can actually enjoy it now. The game looks incredible, I could look at the waves all day, it's got great music. It really is an experience , I definitely recommend it.

Here's where the game gets it wrong:

Smaller ships have an advantage in combat against bigger ships. They're faster and they can be repaired by one person faster than a bigger ship can. A party of 4 of us lit up a little clipper that came to steal our loot, and not only was it not damaged at the end, but they sunk our ship. Our gigantic 4 person ship, sunk by basically a row boat. 

You spend half your time loading and unloading your boat.

The combat doesn't feel very satisfying.
The cosmetics are great but there's no progression.

The missions seem pretty soulless. In a game full of treasure, most missions feel like a mild payout. It's a grind.

I've got my worth out of it, but I won't recommend it to others.
