Here are my honest thoughts on the game!

High Seas: With over 150hours invested into High Seas, I feel I am in a good position to give an honest and fair review of High Seas, so, here it is - High Seas players for the most part are PvE players looking to enjoy friendly PvP encounters but want to focus on PvE content with maximum rewards gained for their valuable time and effort, HOWEVER; if the comments in these forums are anything to go off, those that would have you believe that the PvP community are lovely people are full of themselves! The PvP community in this game is by far the worst I have ever come across, even worse than DayZ (and that's saying something), they will constantly shun you, and purposefully try to bully you into believing their opinion is the right one and that you are not to be believed nor trusted with your experiences because they themselves have never had a bad one or have good ones every play through. This is far from the truth, if you load into High Seas, you can be rest assured that within your first few hours of playing the game, you will have some sweat-lord roll up on you and do what they do best, get toxic, verbally abusive to the point of telling you to "End yourself" and sink you while throwing slurs, and abuse your way (God only help you if you're a female player because you are going to get called a lot worse and really have some disgusting things said to you!), this is if they don't chase you across half the map first or you don't manage to run away and scuttle before they get to you. High Seas to the devs and PvP lords is a perfect game, couldn't be fixed, and must be played to their pleasure, not yours! I have spent many hours playing High Seas, and it has only gotten more toxic since Safer Seas has come out! Noting once again in these forums there are a few select people who get confused with PvEvP and PvPvE (the concept is simple, PvEvP = Player Vs ENVIRONMENT Vs Player = while PvP is a concept and component in the game, the core focus is PvE and the game SHOULD theoretically be played as such with the game mechanics facilitating this, with PvP elements to your PvE gameplay - NOT THE OTHER WAY AROUND as these people love to try to say this game is PvPvE - it is marketed, tagged and sold as a PvEvP) and unlike the very out of touch select group in these forums, having played my last HS session TODAY, I can tell you this entire statement is accurate having been minding my own business and rolled up on by a sweat lord, sworn at, called a coward, told to go "End yourself"(Edited because the 3 letter acronym is banned text) - "GO PLAY SS IF YOU DON'T WANT PVP LOSER!" - this is the type of gameplay they will try to tell you doesn't exist or "Rarely happens - you're just unlucky" but the truth is, it happens more often than they will admit and if they say it doesn't - they're probably the ones instigating it, with their entire argument backed by "Its called Sea Of Thieves" or "You got a PvPvE game - its what you paid for" ( sad mentality), which these people seem to harbour so much saltiness towards the PvE player base for some unknown reason, but its very sad they are so driven to make the PvE player base leave by bullying them out or at the very least conform to their ideology - bringing me back to the whole PvEvP meaning and what the game is actually marketed as compared to how the game is actually played.

Safer Seas: Oh let's talk about this game mode, it was wrongly advertised and wrongly marketed as a place where people who enjoy the aforementioned PvEvP can go to really enjoy their experience of Player Vs Environment and not be punished for it. However, we have seen a couple of moderators and players tell us this game mode serves as a "tutorial for HS", and if that is the case, should have been marketed as one in the first place before people spent REAL MONEY on a game to play a game mode that failed to deliver in its initial concept/ marketed purpose. Since this game mode has come out, these forums have EXPLODED with MANY MANY players expressing their sincere displeasure with this mode and how it has been delivered, attempting to give honest, constructive, and genuine feedback to the Moderation team and (as stated in a statement from Rare, this team works DIRECTLY WITH THEM) the devs in the hope that they would listen to this feedback and act in the best interest of their player base and not their own selfish desires, however, this has been the case where we have now seen the admin team forming a single-minded agenda based response system, copying and pasting responses, shutting down threads that tell them they are doing a bad job, and, (like myself) banning people who speak out more harshly against this type of despicable behaviour. The feedback given should of been welcomed but instead, we have been told that unlike every other game on the market, the devs WILL NOT ADAPT to their player base and will instead stick their heads in the sand and wish it all went away by censoring and silencing people who speak out against it! Let's get this out there, while this game mode might be enjoyed by a small handful of PvE players who like to play with their families or may have special access needs, this game mode is not enjoyed by the majority of PvE players, for its simple yet obvious attempt at giving the PvE community the middle finger by cutting profits/ rewards, taking away captained ships, blocking voyages and MORE! The attempts to silence people and delete their comments only go to show that anyone who does not agree with the dev's FAILED VISION of a PvP-only game will be silenced!

Like many others, I have spent real-world money on this game and in the EPIC store buying skins, etc, helping to keep the community, the player base, and the game alive (Not to mention pay these devs/ mods bills). I am sincerely appalled at the moderators and the dev team for their actions in silencing people for having opposing views that may shine a light on their actions and calling them out for it. In an age where censorship is the only way to enforce your point - it is disturbing to see it happening here too. I have compiled and will continue to compile video evidence of the censorship taking place on these forums which may make a great video one day - who knows? ;).

All I know is, IF you have read this far, and are considering buying this game, I would carefully think about your valuable REAL WORLD COIN, because if you do and are hoping the game will be a welcome place where you can act like a Pirate but have fun in the game - you may want to think again! The support structure in place both in these forums, and at Rare will not support any grievance you have - PvP tickets raised for toxic behaviour go unaddressed, and you had better not have an opposing view to that of the game devs or stand from under because you're in for hell if you do!

IF the Devs truly cared about the game, and their "Vision" they would listen to their community and adapt accordingly, take Fortnite for example, it listens to its community and adapts to the times giving its players what they ask for, because of it, they make MILLIONS of dollars a week (Estimated 8Billion in 2023 from 6 Billion in 2022) and are one of the most successful games running for many years now. If the Devs want to look at successful game models, Fortnite is one, along with many others, and paying attention to what's working and what isn't FOR YOUR COMMUNITY is how you run a successful business/ game! It's really that simple!

I know that I will cop a lot of abuse from these select group of players in these forums against this post, however, I have said what needed to be said and am not afraid to stick up for what's right and wrong! I am no sheep!

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Terrible audio, it changes somethings in windows to make you constantly hear your own mic input in your headphones. It will drive you insane after 5 minutes, with no clear guide or solution online to fix.

But also no. I actually sort of hate this game.

For one, I can't scale the FOV and I end up getting motion sick from it - which is rare (get it?) for that to happen to me as usually I can stomach VR and a few other things, but I always adjust the FOV to my preferences.

For another, since I'm usually stuck playing alone which isn't really a problem, it limits a lot of what I can do and I'm not keen for jumping onto a ship with totally random players. This leaves me prey to much larger groups of players (Who can come off as overtly toxic in many situations)

But the game is a beautifully well done game. Polished well with a strong idea and interesting approach (albeit slow) for combat. I wish there were proper combo's with the sword fighting, timed parry/blocking mechanics which just aren't really there. But the game proves to have a lot of merit with friends - but again, the PvP in the game can ruin it as almost every PvP scenario I've been in has usually been with toxic groups of players much larger than my own friend group

Or those camping nearby settlements with a larger group then my own friend group.

So the game becomes more of a chore then anything else. Perhaps I am missing a key component of the gameplay, but I know (inherently by playing it) the gameplay IS solid, the game is near bugless from my experience, and the stories on the islands, the missions and characters are all lively. Then there is the art-style of the gameplay in itself which is quite well done.

It's nothing as Rare as Rares' original titles years ago, but it is still a good game none-the-less even with my own issues about it. Granted I barely touch the game as playing solo is... well... kinda hell.
Can't recommend this game with the way the developers are going about changes. Constantly slapping veteran players in the face for years and with no signs of stopping.

The reason I picked up the Sea of Thieves was the Monkey Island expansion that was announced. After having gone through the adventure, I can securely say that any Monkey Island fan would love this game. How the Monkey Island tales are handled was extremely enjoyable, it follows much of the pathway taken in the first Monkey Island within an isolated arc of Sea of Thieves. The nostalgia is so spot on with considerable attention taken to make it meaningfully funny, the most important significance of this was in introducing pirate insult sword-fighting. Such a juxtaposition to the base game and such honest work put in to uplift the wittiness that made the point-and-click adventures so fun. I am still to go through the massive amount of content within the original game but from the perspective of a Monkey Island fan, I am incredibly happy at the amount of respect, thoughtfulness and extension to the world which was employed. An excellent pairing between two worlds.

Amazingly fun pirate game, ship controls and content to do make this game very unique, however public lobbies are toxic as hell and unless if you are a competitive person, it's a overall horrible experience.
Season 10 they added private lobbies but they disable so much content that it's only fun for beginning players, or intoxicated players. For the average person private lobbies are just boring.

Game itself has (unused) potential. It may be fun for certain playing style (very very casual and careless one, where all failure is just reason to laugh). However, that is not really way as I like to play games.

Game have very player unfriendly and very unintuitive set of concept of functions, in such way, that you have very hard to find any functions of game while inside of the game. For example, there is no indignation how you even do quests (or "voyages" as game call them). You need search from internet how these works. Often also in-game hints, for example where you sell this item you have in your hand, are misleading and not helpful. -"Go outpost" -"Well, this is outpost. We both are in outpost". Etc.

Content for "Pirates of the Caribbean" and "Monkey Island" are very lazily and poorly done, although latter one had at least some try. They felt more like poorly made "ghost train" in a theme park.

Game does not have any skill development nor items which have different stats, all items are just cosmetic. Of course this means, that it does very little matter if you die, since you cannot lose anything but your loot. But at least for me, it make the game more pointless. There is no progress. Ever.

Player base seems to be toxic. There is player groups who wait in certain points of map, where they know people more likely will come, just in order to kill them. For example final quest of "Pirates of the Caribbean", groups wait that other players are in most vulnerable position, sink their ship, and kill those players who want experice the story. There is no loot, so there is no benefits from ruining other player's experience, except sadistic satisfaction. Developers made this all possible, and they do not care such things, they are very happy with toxicity on community.

Recently there been added "Safer Seas" mode, where you can play alone with your crew in private server. However, developers want punish people who do not want PvP and give only 30% of in-game-currencty if you play with this way, as well, as locking parts of game content away. Developers could chose actually make very interesting PvM servers, where all players would seen friendly and loot would be tied for crew who made the quest or event where it was got. And adding more spawns in areas where is more players, make world bit more dangerous, but manageable. But no. Developers do not want players to have fun. You can only play with sadists or alone.

This game is not made to be fun to play, but just to be money-maker by micro transactions with cosmetic items. Everything in it seems to be done as little effort as possible. I will put this game "forgot" folder, and focus on actually good and interesting games.

Rating: 5/5

Sea of Thieves is a breathtaking multiplayer action-adventure game developed by Rare. Set in an open-world pirate environment, the game offers an immersive and unique experience that truly stands out in the gaming industry.

Graphics and Design (5/5):
The game boasts stunning visuals that bring its vibrant, cartoonish world to life. The attention to detail is remarkable, from the realistic water physics to the dynamic weather effects that make sailing the seas a visually captivating experience. The character design, landscapes, and ship models contribute to the game's overall aesthetic, creating a visually appealing and cohesive world.

Gameplay and Exploration (5/5):
Sea of Thieves excels in providing an unparalleled sense of freedom and exploration. The vast open world is filled with hidden treasures, mysterious islands, and formidable enemies. The game's open-ended design encourages player creativity and cooperation, making every session unique. Whether embarking on a treasure hunt, engaging in ship-to-ship combat, or exploring eerie underwater caves, the gameplay is diverse and consistently engaging.

Multiplayer Dynamics (5/5):
The heart of Sea of Thieves lies in its multiplayer experience. The game seamlessly integrates cooperative play, encouraging teamwork and communication among players. Sailing a ship with a crew, each member responsible for different tasks, adds a layer of realism and excitement. The unpredictability of encounters with other player crews on the vast seas contributes to the game's dynamic and thrilling atmosphere.

Progression System (5/5):
Sea of Thieves strikes a perfect balance between accessibility and depth with its progression system. Players can customize their pirate's appearance and ship, and progression is based on a reputation system tied to various factions in the game. The continuous updates and expansions introduced by the developers keep the content fresh, offering new challenges and rewards for both new and seasoned players.

Community and Support (5/5):
Rare has demonstrated a commitment to fostering a positive community around Sea of Thieves. Regular updates, events, and engagement with the player base showcase the developers' dedication to the game's ongoing success. The Sea of Thieves community is known for its friendly and collaborative nature, enhancing the overall gaming experience.

Conclusion:
Sea of Thieves is a masterpiece in the action-adventure genre, combining breathtaking visuals, engaging gameplay, and a vibrant multiplayer experience. The game's commitment to player agency, coupled with continuous updates and community support, makes it a must-play for anyone seeking a truly immersive and enjoyable gaming experience. With its perfect blend of exploration, cooperative play, and unpredictability, Sea of Thieves deserves a solid 5 out of 5 rating.

I played this game on game pass when it came out and around a year later. And maybe one more time again a year later.  I love this game's atmosphere and the visuals, how you control your ship, and the awesome voyages. Where the game doesn't hold your hand. You need to search for treasure and solve riddles. But i got irritated really fast about how you can't avoid PvP.
In the early times people were attacking each other simply for the loot. But with time and with the growing popularity amongs streamers who constantly invented and popularized new ways to grief and troll people, the community became more and more toxic.

So many people wanted to have PvE from the beginning. 

I promised myself, i will only buy this game when they add PvE.
And they did, and i kept myself to the promise.

Yeas there are restrictions in PvE. You earn only 30%f the gold you can earn in PvP. And a small number of endgame activities are not available. Yes i would love to see these restrictions go. But i don't care neither. I love sailing the seas without some random toxic person constantly ruining my enjoyment.

Well after reaching Pirate Legend and Athena's fortune Champion titles,
I'm finally able to make a review of this game, I hope it will help you decide if this game is worth it! I'll probably update this review the further I play. For now I'll be talkin about the [b]Adventure mode[/b] :)

Pros :
-Cool graphics and simulation of a pirate life.
-It's a game where you either get addicted or hate it in the first hours.
-Funnier with friends or randoms, but you'll learn so much faster in solo trust me.
-Satisfying sensation when you sink ennemies boats and grab their loot.
-Good game if you want to chill and kill time (but sometimes it can be stressful especially if you have a lot of loots and you're getting focused by a reaper or red flag emissaries).
-Active developer team (monthly updates, quick reactivity on problems in-game through their tweeter, so I would recommend to follow them there to not miss a thing and to always be aware of what's happening).
-A lot to experience, Stories, PVP, Fishing, Treasure Hunting, defeating Skeletons, world events, Seasonal events, Shipfight, collecting all achievements, and laugh with strangers :D

Cons:
-Intensive grind.
-Boring after a while.
-Lack of content eventhough it was way worse back when it came out in 2018.
-FPS optimization is a joke on islands (At full ultra I go from 120fps to 55 fps on big islands).
-PVP mechanic is old and boring (idk maybe they need to add some new guns or mechanics).
-Bugs after new updates are not even a surprise anymore.
-Servers issues is normal and the community is used to it (so an advice would be to never do an event the day it comes out because you probably won't receive your loot's coins, XP and achievements).
-Some events are only visible on their website and not in-game so sometimes you can miss them (Just stop it, we are lazy and hate to go through google to see our fck in-game event progression, just put it in game already ffs it's 2020).

Overall the game has a lot of problems but I still love the concept it does represent otherwise I wouldn't have reach one of the highest titles you can earn and I hope this game will continue to get the support it deserves. I haven't played such a great game in a while, so if you like intensive farming, bugs, coop and pvp but also the big map you're in the right place. We'll be waiting for you on the ocean :)

PS: If you're a veteran please help new players and don't bully them, that's what I do and I would have loved to be helped too when I started, so please do so they will always remember you, thanks fellow Legends.



[h1]Edit 1:[/h1]
So after 3 months, the game is still awesome, probably one of the best open world in multiplayer that I've played in a while. Nothing better but to fish with friends during late nights.



[h1]Edit 2:[/h1]
They finally added an Even tab in-game! Anyway I've been playing [b]Arena[/b], joined a competitive team and reached Legendary Sea Dog. So the Arena mode is way different from the actual game (adventure). It also have its pros and cons so here we go :

For the positive aspects :
- Helps you improve cannon shots
- Helps you improve your weapon accuracy
- TDM (Team deathmatch) is a lot of fun! It's like the endgame community event in the Arena
- You can make friends in this mode
- Since the last Arena patch, there's only one chest now and it's way better than before

Some negative aspects :
- Hitregs (When you hit players usually with weapons and you have the hitmarker but the server didn't register the damage, so sometimes you'll need to hit 3-4 time the player before he dies, and sometimes you may think they're cheater)
- Lobby waiting time : because the Arena mode is not the main mode, the playerbase is not that big here, so you might wait 10-30min in the worst case...
- Server region merge : Yeah well sometimes there's no server in EU (in my exemple) at certain hours and I usually get matched with NA players and I have an average of 200-250ms
- FPS optimization (Even on High-End PC you'll probably struggle to maintain a stable 144fps



[h1]Edit 3:[/h1]
They removed their own game mode called Arena. I don't know if it would now be an interesting game for pirate that love to pvp...
Quite a sad day for Sea of Thieves...



[h1]Edit 4:[/h1]
They added an alternative to the Arena inside of the Adventure mode!
Which means that you can now activate a totem on your boat which will transport you against another equivalent ship. Basically a great thing for the pvp community! Not tom mention you can customize your own ship, name it how you want, and even create or joind a Guild!

At the current state, I would seriously recommend this game to every gamers wanting to experience some adventure in the pirate world. In 2023 there is a lot of things to do, explore, farm, fight, collect and stories to experiences which are really amazing.


[b]Thanks for all the support I received for this review, I wish you all a good day :)[/b]

I honestly love playing this game. Sometimes there are small bugs or bigger ones that you laugh at with your friends, but overall it's very fun. Any gold you earn in this game is spent on cosmetics, more quests, and becoming a captains. Though I will say the amount you spend on quests is pretty much pocket change. It definitely takes a while to really learn the mechanics of the game, and learning with a friend is best. However, if you don't have a friend who has played this game before definitely check out the official Sea of Thieves discord. It's a hub for players to go to to find crews with the same goals or someone to teach you the ropes of the game. Everyone uses it.
It is worth noting that this game runs through Xbox and thus requires a Microsoft account to play. So, if you play on steam you'll mostly be inviting people with the game bar, also occasionally on steam the updates can be a tad glitched but entirely fixable. Would recommend.
I will also say it is in the nature of this game for their to be a lot of PVP and ship battle and stealing. It's a pirate game.

Edit: The end was a bit toxic so I deleted, but I want to address the PVP vs PVE people  in the reviews of this game. I honestly really enjoy playing both parts of the games and my ideal run of Sea of Thieves is when I have a fairly even amount of player fights and normal in-game missions or whatever. I understand the sentiment of players who really enjoy the PVE elements and don't want to be involved with PVP. I used to feel the same way when I was new to the game, but sometimes I feel like people fail to realize what this game is. It's about being pirates and stealing from each other and the world. I've realized the longer that I've played that's it's not really about winning the battles with players, it's about enjoying playing the game with them. I have sunk and been sunk by many different in the game, and I love it everytime. This game is honestly one of my favorites.

Note to struggling players: If you are struggling with getting levels and playing the game because you can't make progress let me help you out here.
1. A lot of PVP players will choose whether or not a ship has an emissary flag flying as the deciding factor for attacking you. If you have an emissary on you are a target, but also you should always be flying an emissary to get more xp.
2.If you are really struggling with PVP people I would highy recommend going to the discord and asking for help for a more veteran player. It really helps to be able to learn how to defend yourself better. Honestly, I was carried a lot before I could hold my own. If you don't want the help, server hop.
3.Avoid going solo unless you know what you're doing
4.PVP is a major part of this game and there is no avoiding it unless you want a massive cut in gold and reputation in the safer seas. I personally think the PVP is great, but please consider that if you do not like PVP you may not like this game as much.

UPDATE: the Safer Seas update attempted to address the issue that the game is unplayably frustrating with other players. Now, you can sail with your crew and not have any other players on the map. The issue is... its shit. Ontop of the fact all rewards are accrued at a pathetically low 30% of the rate they are in the normal mode, you're also capped to level 40 in all trading companies. The reward reduction is actually even harsher than 30% since you can't play as an Emissary. Even if you're fine losing out on potential rewards, you also can't bring your own ship in, so say goodbye to that level of customization. Guilds are also flat-out impossible to level. If this update interested you, just know it sucks.

This game is a lot of fun... if you have exactly 3 friends willing to play it with you. In any other situation, I wouldn't recommend it. Its equally refreshing and baffling in its design. 
There's no permanent progression system, every time you boot up the game you essentially start fresh minus unlocking more content and cosmetics. That's very unique for this sort of game, but I wish you could at least carry SOME stuff over, like having a permanent inventory. It makes stuff like fishing feel kinda superfluous.
The meat of the game is looting treasure, hidden on islands and stolen from ghost ships. Finding treasure with maps and hints is really fun, the sailing is enjoyable, but the one thing that ruins the entire experience is other players. Essentially everyone you meet is going to try and grief you. If you're a solo player, prepare to have literal hours of work lost because another crew ganged up on you and stole all your treasure. If your ship is lost, you lose EVERYTHING you haven't sold. There's absolutely no way to prevent it from happening. You WILL eventually get snuck up on and lose your ship. Its just a gamble on if you survive long enough to sell.
If you can find a full crew, you stand a chance, but alone you're just fucked.

Update: Now that Safer Seas is out, I've happily returned to peacefully sail the Sea of Thieves! I've greatly enjoyed exploring, sailing, collecting skulls and finding treasure and finally able to pursue Tall Tales without player disruption. I personally don't mind the reduced rep and gold for voyages if it means I get to enjoy the game without forced PvP. Safer Seas is a great addition! 

The game is SUPER beautiful and the water and sailing were really amazing experiences.

Though if you are a working professional without a lot of time to play games and you really want to enjoy the time you DO get, don't get this game.  You'll be griefed by some 12 old year who watches Twich all day and just steals your stuff. I tried to sail away but he just blasted my ship to pieces before I could even get away... after he sunk me I lost all of my progress that I just made effectively wasting that 4 hours of game play.

I don't have the time or patience to deal with PvP nonesense.  Save that for the kidos who have the time to waste. Requesting a refund for this game until they add a PvE option for those of us who are older than 14.

Even if you're not a Pirates of the Caribbean fan, this game is still really fun!
Acting like a pirate and sailing the sea is an experience I was missing out on in life.
I will warn that the story campaigns can bug out sometimes, for example I had to redo the mermaid story-line because the mermaids wouldn't spawn so I was unable to progress through the story and had to restart, luckily it worked fine the 2nd time around.
The puzzles in the game are SO MUCH FUN! I'm a sucker for finding clues and solving puzzles. I also really love taking a treasure map and finding the buried hidden goodies under the sand/dirt, it gives a rush of happiness when you find the right spot.
So the PvE aspect of this game is really enjoyable, especially when playing with friends. The PvP aspect can be a bit troublesome if you don't have friends to play with you that you can coordinate with, or a good team on your side in general, it can be pretty challenging and frustrating especially when the enemy ship players can yell curses and other inappropriate stuff at you with the proximity voice chat so if you're not a fan of the classic toxicity that comes along with PvP then I don't recommend playing PvP. I do believe there is an option to sail "safe" seas (or change the instance you're in to a different one) so that you don't have to worry about other players coming to attack you and steal the loot you worked hard for.
I will say the game can get kind of repetitive after a while and I feel like they should add more things to do, perhaps adding some mini-games of some kind on the city islands could be a real fun way to bring more of the community together. Because that's honestly another complaint of mine is that I don't run into people very often, unless they're chasing me to attack me or unless I'm chasing them to attack them. So I feel like there's a lack of PvE player interaction. I know you can just join random people's ships with the xbox group finder but honestly what is the fun in that? I would much rather naturally run into someone on an island trying to work together to play a mini-game or solve a puzzle together or something, I think that would be much more fun and immersive.
I also have to mention that if you get motion sickness easily then maybe don't play this game. You're spending A LOT of time out at sea and the swaying of the ship could mess with you. I played with a friend who has motion sickness and he couldn't play for very long because of it so just be cautious of that.
As far as everything else goes, I have a blast playing this game and especially recommend playing with friends because that's where the true fun happens when you are goofing around on the ship playing music or drinking until you barf or petting each other's pets or helping your crew blast an enemy ship down or solving puzzles together. It's overall a perfect game to play with friends! (you can fish too if you want a more chill activity)
And if you ARE a Pirates of the Caribbean fan, this game will be even more up your ally!

So I initially gave this game a positive review, but with the Safer Seas update, I can't recommend this to the general populous anymore. 

For those of you who are unaware, Safer Seas is Rare's poor attempt at a PvE mode. Basically, you make 30% what you normally would in PvP servers, have a very stringent level cap, can't be an emissary, can't use your own captained ship(s), can't participate in guilds, and can't even participate in quite a few missions.

This mode is a joke and a slap in the face to those who just want to chill out and go on adventures with friends, or just roleplay as a god damn pirate. 

This is especially insulting since there are a ton of toxic players who will shout slurs at you and hunt you down for several hours if you dare even slight them. And if you report them for being toxic, Rare is very unlikely to do anything about it. Keep in mind this is not even considering the fact that Rare won't do anything about the rampant cheater problem that has existed since the game came out in 2018.

I love this game to death and have sunk hundreds of hours into it across xbox and pc, but I cannot in good faith recommend this to people. 

Rare, for the love that all is holy, stop treating people who have full time jobs, people who are in school, and people who generally just have lives as second class citizens in this amazing world you have crafted, lest you lose even more respect than people already have in you.

I refunded this game because the "Safer Seas" Mode, which I thought was a way to finally play this game like I always wanted to; solo and not beeing forced into PvP with sweaty neckbeards, turned out to be nothing but a glorified tutorial mode. Your gold and reputation gains are much lower than in the pvp mode and you are capped at level 40 with many features straight up not beeing avaliable in this mode.

All this mode is is a way for rare to try and lure in some fresh blood for the diehard pvp players. Because eventually you will have to enter pvp mode if you want to experience all the game has to offer. Get ready to be trolled, griefed, spawn camped and called racial slurs. The community of this game is toxic and as a new player you don't stand a chance against the people playing this game for years now. Nothing is more frustrating than to loot some treasures and bring it to a harbor only to be killed by a bored veteran a couple of feet in front of the merchant, effectively deleting all your progress of the last hours. 

Also the controls and combat feel incredibly dated and clunky and everything about this game just screams "I am a console game". Even within the first few hours you will feel like you've done it all before, the missions are repetitiv and quite boring, there is nothing to unlock aside from cosmetics and nothing to change up your gameplay. Only good thing I can say is that sailing is kind of fun and the way the ocean waves move dynamically is pretty cool.
 If you don't already own this avoid it.

A Pirate's Chronicle: Navigating the Wonders of Sea of Thieves

Avast, me hearties! Let me spin ye a yarn about the wondrous seas of Sea of Thieves, a realm where the salty air be filled with tales of plunder, perilous battles, and the allure of hidden treasures.

First and foremost, let's talk about the beauty of this vast expanse. The seas stretch out like a canvas painted by the Almighty himself, with sunsets that set the sky ablaze in a riot of colors. The waves, me mateys, they dance and frolic, a constant reminder that the sea be a fickle mistress. The islands, draped in verdant greenery and shadowy caves, be beckoning like sirens, tempting us to explore their secrets.

But what truly sets the heart pounding is the clash of steel and thunder on the treacherous battleground known as Hourglass. The roar of cannons, the splintering of wood, and the taste of sea spray in the air – it's the symphony of chaos that every true pirate lives for. Hourglass be a crucible where crews lock horns in ship-to-ship combat, and let me tell ye, there be no sweeter victory than sending a rival to Davy Jones' locker.

Picture this, me hearties: the wind howling through the rigging, the ships weaving and dodging like a dance of death. It be a spectacle that would make even the Flying Dutchman shiver in its ghostly timbers. The thrill of the fight be like a shot of the finest grog, warming the belly and quickening the pulse.

But a pirate's life ain't all cutlasses and cannonballs. Nay, there be moments of quiet reflection and camaraderie. Sailing the open seas with naught but the wind at yer back and the creak of the ship beneath yer boots – it be a balm for the soul. The freedom to chart yer own course, discover hidden coves, and dig up the spoils of buried treasure be the essence of the pirate's code.

And then there be the tales of Glitter Beard, a legend among legends. The encounters with this mysterious soul and others like him be the stuff of legend, passed down from one pirate to the next around the tavern fire. Ally or adversary, the unpredictability of these interactions be the true spice of the Sea of Thieves.

In the end, Sea of Thieves be more than a game; it be a saga of high seas adventure, where every ebb and flow, every battle won and treasure plundered, be etched into the annals of pirate lore. So, me hearties, hoist the Jolly Roger, set sail for the horizon, and let the Sea of Thieves weave its tale around ye!

I first got this game 2 years ago I think, and trying to play it solo was a nightmare. I would always want to reinstall it and hop in but with no friends that enjoyed it I was out of luck. Getting chased down by any ship that happens to smell me and hearing profanities yelled out the ass at me was just a huge deterrent. 
 
A year ago I joined a great friend group and beginning of this year we started to play a lot of this game. (clearly I have almost 600 hours in just like 8 months) Occasionally the PVP gets to me and I rage-quit, but with a competent crew I was able to learn and get better. And I really love this game now. And I am more confident in my abilities than I was when I first bought the game.

And I am extremely happy that safer seas was added, because now (when my dad actually gets around to making his damn pc, bastard) I can introduce my dad to the normal PVE loop without the toxicity of the PVP community. (And eventually we would switch to the high seas, for more gold!) And for many other new or young players this is a great thing. I have seen many kids playing with their fathers on here, and in the same server I hear people screaming the N word at the top of their lungs, so having safer seas as an option, it is nice to avoid the toxicity of the community and just to learn the regular PVE loop! You can learn to aim cannons by fighting off skeleton ships, you can learn the sword to sword combat by doing tall tales or just going on islands, without the worry of some sweats chasing you out of the map. 

The biggest problem I have with the actual game is that they prioritize pay piggy content and not new actual good quests.

I have been playing on console since early summer 2023 and now have over 650 hours in the game. My Xbox yearly wrap-up revealed that I am among the top 5% of players in the world in number of hours played this year so I feel qualified to give my opinion. As a matter of fact, I don’t think I’ve ever put so many hours into a game previously and it quickly became one of my favorite titles. It’s a great game but not without its faults. It has one of the most toxic but also most incredibly awesome and friendly communities I have ever experienced in a game. My all-time favorite multiplayer memories come from this game. But there are a few things that you will need to be comfortable with in order to really enjoy it: 

-	It is a grind. There is no skill leveling other than naturally getting better at things through practice (more on that later) and very few items that you can unlock will give you a tactical advantage over other players. The items that DO provide a small advantage (which is mostly because of some small detail in the item’s artistic design that comes across as almost accidental) are slowly being nerfed. The number one way that veteran players have to demonstrate their skill and experience is through expensive in-game cosmetics and those cosmetics take a very very long time and often require repeating the same task hundreds or in some cases thousands of times (that’s not an exaggeration). If you do not like repetition this is not the game for you. This game will afford you few advantages beyond “getting good” through run of the mill practice and experience.

-	If you have anxiety in any form this game is probably not for you. It takes a long time to amass gold and it is incredibly easy to lose it. You will earn and lose fortunes in High Seas mode. It’s part of what makes the game fun (there is no reward without risk, after all) but the paranoia can be incredibly nerve wracking and overwhelming – particularly when you are starting out and don’t yet know the “systems” for earning large amounts of gold more efficiently in the game.

-	The game does not hold your hand and will not teach you anything. And, for the most part, neither will internet searches. You must learn from experience, observation, and anecdotes from more veteran players. Which really does make the game feel authentically old-timey and special. There is nothing like finding a crusty veteran player who is jaded as heck and befriending them to learn all the tricks. The best thing that you can do is find a mentor – just don’t be overly trusting because it is a pirate game and even the nicest players constantly have their guard up. After a while you will have amassed quite a few preferences and habits to improve your survival and make yourself more efficient. Some of these are the results of intentional design features but many of them are taking advantage of loopholes in the design principles. There are many of these that the devs purposefully leave in the game and encourage and others that they patch. They have gone on the record of saying “if Jack Sparrow could do it it’s fair game”. An example would be that fighting other ships on the left side of your Sloop decreases your chances of being sunk because there are two spots along the left bulkhead of your ship that lack hitboxes due to the placement of your ship’s grog barrel and bunk and therefore the left side cannot take the same number of holes as your right side can. The game is full of little “hacks” like this to learn on your own. I learn something new almost every time I play over six hundred hours later. 

-	The developers are currently more concerned with revenue in the form of their Plunder Pass, microtransactions, and real-world merchandise sales than anything else. I don’t blame them for this – they have to feed their families. And they do give out quite a few freebies through Twitch streams and in-game events if you monitor their social media channels and participate in events. But because of their focus on continuous revenue…

-	The game has a lot of bugs. This is a big frustration to game fans. The game lacks anti-cheat and the money that players spend seems to be funneled into new cosmetics to purchase with real money rather than anti-cheat, new content/events, or bug fixes. Oftentimes the bugs are Bethesda-level hilarious like flying ships but other times they are frustrating and game-breaking like a ship-sinking invisible rock that has been present in the center of the map for months. These can be particularly frustrating when they prevent you from turning in a large hoard of treasure that you have spent a few hours collecting. 

All of that being said, the game really is fun. There is nothing more exhilarating than fighting off a rival pirate crew attempting to steal your loot or joining forces with all of the rest of the server to maximize your gains together until one crew inevitably tries to betray the rest and make off with everything. I’ve made the best long-lasting sincere gamer friendships with strangers that I’ve met playing this game and have yet to grow tired of playing it. But I’ve also met players who made me question humanity and caused me to rage quit. Know what you’re getting into and evaluate whether or not you can handle the frustrations. It’s an incredibly beautiful and fun sandbox to make friends in and explore. 

Oh, and learn what Glitterbeard is, why it exists, and do it as soon as you can…you won’t regret it.

so edit:
After having had played for a while i decided to stop playing this game for a very long time, specifically, over a year now. And the reason was that events, adventures, seasons and the like were passing by way to fast, in comparison to how long you need to play the game to actually complete them. Not everyone can just sit down and play the game for 5 hours a day, and if you only play an hour at a time, you're never gonna get anything done, because you start getting emmisary bonuses and other once you've invested enough in a session. My other gripe with this game how grindy and reppetitive it was. As a wannabe completionist I want to do all the achievements, unlock everything, do all the events, but I just started finding myself playing this game less and less, because it started feeling slower and slower while limited time things just kept going by faster and faster, if i didn't play for a week or two, i would be forever locked out of some cool sails or equipment just because i didn't play at that specific point in time. 
And the thing that killed me off finally was the removal of Arena mode. While i didn't play it much, I was still appreciative of it existing, because I knew that whenever I wanted something more fast paced I could have it, but they chose to remove it, not only was I mad that I couldn't play arena, but I was more mad that my arena related achievements and equipment could never be completed and unlocked again, leaving me in a completionist hellscape of half finished things.

Now I havent kept up with anything news related for this game while ive been away. Maybe they've improved the aspects i disliked, maybe they've brought back arena, who knows, I sure don't. I will possibly try it out again soon, but no promises.

And to wrap this up, I still reccomend the game, the time I had with it were some of my most enjoyable days and hangouts with friends and strangers, but I don't know how ready I am to come back to it. Peace.

An ever growing game by Rare. Captain your own ship and engage in a pirate's life of finding treasure, or stealing it from other players. Everything of consequence is available at the start, and it's all about unlocking and buying new skins for the individual pieces.

Yes

I like this game.

I have the most fun in high seas with a group of four friends.

But I do not like playing single player high seas. It just feels like I waste hours of my time to try and do anything just to get smacked down. With friends, I don't mind so much because that moment feels shared with other people.

You could argue as a first argument, just get better at the game. In fact I may go so far as to say you may be right in that response.

But I have other games I like to play, and other things I like to invest my time in. Spending countless hours in sea of thieves getting better at combat just so I'm not grieved as much, I just simply do not want to do. Is that a me problem? Maybe. But I want to enjoy the game without that element.

So here's the part with safer seas. It exists. And it is not terrible. However the inability to enjoy many features that are present in high seas in one thing, however the amount of things limited in safer seas, and how little money is earned feels more like a punishment on players like me than enabling a different way to play for me. It just feels unfriendly.

I understand that Rare likely wants people to enjoy this game in a specific way. And that way may be the true multiplayer sandbox experience. However it has a large presence of what in my opinion, is toxic players, that I find very difficult to avoid. It is discouraging, and largely makes me feel that Sea of Thieves just might not be a game for me most times as a result.

Safer seas, I admit, I am happy has enabled me to be able to enjoy the beautiful world of Sea of Thieves without such toxicity. Despite it's glaring flaws, I still play it. The fact I can lose hours in it and feel nice afterward I think is a telltale sign that the game is clearly fun in some way, at least to me.

I like this game, I have for a long time and that has not changed. But I dread the idea that I may need to accept, still, that this game may not be for me for how Rare seems to want it played. That is fine, but I repeat -- the amount of time I feel I need to invest to properly enjoy how they prefer people play it, is just time I'd prefer to spend elsewhere.
Which is a tragedy, because this I find is the only modern game that has Rare character written all over it. And I wish I could enjoy it more outside of friend groups.

This isn't a review but a big shoutout to Rare for the Safer Seas mode. I've tried many times in the past to play Sea of Thieves but while I was always minding my own business on my little sloop, there were always some irritable and toxic people who enjoyed ruining my enjoyment of the game. While I understand that the game was meant to be a pvpve, I stopped so many times because I simply wasn't having fun at all. Even my friends didn't wanted to play with me because of the pvp so I was stuck to play solo. Now with the Safer Seas mode, we all can finally enjoy the game I was hoping for to play since launch and do the campaigns we were waiting to do for a long time! From the bottom of my heart, thank you Rare!! Very appreciated!

(Sorry for the length) Its a real shame that this game is PvP focused, as the baseline mechanics and graphics are superb, but sadly due to Rare's 100% balancing for PvP there is absolutely no progression in this game outside of cosmetic skins, faction experience and in game decorations like pets. There are no skills, special abilities or tools/weapons outside of what you start the game with. It gets dry pretty quick. Although this game does have tons of locations and interesting missions, its plagued with griefers and dedicated PvP players. Although there is a Arena, most of the remaining player base is dedicated to attacking players in the open servers. If you have a group of exactly 4 friends than you can take a large ship and explore/loot in a somewhat quick and rewarding fashion, and easily take on the 1-3 player PvP groups that attack anything that moves regardless of its worth/faction. If your into PvP there is a faction dedicated to killing players and it rewards you with cosmetic items and in game currency that can be used to buy cosmetic items... its worthless to play PvP. At least with the non-PvP story missions you get some interesting quests to fight waves of enemies and ghosts along with traps and puzzles. Anyways if you get it on sale for $5 or less its worth the few hours of game-play and exploration with friends.

Absolutely am in love with this game, the aesthetics, the scenery, the sailing, and above all just being able to play with my friends and have a good time. This game has so many different activities you can do such as: digging up treasure, slaying skeletons for their skulls, trading cargo between outposts, fishing, slaying Krakens and Megalodons, destroying skeleton ships, PVP with other players, and more!! If you play this game, you're bound to find something you'll love doing in it!! Just, watch out for other player ships that want your loot as much as you want yours!

Review at 15.8 hours:

Great game. Sailing is fun, Combat is fun. Voyages are more fun by yourself, but world events and PVP is better with friends. But either way it is an amazing game to play with your friends. 8/10 Would recomend.

Review at 167.8 hours:

Amazing game. Compared to everything else, voyages are not very fun by yourself or with friends. However combat is still very fun. World events are fun to do by yourself or with friends. PVP is hard, annoying, and just not fun when you start playing. However when you accept the fact that PVP is an essential part of the game, it gets very fun and exciting. Hourglass PVP introduced in season 8 is a great way to get better at it. I'm by no means good at PVP but i have gotten way better at it and I no longer run from every ship I see. 

In short, great game. Buy it if you like pirates and playing with friends, you will have a lot of fun.

Review at 286.2 hours:

It's still a great game, which is why I still rate it 8.5/10, however, after unlocking the Skeleton Curse, and then unlocking Pirate Legend, the game has been pretty bland lately. Season 9 lasted about 7 months which was way too long for what it was; a QoL update. With that being said, Season 10 is not that special either. I also despise the decision to add PvE servers into the game come December 2023. I wish Rare would focus on making the game less buggy and fun instead of making pointless updates that completely go against the premise of the game. 
People don't understand that the constant risk of another pirate stealing the treasure you found is what makes the game fun. If you can't handle one of the core aspects of this game, it is not for you. 

Tldr: It's a skill issue if you can't handle PvP. Get good.


8.5/10 Would recommend
